PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr SPEAKER (Rt Hon. Sir Billy Snedden) took the chair at 1.45 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies have been referred to the appropriate Ministers:

PETITION.TITLE: Community Youth Support Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia claimeth:
That we deplore the closure of all the Community Youth Support Schemes as they provide an essential welfare service to the young unemployed.
CYSS provides a tangible community support for youth suffering the emotional, social and economic effects of long-term unemployment.
We believe that the decision to abandon CYSS is a mistake demonstrating a lack of awareness on behalf of the Government. CYSS helps the unemployed to help themselves.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives takes all possible steps to continue funding of CYSS programs.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Community Youth Support Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned wish to strongly protest against the deplorable action of the Federal Government in disbanding the Community Youth Support Scheme. The scheme provides the only means of support for the young unemployed in the Kyogle area. We urge the Federal Government to provide the funding necessary to maintain the scheme or establish alternative assistance for the young unemployed.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Community Youth Support Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia who respectfully showeth:
Their anger and condemnation at the Fraser Government's decision to abolish all Community Youth Support Schemes on 31st October 1981.
Further they denounce the decision for the disastrous effects it will have on growing numbers of unemployed young people around Australia.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Government immediately and fully reverse its decision and restore complete funding to the Community Youth Support Scheme.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Sir William McMahon,Mr Hicks,Mr Kerin,Mr Les McMahon and Mr O'Keefe.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: ADERMANN; CHILD; DARLING; FREE; MILDREN; MILLAR; SCHOLES
PETITION.NAMEIDS: ID4; HF4; UD4; HG4; AI4; CI4; 5J4
PETITION.TITLE: Community Youth Support Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That a need exists within the community for the Community Youth Support Scheme.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government not remove any funds for the Community Youth Support Scheme.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Adermann,Mrs Child,Mrs Darling,Mr Free,Mr Mildren,Mr Millar and Mr Scholes.

PETITION.TITLE: Community Youth Support Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
We, the undersigned are concerned with Government closure of CYSS (Community Youth Support Scheme).

CYSS groups act as a resource centre for unemployed youth and provide low budget living skills. The breakdown of this link between youth and community activities will surely be of great harm to many unemployed youth in the Illawarra Region.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Government continues its allocation of funds to enable the provision of Community Youth Services.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Cowan and Mr West.

PETITION.TITLE: Community Youth Support Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the decision of the Government to abandon the only tangible form of direct assistance to Australia's young unemployed, ie, the Community Youth Support Scheme, will have a serious effect on the thousands of young Australians presently benefitting from the operation of the scheme through almost 300 decentralised CYSS centres around Australia.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will reverse this retrograde decision before the due date of termination on October 31st.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Community Youth Support Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully demand:
That the decision of the Government to end funding for the Community Youth Support Schemes on October 31, 1981, as announced by the Treasurer in the Budget Speech of 18 August 1981, be reversed.

Community Youth Support Schemes have operated successfully for five years and provide valuable community support and educational opportunities for unemployed young people which will not be adequately provided by other Government programmes. The full effect of the abolition of Community Youth Support Schemes will be felt by the unemployed people whose opportunities to participate in the Australian Community will be further diminished.
The petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives take all steps necessary to ensure continued Government funding of Community Youth Support Schemes.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Community Youth Support Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
1. That the Federal Government's Budget decision to disband the Community Youth Support Scheme is a total abandonment of the so-called 'hard-core unemployed' and indeed of all unemployed youth.
2. That the Government has ignored the valuable contribution made by CYSS Centres in teaching basic skills and self-reliance and in mediating between the community and the unemployed.
3. That the Government has breached a 1980 election promise to increase its financial assistance to all youth programs.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will call on the Government to revoke this Budget decision and restore funding to CYSS in line with its 1980 election promise.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Community Youth Support Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia, respectfully showeth:

That your petitioners are gravely concerned at the Federal Government's decision to abolish the Community Youth Support Scheme (CYSS). There is no other agency to give the support and care which the participants of the Community Youth Support Scheme require. Transitional education schemes are suitable for only a small number of the unemployed.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Parliament allocate the necessary funds to enable the continuation of the Community Youth Support Scheme.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Community Youth Support Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament as assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
Their anger at the Government's decision to abolish all Community Youth Support Schemes on the 31st October, 1981, despite previous assurances of the Minister of Employment and Youth Affairs.

Further they submit that the decision will have disastrous effects on numbers of unemployed young people around Australia, in that no other government scheme can assist the 50,000 people annually serviced by CYSS.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Government immediately and fully reverse its decision and restore complete funding in the Community Youth Support Scheme.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: CAMERON; DUFFY; FISHER; HOLDING; MACPHEE; SHIPTON
PETITION.TITLE: Community Youth Support Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Victoria respectfully showeth.
That the serious youth unemployment problem is a direct result of the community's failure to create sufficient jobs.

In these circumstances the decision to abolish Community Youth Support Schemes (CYSS) is a socially retrogressive step. The CYSS Projects provide valuable support services and work training for many young unemployed.

We the undersigned are concerned that the closure of CYSS Projects may lead young unemployed to become involved in anti-social behaviour such as crime, vandalism, prostitution, rebellious behaviour and mob action. There is the even more frightening prospect that many more young people will give up hope of obtaining a job, become idle and even contemplate suicide.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Government reverse its decision to abolish CYSS Projects and provide sufficient funds to enable the various CYSS Centres to continue their valuable work with the young unemployed in the future.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Ewen Cameron,Mr Duffy,Mr Fisher,Mr Holding,Mr Macphee and Mr Shipton.

PETITION.TITLE: Community Youth Support Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
We the undersigned, Citizens of Chigwell, Tasmania, hereby humbly pray that the Federal Government reconsider the decision to cease funding the Community Youth Support Scheme.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Community Youth Support Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Geelong respectfully showeth:
That the serious youth unemployment problem is a direct result of the community's failure to create sufficient jobs:
We the people of the Geelong Community, request that the Community Youth Support Schemes, CYSS, throughout Australia, be restored.

We particularly ask that the Geelong and Corio CYSS Schemes be ongoing after the proposed closure date, 31st October, as they have contributed much to our community. CYSS has provided interests, support, opportunities for service, a voice in the community and job training for its thousands of participants over the past four years in Geelong. CYSS is an important part of our community and we as a community, support it especially in times of high youth unemployment that seriously affects our region.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Government reverse its decision to abolish the CYSS Projects and provide sufficient funds to enable the various CYSS Centres to continue their valuable work with the young unemployed in the future.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: CHARLES; CHILD; CUNNINGHAM; DUFFY; HOLDING; KENT; MILDREN; MILTON; THEOPHANOUS; WILLIS
PETITION.NAMEIDS: GF4; HF4; 0G4; 6G4; CH4; PH4; AI4; DI4; QJ4; ZJ4
PETITION.TITLE: Diabetics: Insulin
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned Citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That in view of the recent standardisation of insulin and insulin syringes, having the effect of increasing the costs of both items to the Diabetic in general, and as every insulin-dependent Diabetic must use the same, daily or twice daily according to medication.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that syringes be made available on the NHS and that insulin prescriptions revert to 10 bottles as previously supplied.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Charles,Mrs Child,Mr Cunningham,Mr Duffy,Mr Holding,Mr Kent,Mr Mildren,Mr Milton,Dr Theophanous and Mr Willis.

PETITION.TITLE: Health Care Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That many Australians will be financially disadvantaged by the health changes proposed by the Federal Government, especially the withdrawal of Commonwealth medical benefits for the uninsured, and the introduction of a means test for free public hospital care;
That the health insurance changes promote inequity, inefficiency and lack of universal coverage;
That the public hospital system and community health programmes will be financially disadvantaged by the abdication of Commonwealth responsibility and funding.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will take all steps necessary to reintroduce a system of health care based on ability to pay, and access to health care based on medical need.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Howe,Dr Jenkins,Mr Kerin and Mr Mountford.

PETITION.TITLE: Trans Australia Airlines
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
Many Australians depend almost exclusively upon Trans Australia Airlines for the provision of essential air services.
The Federal Liberal Party policy objective of selling Trans Australia Airlines within 4 years is contrary to the national interest.
Sale of Trans Australia Airlines would inevitably result in-
(i) the creation of a private monopoly of major airline services in Australia:
(ii) higher domestic air fares.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House will reject outright any proposal to sell Trans Australia Airlines.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beazley,Dr Everingham and Mr Mountford.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled.

The humble petition of the undersigned showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned that the Government is not fulfilling its responsibility in ensuring an adequate standard of living for all Australians, which is causing untold hardship on relief agencies' limited resources, and require the following steps to be taken as a matter of urgency:
1. That the Commonwealth Government raise the level of all pensions and benefits at least to the poverty line.
2. That the Commonwealth Government reconsider its recent decisions in relation to the health system and cuts to Commonwealth activity.
Your petitioners, therefore, humbly request that Parliament take immediate and positive action to avert further poverty and suffering in our community by implementation of the above measures.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Ewen Cameron,Mr Hawke and Dr Jenkins.

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled: This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

1. The proposal to introduce fees for higher and second degrees will mean that access to post-graduate and recurrent education will be limited to the rich; Australian research and ability to cope with technological change will suffer; this proposal must be seen as a step in the direction of the introduction of fees for all tertiary students.

2. The proposed introduction of a loans scheme for students will mean graduating with a heavy debt or being denied a tertiary education if loans are refused because a student is seen as a ''poor risk'' particularly affecting women and those doing non-vocational courses, only the rich will be able to get a tertiary education without course restrictions and the burden of indebtedness.

3. In regard to the proposal to restrict eligibility for TEAS and the foreshadowing of reviewing TEAS levels only in the light of the availability of loans, it should be noted that any further downgrading of TEAS, which is already inadequate, can only further limit access to education.

4. The proposed restriction of Adult Secondary Assistance to those needing qualifications for employment will severely restrict access to a full high school education and necessary bridging education to tertiary education for those who left school early.

5. The proposal not to fund 30 Colleges of Advanced Education if they are not rationalised is an attack on teacher education. This attack will create teacher shortages in the mid 1980s, restrict access to education now and endanger the future quality of teaching available to Australian children.
Your petitioners therefore pray:
(i) post-secondary tuition fees not be introduced for any courses or for any category of students;
(ii) that the TEAS scheme be extended so as to more fully meet the real financial needs of students.
(iii) that a comprehensive loans scheme not be introduced.
(iv) that there be no restriction of Adult Secondary Assistance.
(v) that the proposal not to fund 30 CAEs unless they are rationalized be rescinded.
And your petitioners as in duty bound shall ever humbly pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Bradfield and Mrs Child.

PETITION.TITLE: Moreton Island: Sand Mining
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Respresentatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That sandmining on Moreton Island poses a threat to the natural ecology and environment of the Island.

2. That Moreton Island is included on the Register of the Australian Heritage Commission, and the Federal Government is urged and indeed it must, under the Australian Heritage Commission Act, 1975 take into consideration the protection of the island.

3. That the Queensland Government has given approval to the sandmining of Moreton Island despite the advice of conservationists and despite the opposition of the majority of electors in the Moreton Region.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will request the Government to refuse export permits covering mineral sands mined on Moreton Island.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Cross and Mr Humphreys.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the basic rate of pensions and rent allowance is not sufficient to meet present day needs.
In light of the 20 per cent increase in M.Ps. salaries pensioners are being unfairly treated.
Therefore, your petitioners urge that:
1. Basic rate of pension be increased to 30 per cent of the average weekly earnings.
2. Rent allowance be increased from present $5.00 weekly to $20.00 weekly.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Hawke and Mr Tambling.

PETITION.TITLE: South-west Tasmania: Wilderness Area
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned showeth:

That your petitioners are gravely concerned at proposed future hydro electric developments in South West Tasmania. This area is on the Register of the National Estate and therefore is of national concern.

We call on the Federal Government not to allocate funds or allow funds to be raised for development of roads or dams in the South West but rather to provide such funds as would enable the preservation of this area.
It is a national issue and therefore Tasmanians should not be made to bear any financial burden resultant from its preservation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Queensland Conservatorium of Music
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable The Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia, respectfully showeth that:
The merging of the Queensland Conservatorium of Music with any other Institution would result in the abolition of the Conservatorium in its present form.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that:
The Government takes all possible steps to preserve the identity of the Queensland Conservatorium of Music at it is presently constituted.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Institute of Early Childhood Development
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Federal Government should reconsider the proposal to merge the Institute of Early Childhood Development with another tertiary Institution.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Institute of Early Childhod Development be allowed to continue operating as an independent and autonomous institution providing specialised skills and unique training applicable to the development of children aged 0-6 years.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Toxic Shock Syndrome
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled:

The humble petition of the undersigned showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned by the threats to women's health and lives posed by Toxic Shock Syndrome, and urge the following steps to be taken as a matter of urgency:

(1) Tampons, sanitary napkins, vaginal deodorants and similar sanitary products to be re-classified under Therapeutic Agents not under Cosmetics as at present, in order to bring them under the scrutiny of the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee. We believe manufacture must be under the strictest hygienic conditions.

(2) After re-classification, we urge an immediate government-funded inquiry into all aspects of manufacture and content of these products. This must lead to: (i) contents of product and instructions for correct usage to be shown on the packaging; (ii) removal of synthetic fibres, chemicals or ingredients that are potentially or actually harmful to users.

(3) Allocation of extra funding for ongoing research by the National Health and Medical Research Council into these products, results of this research to be made public to ensure all health workers and potential users are fully informed. This campaign of public education would necessitate multilingual distribution of the information where appropriate.
Your petitioners, therefore, humbly request that Parliament take immediate and positive action to avert possible threats posed to women's health by implementation of the above measures.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. The government proposes to impose a Sales tax of 17 1/2 per cent on manufactured pet foods which were previously exempt.
2. That this new tax will impose an unreasonable burden on pet owners, many of whom are pensioners and citizens in receipt of a small income.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will withdraw or repeal its Sales Tax Legislation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will every pray

PETITION.TITLE: Eagle Farm Airport
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That noise levels created by aircraft using Eagle Farm Airport already constitute an annoyance and inconvenience to those residents living near the airport and along its flight paths.
That relaxation of the Eagle Farm Airport curfew to allow any aircraft including TAA's Airbus to fly into and out of Eagle Farm Airport between 11 p.m. and 6 a.m. would-
(a) Substantially increase the inconvenience and annoyance caused by aircraft noise because the operation of aircraft at this time would seriously disturb people's sleep;

(b) Contradict and negate a commendable undertaking made by the Commonwealth Minister for Transport, the Hon. Ralph Hunt, in reply to a question on notice in the Parliament, that the curfew will remain on the runways at the existing site at Eagle Farm Airport.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government will not approve the application of TAA-or any other airline-to relax or withdraw the curfew at Eagle Farm Airport.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Privacy and Personal Information
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that: Paragraphs 107 and 108 of the Privacy and Personal Information discussion paper number 14, brought down by the Law Reform Commission in June 1980, undermines the family unit and the authority of parents, which is the Christian basis of our society, by proposing that between 12 and 16 years, a child should be entitled to object to disclosure of information to a parent.
It is your petitioners sincere belief that:

(a) An adolescent between the ages of 12 and 16 is not at a mature enough stage of life to decide whether or not the disclosure of information to a parent will be in the best interests of the adolescent.
(b) As a record keeper has no responsibility for the child, and as his moral standards may be different to those of a parent, he should not be permitted to come between child and parent.

(c) A parent has a unique position which may enable him-her to perceive a situation that the record keeper does not. The parent must therefore be aware of the problem if remedial action is to be taken, and has the right to guide the child in the direction he-she feels fit.
Your petitioners therefore pray:
That the Members of the House of Representatives will reject the recommendation of the Law Reform Commission and find some other means to protect children from the excessive abuse of some parents.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

The humble petition of the undersigned showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned that the Government is increasing interest rates on home mortgage loans without due concern for its impact on the general community and ask that the Government reconsider its attitude to low and middle income earners.

Your petitioners, therefore, humbly request that Parliament take immediate and positive action to avert any further effects of increases in interest rates on home mortgage loans which cause financial, social and psychological pressures on families.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Service Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the Ex-Servicemens' & Womens' Pension Association is a body formed for the express purpose of obtaining a Service Pension for all Ex-Service Personnel at sixty years of age for men and fifty-five years of age for women regardless of where they served during the 1939-45 war.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled should give urgent consideration to a favourable decision to the granting of the Service Pension to all Ex-Service Personnel who served their country in time of need and who did not serve overseas through no fault of their own. The Service Pension is presently only granted to Returned Ex-Service Personnel.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. Because of an anomaly in tax rates a single income family pays nearly $10 a week more tax than a dual income family earning the same total amount.
2. Family allowances established in 1976 have not been increased since then, yet over the same period living costs have increased by nearly 60 per cent.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that:
The Parliament should act-
1. To restore the lost value of family allowances and to index them for future price rises.
2. To increase the spouse rebate from $830 to $1,342 per year.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medibank
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled: The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully requests that the Federal Government ensures that:
a. It honours its 1975 election promise to maintain Medibank-a free, universal health insurance scheme, and institute methods of improving hospital and health services for the Australian people.
b. The Community Health Program remains a Federal Government responsibility, with increased funding and expansion of services.
c. It abandons means-testing and the re-introduction of charges at public hospitals which will severely disadvantage low and middle income groups.
d. Every effort be made by the Federal Government to meet the health care needs and demands of the Australian community.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled will give earnest consideration to this most vital matter.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Commonwealth Experimental Building Station
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The Humble Petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

1. That the decision of the Federal Government to dispose of the Commonwealth Experimental Building Station to private enterprise could lead to a conflict of interest and will not be conducive to providing impartial information on safe, effective and efficient building practice.

2. That the costs to the industry and to the community may include-the acceptance of reduced or static building standards; reduced materials quality, equipment efficiency, building longevity and finally may result in loss of life.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will request the Government to restore its funding to the Commonwealth Experimental Building Station in recognition of the fact that it has contributed greatly to the effective and safe conduct of the building industry.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Budget imposition of 2 1/2 per cent additional Sales Tax to both existing sales tax items and to previously exempt goods
(a) will add to the regressivity of the tax structure by imposing a similar burden on all sections of the community-regardless of the capacity to pay tax;
(b) will be highly inflationary and a disincentive to economic performance in key sectors of manufacturing industry, e.g. car manufacturing, textile and footwear industries;
(c) is yet another breach of Government promise, given the Treasurer's undertaking in the Parliament on March 12th of this year, that there would be no increase in indirect taxes.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House will request the Government to repeal the Budget Amendments to Sales Tax Legislation which increases existing sales tax items from 19th August and to withdraw its Sales Tax Amendment Bills which add Sales Tax to presently exempt goods as from 1 January 1982.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

(1) That a single pensioner earning $20 per week will have an actual income per annum of $4,505 i.e., $310 over the tax-free threshold rendering the pensioner liable to pay $97.60 tax in the 1981-82 financial year
(2) That the limit of allowable income of $20 per week for a single pensioner ($34.50 for a married couple) has not been raised since 1967

(3) That under the present system elderly people who have paid taxes all their working lives are twice penalised after retirement as superannuation or other income may lift their allowable earnings over the tax-free threshold, as well as exclude them from pension-related fringe benefits.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray-
That the Government will increase the lower end of the income test scale in order that pensioners with little savings will not be penalised by small fluctuations in their income.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Eagle Farm Airport
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:

(a) That residents of densely populated suburbs in the vicinity of the airport and residents of other suburbs in the flight path of international and domestic jets are experiencing an unreasonable degree of aircraft noise.
(b) Further, that these same residents will be subjected to prolonged bouts of such aircraft noise if a decision is taken to extend the curfew at both the domestic and international airports.
(c) That this decision has been foreshadowed on two occasions as follows:

(i) In submissions to the public hearing held by the Public Works Committee of this Parliament in regard to stage one-Redevelopment of Brisbane's International Airport: these submissions proposed an extension of the existing curfew when the new runway is completed (approximately 1986). This proposal received the full support of the Queensland Government.
(ii) TAA's request for an extended curfew to coincide with the introduction of the Airbus.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will refuse to extend the existing curfew and will reconsider its siting plans for the proposed new runway so as to minimise noise pollution over high density suburbs.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Labelling of Cosmetics
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That continued use of animal ingredients in cosmetic products, and the inhumane use of animals in scientific research for cosmetic products is abhorrent and barbaric.

That the Industries Assistance Commission, because of the Commission's terms of reference, seems unable to impose any regulation or recommend any regulation which might restrict the activities of Cosmetic Companies which produce cosmetics in which animal ingredients have been used, or for which animals were subjected to research.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will:
Legislate to require comprehensive labelling of perfumes, cosmetics and toilet preparations to indicate:
(1) whether a product contains any animal derivative. If so, the ingredient and source should be indicated.
(2) whether the research and development of that product or any of its ingredients involved experimentation on animals.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Unemployment Benefit
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia, in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully calls for:
The immediate and unconditional withdrawal of any proposals to deny unemployment benefits to unemployed people under 18 years old.
That the level of benefits for all unemployed people, and including people receiving sickness benefits and pensions, be raised to at least 120 per cent of the poverty line.

That future employment policies be devoted to job creation and the restoration of full employment rather than the evasion of this responsibility by hiding the unemployed in short term training and education schemes.
Public acknowledgement of the fact that unemployment is the result of insufficient jobs and not the fault of any minority group, the education system or the unemployed themselves.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

We, the people who have signed this petition, ask all parties, Labor, Liberal, Democrats and others, to stop the latest increase in taxes and the forever increases in taxes which hit all people of the country of Australia in all goods and consumer goods and we call for a referendum on taxes and interest rates.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker, Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

(1) The financial situation of students enrolled at Australian post-secondary institutions is already extremely difficult (as indicated in the Commonwealth Department of Education 1979 survey of student incomes and expenditures) and any substantial increase in the financial commitments of students would gravely worsen their difficulties.

(2) The imposition of post-secondary tuition fees of comparable levels to those imposed prior to 1974 would force many currently enrolled students to discontinue their studies and deter many persons willing and able at present to undertake post-secondary study from doing so.

(3) Those students and potential students from social groups currently under-represented and disadvantaged in the post-secondary education system would be most severely affected by the reintroduction of post-secondary education.
Your petitioners therefore pray that:
(1) Post-secondary tuition fees not be reintroduced for any category of students.
(2) The visa charges upon private overseas students be removed immediately.
(3) That the Minister for Education immediately clarify the Governments attitude to the reintroduction of post-secondary tuition fees.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the allowable amount of income to be earned by people receiving social security benefits has not been adjusted since 1972 and in the case of unemployed not since 1969.
That the $20 allowable for beneficiaries in 1972 was at a time when the benefit was $18.25 per week.
That if the same principle applied and if the amount earned had been indexed the amount now allowable would exceed $63.20 per week.
That Family Allowances have never been indexed.
That heartless, insensitive, frugal and anomalous social security benefits, allowances and rules are causing severe financial distress to many citizens and causing the breakup of families.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Government will bring all allowances and benefits up to levels which would make them equivalent in real monetary terms to the time when they were set.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth.
That the burden of interest payments on housing loans is now at such record levels that most citizens paying off their homes are becoming severely financially distressed.
That the burden of additional expense together with increases in health insurance and hospital charges is putting increasing stress on family relationships.
That the policies of favouring overseas private investors to buy up our resources are causing inflationary pressures, declining public services and ever higher interest rates.
That we support all efforts to give relief to people making house repayments, particularly in the first five years of purchase, but also when expenses are higher after the first years of marriage.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Government will give interest rate relief by way of tax concessions of a subsidy on mortgage repayments
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Human Rights in Chile
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That many people have left Chile because of political, religious and economic persecution, and that these people would face imprisonment, and political and economic harassment if forced to return.
That statements by Amnesty International and the London-based Chilean Committee for Human Rights reveal there has been no abatement of political, religious and economic persecution in Chile.

That Australia, as a signatory to the 1951 United Nations' Convention and the 1967 United Nations' Protocol on refugees, adopt and endorse the principles for refugee status espoused by the legal adviser to the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, Dr Guy Goodwin-Gill.

That many Chileans presently in Australia, including two refugee status applicants, Fernando Del Carmen Cerda Labarca and Pedro Jose Belmar Aquilera, clearly fall within the parameters of Dr Goodwin-Gill's definition.
We urge the government to grant refugee status to these two refugees.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medibank
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That many Australians will be financially disadvantaged by the health changes proposed by the Federal Government, especially the withdrawal of Commonwealth medical benefits for the uninsured, and the introduction of a means test for free public hospital care;
That the health insurance changes promote inequity, inefficiency and lack of universal coverage;
That the public hospital system and community health programmes will be financially disadvantaged by the abdication of Commonwealth responsibility and funding.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will take all steps necessary to reintroduce Medibank.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding of Women's Centres
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of New South Wales, Australia respectfully showeth:
That many thousands of women and children in the Australian community who use the services of Women's Refuges, Rape Crisis Centre and Women's Health Centres:

1. Express their concern at the decision of the Federal Government to pass to the States, the responsibility of funding those essential services because of the poor record already demonstrated by some States;
2. Call on the Federal Government to reverse that decision;
3. Request that the Government ensure that there is one department which will administer all funds for the above under the heading of Women's Services;
4. Propose that future funding should be on a guaranteed triennial basis which must take into account inflation and indexation rises;

5. Request definite government policy commitment to a substantial injection of funds to consolidate existing services and develop new ones. That such funds be distributed in such a way as to insure equitable national distribution of these resources.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Excise on Beer
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

1. The club industry in Australia is long-established and a valuable part of the community of this nation, providing places where the people may partake of the three basic needs of life: a place to eat, a place to drink, a place to sleep.
2. The club industry is accepted throughout the nation as occupying an important place in the social and economic activities of Australia.
3. The club industry is entirely within the private sector and makes a contribution to the government in taxes of various kinds.
4. The club industry has a need to sustain an appropriate level of turnover and growth, to make profit, and to sustain and improve the level of employment.
5. The club industry of Australia is gravely concerned at published reports that the Government intends to increase excise charges on beer in the forthcoming Budget.
6. Sales of beer constitute the major source of income of most of the industry.
7. The very steep rises in beer excise in 1975 and 1978 severely retarded the growth of the Australian club industry.

8. Any further increases in excise on beer in the 1981 Budget would further retard the industry at a time when growth is essential to maintaining economic viability and the ability to serve the constantly growing needs of the community.
9. Such is its significance as a community requirement, beer occupies a place on the Consumer Price Index, and any alteration to its cost to the community would have an inflationary effect.
10. Any increase in excise would result in and force the club industry to pass on such increases to the consumer by way of higher prices for beer.

11. Higher excise would be only the starting point for an upward spiral in beer prices because of the presence of other factors, such as State Licence Fee taxes, which are directly linked to excise rates.
12. The club industry of Australia already is gravely handicapped by heavy excise and other tax imposts, its growth is at a standstill; and, inevitably must decline if beer excise is increased.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that Honourable Members of the House of Representatives:
1. Recognise the importance and place of the Australian club industry in the social and economic life of the nation.

2. Accept that the viability of the club industry is essential to the maintenance of employment opportunities and stability of the industry is essential to enable it to continue to provide for the club needs of the nation in this period of growing population and increasing tourism.
And further, that Honourable Members of the House of Representatives resist and reject any move to increase excise on beer.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Rights of Disabled
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

1. The failure of the Federal Government to seek information from the census re disabled people-i.e. partial or total disability-to enable for adequate planning of, and for, types of services needed by disabled people to be undertaken.

2. The failure of the Federal Government to lead the way in employment of disabled people by employing a greater number of such people within the Commonwealth Public Service-note the small number currently employed within the Service.

3. The wastage of the Federal Government funds perpetuating large, bureaucratic institutions and organisations where there are often few disabled people on their boards and little emphasis is placed on consumer participation in decision making.
4. The failure of the Federal Government to encourage independence of disabled people, or to develop ''normalised'' support systems-attendant care.
5. The failure of the Federal Government to provide ''non-institutionalised'' specialised accommodation for those people who would not be able to benefit from, or cope with attendant care.
6. Failure by the Federal Government to alter, or create a ''disability'' allowance means test free for all disabled people-this would assist with necessary equipment and mobility costs.
7. Failure to provide a national compensation scheme thus saving time and enabling people to be automatically covered in the event of a disability.
8. Failure by the Federal Government to abolish tariffs on all equipment available to the disabled-e.g. Optacon.
9. Mismanagement of Federal IYDP Funds-e.g. non-receipt by some States of funds through unresolved negotiations.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that immediate action be taken to remedy the above stated and that the Federal Government recognise that disabled people are citizens who should have equal rights.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

The Federal Government should provide sufficient funds for State Education Systems that will ensure the maintenance of the current high quality of education and the continuance of educational services to all children in a happy and stress free environment.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Dystrophic Epidermolysis Bullosa Research Association
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

The petition of the Dystrophic Epidermolysis Bullosa Research Association of Australia (DEBRA A) and their supporters respectfully shows that funds for medical research into Epidermolysis Bullosa are no longer being made available from the Federal Government to the medical research team at the University of New South Wales, enabling them to continue medical research into Epidermolysis Bullosa.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that these signatures contained on these forms will serve to make it known that we expect these funds to be forthcoming in the very near future.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable The Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned members of Parents and Citizens Associations respectfully showeth:

That retention of the Schools Commission and the Curriculum Development Centre in their present forms is essential for the balanced and progressive allocation of educational resources and facilities in the Australian community:

That serious concern has been generated by the decision within the School Commission guidelines, to cut funds to the general recurrent and capital programs by reallocation to transition, the decision not to implement the school improvement program; and the divisiveness created between government and non-government schools due to increases of $43.25 million to non-government schools while government schools funds have not increased.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:

That the Government will reverse these decisions-will retain the Schools Commission and Curriculum Development Centre in their original forms; retain the Schools Commission proposals including recurrent and capital funding proposals; basket of services and the schools improvement program.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hurford Mr C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-

(1) notes with regret the failure of the Government to honour its undertaking to the Presiding Officers of this Parliament to consult fully with them before setting the 1981-82 appropriations for the running of this Parliament;

(2) resolves that in appropriation procedures for 1982-83 the funds for Parliament should be contained in a separate Appropriation Bill and notes the support for this procedure contained in the recommendations of the Senate Select Committee on the Parliament's Appropriations and Staffing and at the meeting of Estimates Committee A of this House held on 8 September 1981;
(3) registers its grave disquiet at many of the proposed cuts in real terms in the budget for the Parliament; and

(4) condemns the Government for its decision to deprive Government backbenchers and all Opposition Members of the resources to properly conduct their duties as parliamentarians by cutting the overall appropriation to the Parliamentary Library in real terms by more than 22 per cent and by its specific cuts of 46 per cent, 43 per cent and 63 per cent, respectively, to the individual items for books, photocopying, stationery and microfilming services covered by the Library's appropriation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-
(1) deplores the funding of political parties for the purposes of elections, because it reduces the funds available for housing, health, education, handicapped and early childhood programs;
(2) endorses as a prerequisite the holding of referenda to allow the expression of public opinion on the funding of political parties for elections;
(3) recommends that the Commonwealth Grants Commission Act be amended to take into account election funding when examining relativities between the States for revenue sharing; and

(4) proposes that the Federal Government investigate the possibility of immediately reducing general revenue grants to States which adopt election funding by amounts equal to that amount spent by State governments for funding political parties.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Klugman Dr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give noice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That time be set aside after the New South Wales elections so as to enable members to debate intelligently and on a non-party basis the question of defamation of dead persons.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris Mr P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House condemns the Government's action in squandering taxpayers' funds on its $40m VIP aircraft program and overseas safaris by the Prime Minister while denying adequate funds for housing to the States of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Goodluck Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-
(1) is of the opinion that the Government should continue to allow age pensioners to maintain reasonable non-interest bearing accounts; and
(2) considers that the means test for basic pensions and the pharmaceutical health benefits card should be liberalised.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Deputy Prime Minister. Is it a fact that the Budget strategy hinges very much on a continuing huge capital inflow this year exceeding that of last year? Is it a fact that that huge capital inflow is necessary to cover forecast larger deficits in the balance of trade and current account which go well beyond equipment inflows associated with resource development? Is it also a fact that a sudden large contraction of that capital inflow will generate serious balance of payments problems with domestic consequences that cannot be resolved by simple domestic expansion because of the worsening balance of trade deficit and the aggravation that expansion would have on that? Does the Deputy Prime Minister therefore realise that his statements yesterday and this morning signal the very real possibility of this development? Was he warning that the Government is now preparing to jettison the strategy laid down in the Budget after only one month? What alternative means of economic management does the Government have in mind especially to avoid further deterioration of the balance of trade and on current account and at the same time avert a severe domestic contraction? If he is not prepared to discuss these matters why did he make a statement last night and this morning with such serious implications for domestic economic management?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: DEPUTY PRIME MINISTER; TRADE AND RESOURCES

TALK.START.PARA: —I think all Australians will be very pleased that the Government has had the strategy it has had to encourage investment in resource developments in this country. As a result of the confidence that people have, we have a very large amount of private capital inflow for these developments. At the same time it is helping to maintain a strong balance of payments situation. It is very fortunate that the Government has had this strategy by which we can maintain high economic activity and the well-being of Australians and improve employment opportunities. Last night I addressed an audience in Melbourne where I presented the export awards. That was the last occasion that these awards will be presented as the Export Now campaign is concluding. I was emphasising the point that during the Export Now campaign we endeavoured to make Australians more aware of the need for and the importance of exports. It is only by maintaining a healthy level of exports that this country can continue to progress.

ANSWER.PARA: However, the figures for the last year show that we cannot be complacent. Imports have risen significantly while our exports have risen only marginally. Although the campaign is concluding it is vital that every effort be made by Australians to continue improving our export performance, particularly in the manufacturing area where there has been a very substantial improvement as a result of the Government's program. I hope that all Australians will not idly stand by and imagine that exports just happen; there needs to be encouragement and recognition. I am proud of what the Government has achieved.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Treasurer: Has the Federal Government power to control interest rates charged by building societies to home owners?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to that question is no. The Federal Government, through the Reserve Bank of Australia, has power-if it seeks to use it-to control interest rates charged by trading and savings banks in Australia. The question of whether government should seek by fiat to control interest rates is, of course, a different issue. The power to control building society interest rates in Australia rests with State governments. This, therefore, invites some comparison of the rhetoric and performance of State governments-not the least, of course, the New South Wales Government-on the issue of interest rates.

ANSWER.PARA: Over the past couple of months I do not think anyone has seen a greater level of political grandstanding than the performance of the New South Wales Premier on the subject of interest rates. He has repeatedly said that his Government is leading the fight against higher interest rates in Australia. Yet every single move by the Federal Government to take pressure off interest rates in Australia has been condemned by Mr Wran. He condemned the borrowing restrictions imposed at the last Loan Council meeting; he condemned the reduction in the Budget deficit. Yet, when it suits his own political convenience, he justifies an increase in building society interest rates in New South Wales by the very same argument that the Federal Government has quite properly used to justify allowing bank interest rates to rise. The argument simply is that if one holds down interest rates in certain areas too far and too long, available funds for housing will dry up completely.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs had discussions with the Queensland Welfare Minister, Mr Terry White, concerning the fate of the Community Youth Support Scheme in Queensland? Have these talks canvassed the possibility of the Commonwealth Government matching a Queensland Government commitment of $200,000 to go towards the maintenance of Queensland CYSS centres plus contributions from local authorities and community organisations? Did the Minister remark during these talks that the Commonwealth Government may have overreacted with its blanket abolition of CYSS because of poor response in some States? Has the possibility of providing $200,000 both from State and Commonwealth revenues been floated with the local authorities in Rockhampton, Ipswich and Redcliffe? What was the response? Is it a fact that a scheme funded under such an arrangement would be sufficient to sustain only 11 of the 35 current CYSS centres operating in Queensland? Finally, what has fate in store for CYSS centres in other States?

—It is true that I have had some discussion with the Queensland Minister and it is true that that discussion touched upon the subject of the Community Youth Support Scheme. I might say that, since Budget day, I have had a large number of discussions with a wide ranging number of people about this subject. The Queensland Minister has made a proposal. That proposal, for all I know, may be pursued at the appropriate place, which is the labour Ministers conference in Darwin later this week and with respect to that proposal, as with respect to other proposals, the Government of course is quite happy to listen to what people have to say and to suggest. The only problem is that some people seem to think that, simply because a suggestion is made and an undertaking is given to consider it, the suggestion has been accepted. The Government's position with respect to this matter has been made plain. The situation is that the Budget decision, being a Budget decision, will not be changed. The Government has also made it very plain that it has embarked upon a course which is presently continuing, namely, a course of explaining to CYSS project officers and participants the skills, training and work experience programs that the Government has. Young unemployed people have been encouraged to take part in those programs. We have also made it plain that if, as a result of our investigations, it appears there are some young unemployed people who are not able to be catered for by those programs, the Government, of course, consistent with the care and concern that it has shown over the years for young unemployed people, will look at what measures, if any, have to be put in place to cover those young people not covered by the programs we have.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: INDUSTRIAL DISPUTE AT VICKERS COCKATOO DOCKYARD

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Is the Minister aware of the situation at Vickers Cockatoo Dockyard where there is not only a strike over shorter hours but also about 700 of the company's employees cannot get to work on the island because of a ban by the Firemen and Deckhands Union of New South Wales which has led to the withdrawal of ferry services? Can the Government and in particular can you, Mr Minister, do something about helping these 700 employees to get to work?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Viner The Hon R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the situation at Vickers Cockatoo Dockyard, and it is a deplorable one as the facts outlined by the honourable member clearly indicate. Last night my colleagues, the Minister for Defence and the Minister for Administrative Services, and I met with the management of the dockyard. We were told of the deplorable situation facing that company and its employees. The House will be aware that on Cockatoo Island there are substantial Commonwealth assets and that at that place work on substantial defence contracts is carried out, notably at the moment the building of a fleet underway replenishment ship and the refitting of submarines. The House will be conscious of the vital national interest which the Commonwealth has in the future of the company and the works being carried out there.

ANSWER.PARA: I think the House would also want to know of the concern of the Commonwealth that 700 employees who want to work are being prevented from getting to their place of employment by deliberate industrial action by the Firemen and Deckhands Union which has placed a ban on the ferries which ferry the men to work. We are simply not prepared to stand by and see that situation continue. The Government has considered the matter and, as a result, I was able to notify the company this morning that we are prepared to make available naval vessels to ferry those people to their employment. The planning has already been put in train by my colleague the Minister for Defence. So, within the next couple of days, the necessary arrangements will have been made to enable those 700 people to get to work.

I should add that work at Cockatoo Dockyard is carried out not only for the Commonwealth but also for the New South Wales Government. Power station equipment is repaired and maintained by Vickers for the New South Wales Government. Yet not one jot of help has been offered by the New South Wales Government to this company or to the 700 employees who have been left stranded by the industrial action that has taken place. So this Government is prepared to act firmly, resolutely and quickly when obviously the New South Wales Government is not so prepared.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Is it a fact that Australia's sales to South Africa increased from $67m in 1978-79 to $132m in 1980-81? Have imports from South Africa increased from $37m in 1975-76 to $110m in 1980-81? What is the Government's attitude to this increase in trade with South Africa, particularly in the light of the call today by the United Nations General Assembly to break links with South Africa?

—For a long while the Government has not actively encouraged trade with South Africa but it has not sought to prevent trade with South Africa by any positive means. I think it is worth noting also that trade figures of many countries within Africa and South Africa are also of some significance, perhaps of much more significance to their economies than would be those trade figures with us. I think it ought to be understood, because of the racial policies of South Africa, that the international community has taken certain decisions. This country has applied assiduously and conscientiously certain decisions made within the Commonwealth in relation to sport and it will continue to do so. But there would be no point in Australia adopting an attitude in relation to trade, as a one-off example, even if it were an appropriate mechanism to use. It would have to be something taken as a result of international action, not just action by a country such as Australia. I hope that the honourable gentleman is not suggesting that Australia, of all nations in the world, should conduct trade embargoes against South Africa.

—Is the Minister for Industrial Relations aware of recent reports which suggest delay by the Government in taking action against the Builders Labourers Federation? What progress has been made in preparation of the case for deregistration?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Viner The Hon R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen reports of the kind referred to by the honourable gentleman. Last week, on 8 September, in Estimates Committee E some questions were asked of me on this subject. Because of these developments, since last week I have examined the file from its inception. Therefore I think it is appropriate that I place some facts on the record so as to show the circumstances surrounding preparation of the case and the state of unpreparedness when I assumed responsibility for the portfolio. The Government made its decision to take action to deregister the BLF on 17 February. No prior consultation was taken by the then Minister with employer organisations. The first meeting with employers was held on 24 February and another was held on 4 March. At the time an oral opinion had been obtained from counsel at the Melbourne Bar. His later written opinion, dated 9 February, put the possible time scale for completion of the case between April and 'well into 1981'.

ANSWER.PARA: Officers from the Attorney-General's Department were seconded on 20 February to work with officers from my Department on the preparation of the case. On 8 April advice from my Department to the then Minister was given which showed that at that time there were no statements from private employers in a state to permit drafts of affidavits. The only statements then provided were from New South Wales. My predecessor resigned on 15 April and I was sworn in next day. On 16 April the Attorney-General obtained written advice from a senior officer of his Department seconded to my Department to work on the case. That advice was passed on to me. The advice to the Attorney-General-I will quote from that advice-was as follows:
Progress in the preparation of the case has been very slow . . .
With the exception of one witness's statement taken in Canberra on 2 April 1981, statements from private industry sources have only started coming in since last Friday, 10 April 1981.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Speaker. The Minister is quoting from a document. Is he prepared to lay that document on the table of the House?
—Is the Minister reading from a document?
—Yes; I am quite prepared to table the document, Mr Speaker. If the Opposition is prepared to grant me leave to have the statement incorporated in Hansard, I will have it incorporated.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
AUSTRALIA
ATTORNEY-GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT
Subject:
BUILDER'S LABOURERS' FEDERATION-PROPOSED DE-REGISTRATION PROCEEDINGS
Attorney-General
1. The purpose of this minute is to report on the progress of the preparation for the abovementioned proceedings.

2. Attorney-General's officers were seconded on 20 February 1981 to work on this matter; the relevant Cabinet decision to commence proceedings to de-register the BLF having been made on 17 February 1981.

3. Progress in the preparation of the case has been very slow. The principal reason for this has been the delay in support from the private building industry. You will recall that the industry sought and obtained certain assurances from the Government to protect companies from loss due to industrial action after de-registration.
4. With the exception of one witness's statement taken in Canberra on 2 April 1981, statements from private industry sources have only started coming in since last Friday, 10 April 1981.

5. As of today, 26 statements have been received. Of the 26, 17 are from private industry sources and the balance are statements from officers of the Department of Housing and Construction. The 26 statements consist of 4 from the ACT, one from Queensland, 10 from Victoria and 11 from South Australia.
6. The most co-operative company to date has been Costains. Lengthy statements are currently being taken from Costains employees in Victoria.
7. Notwithstanding the fact that there is now a flow of statements coming in, I anticipate that we are still some time away from instituting proceedings. There are several reasons for this, namely:

(a) The events the subject of the statements are more complex than I originally anticipated. The main area of relevant BLF conduct is the imposition of bans in support of industrial claims. In the case of Costains, at one site on one day, the BLF imposed 20 black bans on various areas of work. It will be appreciated that preparation of statements of this kind is a lengthy process because one statement might relate to as many as 50 incidents of relevant BLF conduct.

(b) The process of settling the statements is being affected by the fact that the various State Master Builders Associations are insisting that all statements be pro- cessed through the Association. This creates delay and also it means that witnesses cannot be directly contacted except through the relevant trade association. I have asked the Department of Industrial Relations to seek agreement from the Master Builders' Association that at least in the settling stages of affidavits we be permitted to deal with witnesses direct and that the Master Builders Associations be given copies of the final affidavits before they are sworn.
(c) I expect that the document instituting proceedings will be supported by 80-120 affidavits. It will take a considerable amount of time for the lawyers to process and proof these affidavits.
8. I consider that these proceedings are unlikely to be instituted before the end of May 1981. We may be able to institute earlier if the MBA red tape can be avoided.

9. A very important step prior to the institution of proceedings will be to obtain Counsel's considered opinion on whether the evidence available gives the Minister reasonable prospects of success. We must face the possibility that Counsel may advise that there is insufficient evidence to support these proceedings. However, I must say that the statements received to date are starting to give a picture of very disruptive and costly action by the BLF in support of claims, particularly by means of black bans.

10. Once the proceedings have been instituted, I expect there will be a delay of some 4 to 6 weeks before the date of trial. The Court will give the BLF a reasonable amount of time to prepare its defence. I anticipate that the trial would last of the order of 40 hearing days. In these circumstances, allowing for a period of time for the Court to consider and make its decision, I think it is unlikely that the BLF would be de-registered before November 1981.
SENIOR ASSISTANT CROWN SOLICITOR
16 April 1981

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall also quote certain parts of the document. As I was saying before, the document states:

ANSWER.PARA: With the exception of one witness's statement taken in Canberra on 2 April 1981, statements from private industry sources have only started coming in since last Friday, 10 April 1981.

The statement indicates that 17 statements from private industry sources had been received by 16 April. I think, Mr Speaker, that the House will be conscious of the justification for my statement to the Estimates Committee, recorded at page 45 of the Hansard transcript, that:
. . . it was utterly impossible to lodge the application in April when I took over the portfolio because the case had not been prepared to that point to allow that to be done.

In contrast to the position as I found it on 16 April, over 250 interviews have now been conducted, 150 statements have been obtained and the particulars of industrial incidents forming the statement of claim which is now ready to be lodged number in excess of 450 cases. The advice to the Attorney-General stated also at that time, 16 April, that it was unlikely that proceedings could be instituted before the end of May 1981. It stated further that it was unlikely that the BLF would be deregistered before November 1981.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Speaker. We are dealing with questions without notice. This is a complete abuse of Question Time. It is not as though a vast amount of business is before the House. If the Minister has a statement to make he should make it at a time when it can be debated.

—Order! I point out to the honourable member for Swan that there is no substance to his point of order. No time limit is placed on a Minister in answering a question as long as his comments are relevant to the question. Certainly, the Minister's comments are relevant to the question. However, it has been my practice when answers have become elongated, as is the case now, to ask a Minister to draw his answer to a conclusion. I now do that.
—Mr Speaker, it is appropriate to raise the matter in the House because it has been raised in the hearings of a Committee of the House. I think it is quite clear--
—I ask the Minister not to make a point about the point of order and, in proceeding with his answer, to draw his answer to a conclusion.

—Mr Speaker, I do so because I have now put on the record of the House the facts of the matter. As I have said, they are the result of an examination I have undertaken of the files on the matter since its inception.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Prime Minister aware that the United States Administration has assured the South African Government of its support in return for the South African Government agreeing to resupply the UNITA guerrillas currently attempting to overthrow the Government of Angola? Specifically, I ask the Prime Minister whether he is aware that earlier this year the United States Secretary of State approved an American foreign policy document which contained the following passage:

QUESTION.PARA: African leaders would have no basis for resisting the Namibia/Angola linkage once they are made to realise that they can only get a Namibia settlement through us . . .

that is, the United States. Was that policy statement of the United States made without consultation with other members of the Western contact group on Namibia? Given Australia's support for Namibia's independence, what is our attitude towards that United States policy? Further, do we still adhere to our commitment of 300 Australian troops to an eventual United Nations peacekeeping force in Namibia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Government has not re-examined in recent times the commitment to the peacekeeping force in Namibia. But there is no reason to assume that that commitment would not stand if those troops were still welcome to both the parties concerned. That, obviously, is a prerequisite of the components of a peacekeeping force. I know that there has been some discussion and talk about linkage of Cubans in Angola. I hope the honourable gentleman would object to Cubans just as much as he would object to other people being in Angola.
