I know that there has been some suggestion of linking that problem to the question of progress in relation to Namibia. But the information available to me leads me to believe that the contact group would not see it as being a practical step to achieve any kind of linkage. I do not think that is real life; I doubt whether the other members of the contact group see that as being real life. I doubt very much whether the United States is pursuing it with any great vigour. It is a question that was raised some time ago, as I understand it, in the exploration and development of the policy under this administration.

ANSWER.PARA: It ought to be stated, I think, that Australia's policy in relation to Namibia has been a consistent one over a long time. We believe there ought to be independence under the appropriate United Nations resolutions. If anything can be done in a diplomatic way or through the United Nations to support the appropriate United Nations resolutions which are supported by the contact group, which includes not only the United States but also Canada, Britain, France and West Germany, which have in a sense the responsibility for applying the decisions of the United Nations, I do not see any real difference between the view taken by Australia and that taken by those other major countries which have that responsibility. Quite obviously, when the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting takes place in two or three weeks time, heads of government will be interested not only in the progress of whatever has happened in the special session of the United Nations but also in whatever reports the two members of the contact group which will be present, Britain and Canada, can give. Whatever reactions the heads of government, as a whole, might want to make no doubt will be significantly influenced by those reports, by what occurs and by whether there is evidence of progress in achieving independence in Namibia, which is something that many countries, including the contact group, take very seriously. They believe too long a time has passed without progress being made.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister for Trade and Resources been drawn to a reported claim that the uranium industry is 'lurching towards collapse' and 'is a poor investment of taxpayers' dollars' and that 'the dazzling dreams of a uranium bonanza have now vanished'? Are these claims justified?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: DEPUTY PRIME MINISTER; TRADE AND RESOURCES

TALK.START.PARA: —One thing that one has to say about the Australian Council of Trade Unions is that it is certainly stubborn about its point of view on uranium. Indeed, I think it is displaying a great deal of ignorance. With its head in the sand attitude it is not facing up to the realities of the situation. It does not reflect the opinion of many sections of the trade union movement which are involved in the development of uranium. Certainly, those involved in the construction, operation, transport and servicing side of the industry all see the virtues of more employment opportunities, increasing wealth for Australia and providing the needy world with energy.

ANSWER.PARA: The facts of the matter are that there are 478 nuclear power stations either operating or under construction around the world. A recent Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development report stated that, by the year 2000, 29 per cent of the OECD countries' electric power generation will come from nuclear sources, and that the world will become more and more dependent on nuclear energy to meet the well being of mankind. To say that that development is not taking place is nonsense. The Australian uranium companies have firm contracts to supply 55,000 tonnes of uranium worth approximately $4,000m. More contracts are being entered into progressively. I hope that, as time goes by, we will see more developments taking place in this country. Knowing that there is a substantial program for nuclear development around the world, the requirements for uranium during the 1980s decade will double. I hope that Australia will play a major role in fulfilling the world's requirement of this vital sort of energy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Health aware of the recommendations of the Victorian Post-Secondary Education Commission to the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission regarding funds in the next triennium to the Victorian College of Pharmacy? It is a fact that these recommendations show a 14 per cent reduction in funds by the year 1984? Is the Minister also aware that the pharamcist's role has moved rapidly from a compounder of drugs to adviser to a community which is increasingly facing a drug problem, and that the Victorian College of Pharmacy was undertaking during this triennium a new graduate and post-graduate course in clinical pharmacy to prepare pharmacists better for this important role? Is he aware that this course is threatened by the proposed cut? Will the Minister take urgent steps to intervene and to press the Minister for Education to restore the Victorian College of Pharmacy to its present level of funding so as to ensure that the proposed clinical pharmacy course is established and put into effect?

—I am not aware of the precise details of the matter referred to by the honourable member, but I can comment in relation to the role of pharmacists in the modern health care delivery system. I am pleased to acknowledge the fact brought forward by the honourable member that pharmacists do now have a significant role to play in advising members of the general public on matters covered by doctors prescriptions and on the drugs that may be prescribed for them. I would like to see a development of this counselling process. I know that this attitude is supported by the Pharmacy Guild of Australia. I will consult my colleague the Minister for Education to ascertain the situation in relation to the principal thrust of the question posed by the honourable member.

—Mr Speaker, my question is directed to you. Are you aware of certain allegations by a leading journalist that members of parliament are drunkards and bludgers? If you were to call in the House 'Order, Order!' and one member were to get up and ask for a gin and tonic and another for a middy of Carlton, would you rule them out of order?
—I appreciate the invitation which the honourable gentleman has given me to reply to the question, but I will reply to him in private.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hawke Mr R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I preface my question to the Minister for Industrial Relations by reminding him that he has twice this day emphasised his concern with the need to act resolutely and quickly and his abhorrence of delay in giving effect to decisions. Is it a fact that on 4 May 1981 the Minister announced the establishment of a Commonwealth inquiry into wage determination and industrial relations which had been agreed upon at the Premiers Conference? I ask whether the Minister concluded his announcement by saying:

QUESTION.PARA: There will be consultation between the States and the Commonwealth over the next week concerning the form and composition of the membership of the Committee of Inquiry.

What steps have been taken to have consultations with the States on this matter? If steps have been taken, when were they taken? Finally, given the imperative nature of the Minister's announcement on 4 May 1981, is this an example of resolute and quick action to give effect to a decision?

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member, as a former president of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, would know of the importance of consultation with employers and unions through the National Labour Consultative Council. It was a requirement of our decision to consult with the employers and the unions before this inquiry was instituted. Discussions were held not only with the States at Premier level at Premiers Conferences in May and June but also with the employers and the ACTU at a meeting of the NLCC in July-I will check up on the date and let the honourable member know-at which subsequently comments were provided as to the membership of the inquiry and the terms of reference. Amended terms of reference were prepared to try to accommodate the interests of all the parties and were to have been discussed by the Premiers at their last Premiers Conference. Other matters took up the time of that Conference. I will be discussing with State labour Ministers in Darwin on Friday of this week the amended terms of reference so that I can proceed from there to report to the Government.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: CAMPBELL COMMITTEE OF INQUIRY INTO THE AUSTRALIAN FINANCIAL SYSTEM

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Treasurer say when the report of the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System will be available and how the Government proposes to handle consideration of the report and its recommendations?

—The latest indication I have is that the report will be sent for printing to the Australian Government Printer towards the end of this month and copies about that time or shortly thereafter will be made available to the Government. The report, without knowing what is in it, will obviously be of very great consequence and will be very detailed. The Government will want to respond promptly to the report consistent with recognising that it is a very complex subject and one that has to be dealt with in an orderly fashion. We have already decided that a core group of officials drawn from my Department, from the Reserve Bank of Australia, from the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet, and also to include two private economic consultants, Professor Rose and Professor Hewson, employed on the personal staffs of the Prime Minister and myself, will examine the report and make recommendations to the Government. Obviously, the whole exercise is one on which I personally and the Government generally place a great deal of importance as we see in this report a valuable vehicle for sensible deregulation of the Australian financial industry.

—I wish to ask a question of the Deputy Prime Minister. It follows that question I asked him earlier in Question Time. In short, I seek to plumb the unfathomable depths of his unique economic understanding.
—The honourable gentleman should ask his question.

—Yes, Mr Speaker. I ask the Deputy Prime Minister: Is it a fact that Australia's deteriorating export competitiveness leading to a very large balance of trade deficit of which he expressed so much concern last night and again today is substantially due to a 10 per cent revaluation last year? Is it a fact that a revaluation of that order is equal to an across the board cut in tariffs in excess of 40 per cent? Is it a fact that huge capital inflows of the order forecast in this year's Budget Papers would imply further revaluations at least of the order of last year's 10 per cent revaluation? Is it a fact that revaluations make imports cheaper and exports dearer and destroy export competitiveness? I ask finally: What does the Minister intend to do, therefore, to alter this damaging impact of Government policies on traditional farm and manufacturing export industries?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: DEPUTY PRIME MINISTER; TRADE AND RESOURCES

TALK.START.PARA: —There is an element of sour grapes in the Leader of the Opposition's question. The fact is that we have economic progress. We have capital inflow developing resources. It is because of this that we have a very strong balance of payments situation. If that has led to a slight increase in the value of Australian currency, I think Australians ought to be very proud that we have a strong and stable currency which is helping to ease the inflationary pressures. No doubt this is one of the reasons why there is a high rate of imports coming into the country. If the Leader of the Opposition is so concerned about helping our export industries he might lend a hand to trying to resolve some of the industrial disputes-particularly those on the waterfront, which are disrupting exports from this country. I could not think of a more valuable contribution that the Leader of the Opposition could make than getting into this area and seeing that that situation is overcome. One of the big cost areas for the Australian economy is the loss of working hours through industrial trouble. We know that the Australian Labor Party is really the trade unions' party. It is muzzled by them. It cannot do anything about it. If it did more in this area, of course, we would be able to help our export industries.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Primary Industry. In the light of the meat substitution fraud and the obvious damage it has done to Australia's meat export industry, can the Minister tell the House what impact this has had on meat prices in the United States? Does the Minister intend to visit the United States of America to discuss these matters?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to the announcement on 11 August of the horse meat substitution problem, the price for lean cow beef was $1.05 per lb. There was no trading in Australian beef for three or four weeks, until about last Thursday when the market opened at $1.03 per lb. I received a cable this morning to inform me that the price today is $1.06 per lb. It does appear as though confidence in the market has been restored following the strong action we have taken in ensuring that the quality of the beef is as it ought to be. That is good news for the Australian beef industry and should not be underestimated.

ANSWER.PARA: In respect of the second part of the honourable member's question, last week the Acting Prime Minister referred to the prospect of my going to America to talk to the Americans about the beef substitution problem. The Government hopes to be in a position to make an announcement on this in a couple of days.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: West Mr S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Prime Minister whether he is aware that in reply to a question on 10 September by the Leader of the Opposition regarding the United States peacekeeping force in the Sinai the Minister for Foreign Affairs said:

QUESTION.PARA: The Australian Government is still seeking further information on the composition and on other aspects of the force.

Is the Prime Minister also aware that, according to the United States Assistant Secretary of State, control of the proposed United States peacekeeping force in the Sinai will involve appointment of a civilian United States director-general and a non-United States field commander? Is he also aware that the Assistant Secretary of State has said that the United States director-general would be authorised to deploy all troops in any manner he saw fit? In the event of any misguided participation by Australia, would this involve complete loss of Australian control over Australian troops in this highly militarised area? Finally, when will the Prime Minister bring this important matter into the House for proper parliamentary debate, instead of confining such discussion to the Government party rooms?

TALK.START.PARA: —There have been debates in the Parliament about this matter. I have said on a number of occasions that there are substantial arguments both for and against Australian participation. That is obviously one of the reasons why it is a difficult and important decision to make. As the matter stands at the moment, I cannot add much to what the Foreign Minister indicated last week or the week before. Certain questions have been put to the United States. If we do not have a response to those questions by the time the Foreign Minister meets Secretary of State Haig in New York in a couple of weeks time, no doubt the Foreign Minister will pursue those questions at that point. As it stands at the moment the ball is in the United States' court to respond to certain matters we have put to it.

—Is the Minister for Trade and Resources aware that resource development potential exists for different regions and States right throughout Australia? I further ask whether planning industrial relations and forward commitment by State governments is an impediment to Australia's resource development in any instance?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: DEPUTY PRIME MINISTER; TRADE AND RESOURCES

TALK.START.PARA: —A great deal of resource development is certainly taking place around Australia. I have also noticed comments by the Premier of New South Wales, Mr Wran seeking to point out the great strides being made in New South Wales as a result of resource development. Resource development in New South Wales is taking place despite the New South Wales Government. Two things are obvious in New South Wales. Resource development is taking place principally in the coal area, yet a complete inadequacy of handling facilities and an unusual amount of industrial disruption on the waterfront are holding up the export of coal from the State. I am told that yesterday 46 ships were waiting to be loaded-30 in Newcastle, 11 in Port Kembla and five in Sydney-mainly because of industrial action being taken in the State, which the New South Wales Government seems quite inept at handling.

ANSWER.PARA: On coal handling facilities, we know that in 1977 the New South Wales Government cancelled the construction of a coal loader at Botany Bay and diverted its attention to Balmain and Port Kembla. Balmain has proved to be totally inadequate. The loader at Port Kembla will not be completed for another year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. What the Minister is saying is not true in the sense that one of the--
—There is no point of order.
—I beg your pardon, sir.
—There is no point of order. The honourable gentleman is not entitled to debate the matter.
—I am not debating it.
—The honourable gentleman is disputing what the Minister said. He said that it is not true. He will resume his seat.
—Mr Speaker, my point of order is based on the premise that the Minister is misleading the Parliament.
—There is no point of order. The honourable gentleman will resume his seat. He is seeking to debate the matter.

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. I seek an explanation from you in doing so. Can we interpret from your ruling on the matter raised by the honourable member for Newcastle that truth is not an important ingredient in a Minister's answer and that a wilful attempt to mislead the Parliament is irrelevant? They are the two charges which have been levelled against the Deputy Prime Minister-I might say from my knowledge of this topic, quite justifiably-in circumstances that convert the procedures into farce.
—The Leader of the Opposition is arguing the issue. There is no point of order.

—It is well known throughout the coal mining industy in New South Wales that the industry is being hampered by inadequate facilities. I have pointed out the situation in Balmain and Port Kembla. There has been a long delay in getting a resolution on a coal loader in Newcastle. A resolution could not be obtained because there was disagreement amongst the unions. In the end, to try to resolve the problem amongst the unions, the New South Wales Government decided to use public funds for 20 per cent of the cost of construction of the loader although private enterprise was quite prepared to put the money in. But, of course, if the unions say they must have a shareholding the New South Wales Government, being a union party government, bows to the pressures of the trade unions. People have to realise that if they keep supporting a Labor government in New South Wales they will be virtually supporting a trade union party government.
—Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member for Dundas claim to have been misrepresented?

—Yes, Mr Speaker. I have been misrepresented in relation to an article appearing in the Sunday Telegraph of 13 September-that is, last Sunday-and a similar article in the Sunday Mail of 13 September. I believe that the article may have been syndicated to other newspapers as well. The articles about which I wish to make the explanation are entitled 'Why Ruddock took up cause for colleagues', which appeared in the Sunday Telegraph, and 'A sobering thought!' Both articles were written by Mr Laurie Oakes under the headline 'On the Inside: The Best Informed Political Column'. The articles impute to me certain motives in relation to the raising of a matter of privilege in this House. The question of any relationship between the Press treatment of the decision of the Remuneration Tribunal and the first article of Mr Oakes and my raising this matter in the House as a matter of privilege had not entered my mind. I cannot, of course, say whether it was in Mr Oakes's mind when he wrote the original article. But I wish to make it clear that, so far as I am concerned, my only motive in raising this matter was to defend this Parliament, this House and its members.
—The Minister for Industrial Relations has indicated to me that he seeks my indulgence to add to an answer which he gave during Question Time. The Minister may proceed.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr VINER

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Speaker. The honourable member for Wills asked me a question concerning the national inquiry. In my answer I referred to meetings of the National Labour Consultative Council and said that I would check the dates. I now have the dates. A background paper on the inquiry was tabled at the meeting of the NLCC on 8 July and was to have been discussed, along with some other matters, at a proposed special meeting set for 29 July. That particular meeting was cancelled but on 29 July I met with the President and Secretary of the Australian Council of Trade Unions and on a separate occasion with the National Director of the Confederation of Australian Industry. I discussed with them the terms of reference and the membership for the national inquiry. Subsequently, further comments were given to me, in particular by the employers. That gives the detailed information concerning the extent of consultations which, as I said, were required to be held with the NLCC.

INTERJECT.PARA: Mr Hawke-Mr Speaker, I crave your indulgence. As you have given the Minister leave to add to the answer that he gave, I seek to point out to you that in the question I asked what discussions the Minister had had with the States and when they were held. The Minister did not answer, certainly not in any detail, that part of the question. I seek your indulgence to ask the Minister whether he would provide me with that information to that part of the question which I initially addressed to him.

TALK.START.PARA: —I call the Minister.
—Yes, Mr Speaker. I will certainly get that detailed information and provide it to the honourable gentleman.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received advice from the Acting Government Whip and the Acting Opposition Whip of alterations in the nominations of members to Estimates Committees C, D and E which are as follows:

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, I present the reports relating to the following proposed works:

SPEECH.PARA: Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation Marine Laboratories, Hobart, Tasmania; and
Armoured Centre Redevelopment, Puckapunyal, Victoria.
I move:
That the reports be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate to the Manager of Opposition Business, the honourable member for Kingsford-Smith (Mr Lionel Bowen), that I did not have a chance to speak before. I ask for just one moment to comment on the speed with which the Public Works Committee has produced the report with respect to the transfer of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation Division of Fisheries Research and the Division of Oceanography to Hobart to form what in the ultimate will be a $25m national marine science research centre. I will not go into the details but I am sure the Opposition, on a bipartisan basis would acknowledge the current situation in the building industry in Tasmania, and the enormous work load of the Public Works Committee. It would agree that the Chairman and all members of the Committee, the Secretary-Mr Fenton-and all connected with it are to be congratulated on getting this report back into the Parliament so speedily. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: — I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That paragraph (9) of the resolution of appointment of the Standing Committee on Expenditure be omitted and the following paragraph substituted:
'(9) That 2 members of a sub-committee constitute a quorum of that sub-committee.'.

This amendment has been recommended by the Standing Committee on Expenditure, and it seems to the Government to be one that should meet the convenience of members of this place. I therefore commend it and recommend its support.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received letters from the honourable member for Adelaide (Mr Hurford) and the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) proposing that definite matters of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion today. As required by Standing Order 107, I have selected the matter which, in my opinion, is the most urgent and important, that is, that proposed by the honourable member for Adelaide, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The damaging uncertainty created in the motor vehicle manufacturing industry by the confusing statements of Government spokespersons.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hurford Mr C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are we to have a continuing motor vehicle manufacturing industry under this coalition Government or not? That is the question raised by the Labor Opposition in this debate today because there is enormous uncertainty about it. If we had a Labor national government-and the sooner we do the better, let me state-the answer to that question would be a resounding yes. We definitely will and must have a continuing motor vehicle manufacturing industry in this country. Under the Liberal and National Country Party coalition, the future is uncertain. The Government is fighting between its dries and its wets-between its free traders and its protectionists. The future for hundreds of thousands of workers is uncertain. Investment plans are halted. Jobs are being lost at a time of tragically high unemployment.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not just the future of the big five manufacturers which is at stake during this time of grave uncertainty. I am not referring just to the worries of GMH, Ford, Nissan, Toyota and Mitsubishi. It is the future of scores of component parts manufacturers and the tens of thousands of workers they employ whose livelihoods are in jeopardy. It goes beyond this. There is the steel industry, the glass industry, the tyre rubber industry, the forging industry-the list is endless. The ramifications of hurting this motor vehicle manufacturing industry are enormous. The industry is truly the engine of our manufacturing sector in general. Damage to this industry has a multiplier effect. Thousands of others indirectly involved are damaged also.

Furthermore, there are the regional implications. Adelaide is the Detroit of Australia. It is immensely dependent on this industry. At the 1976 census 8.9 per cent of its work force was involved in motor manufacturing. Geelong is also dependant on it, with 8.5 per cent of its population dependent on the industry, as are Albury-Wodonga and Melbourne. Indeed, the people of Sydney, Brisbane, Ballarat and Launceston, to mention just a few other places, would be sorely affected if they lost the jobs directly and indirectly dependent on the motor vehicle manufacturing industry.

Let me state the Australian Labor Party's attitude on this sensitive, highly labour-intensive industry. I have already stated that we are firmly committed to a continuing motor vehicle manufacturing industry. Our starting point is the need for jobs in this country-about 2 1/2 million of them at least in the 1980s. Let me just tell the House how I arrive at that figure. With the hidden unemployed, there are about 500,000 people wanting jobs right now. The demographic work done shows that if the rate of immigration remains at present levels-there are plenty of pressures for that rate to be increased-there will be a net increase of 1.3 million in the work force in the 1980s. So already we see the need for 1,800,000 new jobs in Australia in the 1980s. We can add to that the conservative figure of 700,000 new jobs to replace those phased out because of technological change in the 1980s, changes which must happen, which must be adopted, so that we can remain competitive and secure. Phasing out those extra jobs means creating new jobs; and 700,000 new jobs at least will be required. That brings us to a figure of 2 1/2 million new jobs required in this country in the 1980s.

We of the Australian Labor Party are certain that only by stimulating the manufacturing sector will we create the conditions for the establishment of those 2 1/2 million new jobs. Of course, not all the jobs will come from manufacturing. Most of them will come from the services sector. But the services sector is very dependent on people being employed in more basic pursuits like manufacturing. We cannot rely on mining or agriculture for all the necessary basic pursuits, so we have to get the stimulus from elsewhere. We must, I repeat, rely heavily on manufacturing.

Why can we not rely on mining and our resource-based industries? The reason is that they are not labour-intensive. This is not to say that they are not important. Of course, we must encourage them. But from the projects that we know are coming on line in the 1980s, from those published documents of the Department of Industry and Commerce and the Department of Trade and Resources and from other works that have fallen off the backs of trucks, we can be certain that these resource-based ventures will be responsible for creating about 10 per cent to 15 per cent at the most of the 2 1/2 million jobs we need. So we return to manufacturing. In particular, we return to the engine of our manufacturing sector-the motor vehicle manufacturing industry.

We of the Labor Party are committed to its survival. Our challenge is to answer the questions: What can we do to make it more competitive and more secure? What can we do to decrease relatively the prices of cars so that any buyer resistance that exists today will be ended? That is our aim. One thing is certain: We must not behave like our conservative political opponents have behaved. We must give the industry an assured future. We must end the uncertainty that they have created. A starting point is to repudiate straight away that recommendation of the Industries Assistance Commission's draft report which implies that this sector can survive, in the early years anyway before it has been restructured, without quotas.

Let us learn from Europe and the United States with their vastly greater populations and scale economies. The motor vehicle manufacturing industries in the United States and the European Economic Community cannot survive without direct government intervention. In their cases, voluntary restraints on imports are used, preserving for their home products a far larger share of their home markets than applies under our 80-20 quota system in our small country of 14 million people. In other words, in spite of the big differences in size between us and them, with all the scale economy benefits in their favour-not ours-the United States of America and the European Economic Community preserve for their home products a greater percentage than the 80 per cent that we in Australia preserve for our home products. We must not close our eyes to the fact that these quotas have hidden tariff equivalent. But that equivalent is closer to 120 per cent than the 60 per cent recommended in the draft report of the IAC. If we accepted the IAC draft report recommendations to adopt initially a 60 per cent tariff rate-admittedly the report says that it will drop even further later-our shores would be swamped with Japanese cars. We must give that nation credit for the fact that it is enourmously efficient-with its three shifts, its robots, and its better industrial relations. By one means or another Japan can export cars into this country under any tariff barrier. All five of our motor manufacturing companies would be swamped and together they would subside. In our view Australian's motor manufacturing industry would be damaged enormously and quickly. We in the Australia Labor Party believe that the 80-20 quota arrangement for the foreseeable future is essential.

Before leaving that subject let me state that any abandonment of this quota policy which led to greater imports of motor cars would bring benefits to the Australian consumer of only a temporary nature. As our motor industry became devastated from reduced tariffs the imported cars would be relatively cheaper for only a short period. Importers do not administer a perfect free market. Imported car prices would increase to such a level that we would wonder where are the benefits of eliminating our motor vehicle manufacturing industry. I am informed that this happened in Sweden in relation to its textiles and clothing industry. That country is now busily re-establishing a home-based textile and clothing sector at enormous cost after wastefully allowing its previous industry to be eliminated in the name of a non-existent, free trade, perfect competition system.

In addition to a continuation of the quota system in the foreseeable future, until restructuring takes place, we believe that the local content plan must continue. We will not commit ourselves to particular ingredients of this plan until we have seen the IAC final report. There is not a lot of room for change. Some changes must be made to the export complementation scheme to make sure, for instance, that only locally added value is included in the credits allowed. That local content plan is vital for the continuing activity of our component parts manufacturing industry. The Australian Labor Party is committed to its healthy survival.

Incidentally, we should not get too carried away with the idea that our industry is unduly inefficient and uncompetitive. It takes an average Australian worker 22.3 weeks of earnings to pay for an Australian car. Figures for other comparable countries are as follows: Sweden 29.9 weeks; France 30.7; Britain 42; Japan 17.2; and the United States 17.6. In that comprehensive list Australia is shown to be more efficient than all but Japan and the United States. But we are not resting on our laurels and we do not intend to do that. We seek the greatest possible economies of scale in order to achieve the greatest efficiency, productivity and competitiveness. That is what Labor's policies lead to. We would have preferred to achieve this by encouraging standardisation of parts manufacture; in other words, the five assemblers using common parts. But the Government and the majority of the industry now have gone in another direction for scale economies, namely, the use of export complementation. So much water has gone under the bridge and so much investment has been based on the complementation scheme that it is very difficult now responsibly to reject it without creating enormous uncertainty and loss of jobs. But we, on this side of the House, will monitor the scheme very carefully, making sure that transfer pricing is rejected, and that only a discounted value of imports is allowed in return for the exports we generate.

A major area of difference between us and our conservative opponents is in the government machinery that we believe is vital for achieving the continued managed change needed in this sector. It requires close government-business partnership. That is why we have advocated the establishment of an automotive industry authority to examine constantly the tariff quota situation, to eliminate transfer pricing, to monitor and regulate any change from local to overseas component sourcing, to seek to achieve more standard parts manufacturing between the five big companies, and so on. We hope that our automotive industry authority could go further and, by one means or another, achieve such mergers to reduce, to all intents and purposes, our five present companies to at least three when it comes to the manufacturing of the various types and models of cars in Australia. Preferably it would be better to get down to two companies in order to get those scale economies for competitiveness. Ours is not a status quo approach; it is a definite approach with definite objectives, an unashamedly managed change interventionist approach. We want to achieve those objectives in that way. Above all, we want a more expansionary budgetary and monetary policy so that consumers have funds in their pockets to buy cars and other products. All of this contrasts with the uncertainty of our political opponents as they continue their fights between the dries and the wets. The Minister for Industry and Commerce (Sir Phillip Lynch) stated:
Wage pressure and threatened inflation will be countered by tariff and quota cuts in 1982.
That was a quote from the Australian of 21 August 1981. The Australian of 31 July 1981 states:
Liberal (Senator John Watson) hits Party free trade lobby.
I ask the honourable member for Moore (Mr Hyde): 'Is that a good quote?'

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a bad quote.

—That is a bad one, he says. This just shows the differences among government members which cause the enormous uncertainties and this is the subject of this matter of public importance today. Another quotation states: 'New references to the IAC on industry protection and assistance'. We have had two new references in the last month or so which have created enormously greater uncertainty. Business Review of 18 July 1981 states:

SPEECH.PARA: 'Treasury Chief John Stone believes his PM, Malcolm Fraser, has made a fundamental and dangerous mistake in international economic policy . . . If Stone is right, industry could be considerably changed.'
It goes on:

For manufacturers who depend on protection assistance, the fulfilment of Stone's predictions that Malcolm Fraser is going to be pressured by our neighbours into tariff reform, would carry vast consequences. This is why Fraser's push on the North-South issue, which to many Australians appears esoteric, should be taken seriously by business.
The honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Sainsbury) was reported in Hansard of 26 August as having said:
The car industry, like some other industries, receives favours from the Australian people far in excess of what it produces.

I wish I had time for more quotes from the honourable member for Moore. To cap it all off, on 25 August the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Young) asked the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Sir Phillip Lynch) whether he was prepared to give an assurance that there would be no reduction in protection over the next few weeks. The Minister merely answered 'no', without giving the industry some assurance to end the uncertainty. Apparently the car owners association has a copy of these IAC reports but anybody else interested in this industry does not have them. I call on the Government to end the wasteful speculation, to end the era of confusing statements and to take note of this matter of public importance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Mr H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Adelaide (Mr Hurford), like myself, represents a South Australian electorate. Therefore one can understand why he makes some professions of concern about the future prosperity of the motor vehicle manufacturing industry. That is a concern that I share with him. It is important, especially for South Australia, that the motor vehicle industry has a future of prosperity. That industry has important regional considerations for South Australia, both in terms of investment and employment. A significant proportion of employment in manufacturing industry in South Australia is contained in the motor vehicle industry, more specifically the plants of Mitsubishi Australia Ltd, General Motors-Holden's Ltd and various component manufacturers. Therefore it is important that any decisions taken with regard to the future of that industry are taken with great care and adequate consultation and consideration.

SPEECH.PARA: That is exactly what the present Government has been doing. That is, of course, in marked contrast to the approach of the Australian Labor Party. Unfortunately, in this matter of public importance, which the honourable member for Adelaide has raised on behalf of the Labor Party, the Party has again revealed its notorious trait of sacrificing national and regional interests in the pursuit of political expediency.

The Labor Party well knows the established and appropriate procedures which this Government has for dealing with the reports of the Industries Assistance Commission. The Government has consistently pursued that process in dealing with the IAC report on post-1984 protection arrangements for motor vehicle manufacturing. In contrast, the Labor Party and its spokesmen such as the honourable member for Adelaide, the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Young) and others, through their public statements and questions which they have asked of Ministers in this Parliament, have implied that a decision ought to be made immediately. Hasty ill-considered decisions were the hallmark of the Labor Party when it was in government during the Whitlam era from 1972 to 1975. In contrast, the Fraser Government is determined to give adequate consideration to all the issues involved in this important matter.

Of course, when we listened to the speech of the honourable member for Adelaide today, we did not hear much that was of relevance to the words contained in the matter of public importance. It is timely to remind the House that those words are:
The damaging uncertainty created in the motor vehicle manufacturing industry by the confusing statements of Government spokespersons.

It was only in the last minute and a half of his remarks that the honourable member for Adelaide referred to any statements of any Government spokespersons at all. For the rest of his speech he completely ignored the substance of the matter of public importance that he has put to this House.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not unusual.

—It is not unusual as my colleague the honourable member for Barker remarks. The honourable member for Adelaide talked about anything but statements made by government spokespersons. The statements that he did pull out in that last minute and a half did not reveal any conflict in statements made by government spokesmen at all.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me return to the subject of the motor vehicle industry and try to get some relevance into the debate. The present motor vehicle manufacturing plan applies until the end of 1984. Beyond that the Government has to take decisions as to what is an appropriate level of protection to be applied to the industry. In accord with that, in early 1979, it asked the IAC to conduct an inquiry and to provide recommendations as to appropriate government policy after 1984. The IAC, in its usual procedure, took evidence and produced a draft report which was then open to public consideration and public comment. The IAC then took comments from various interested parties such as manufacturers, consumers, importers and anyone else with an interest in the industry who had a mind to give evidence to the IAC and to comment on that draft report. Following that, as is the procedure, it produced its final report, which was recently given to the Government. It is now for the Government to give consideration to that final report in the light of representations and inputs that are provided, once again, by those with interests in the industry and, indeed, by its own back bench members of this Parliament who have also been giving serious and detailed consideration to the future of this industry. Later this year, when all that material is taken into account, analysed by the Government and discussed within Cabinet, the Government will announce its decision on post-1984 arrangements for the industry.

It is not appropriate for the Government to rush in and make an early decision, as the Labor Party would have it do on the basis of the remarks of the honourable member for Adelaide today. It must consider all the issues involved. I will enumerate some of those important issues. The Government must take into account the effects of its decision on the economy, the consumer price index and rate of inflation. It must look also at the effects of its decision on the future of the Australian dollar exchange rate and the impact of that on exporters. It must look also at the needs of consumers, who are a very important component of an industry such as the motor industry. If the needs of consumers are not considered, then certainly the motor industry does not have any future in this country.

On the other side of the coin, the Government must look at the need for stability in the industry and the employment effects of any decision which it might take. It must look also at the regional problems which its decision might affect. I have already mentioned the impact that certain courses of action would have on South Australia. Anyone with any nous at all, of course, knows the relationship between all those issues and factors is very complex and needs careful deliberation. That is what the Government is doing and what it has been doing over recent times.

In contrast, as I have said, the Labor Party, through its contribution to this debate and statements that have been made recently, indicates that a hasty decision ought to be taken, even although it might not necessarily be in the interests of the industry or the Australian economy. In contrast to what the honourable member for Adelaide has inferred in this motion today it is the Labor Party that is hopelessly divided on this issue. On the one hand we have the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Lionel Bowen), the honourable member for Adelaide and some of his colleagues who are old fashioned mercantilists and on the other hand we have Senator Walsh leading the anti-protection lobby within the Labor Party. The industry, of course, does not know which of these factions is dominant, which will remain dominant or which might be dominant if the Labor Party-God forbid-ever came to office again in this country. Let us look at the way in which the Labor Party has taken decisions in the past on issues such as this. Overnight in 1973 it implemented a 25 per cent tariff cut.

TALK.START.PARA: —What?
—It did that overnight, without any adequate consultation or adequate consideration of the issues involved.
—Not the same people sitting over there?

—Exactly those people, as the honourable member for Dundas interjects. Many of them were senior people in that Government. Leaving aside whether that 25 per cent tariff cut was justified, the major criticism that can be launched at the Labor Party is the way in which it took that decision. It was, as I said, a decision taken overnight without any adequate consultation or consideration. Once again that is what the Labor Party is advocating today in relation to the matters being considered at present. We have to remember also that the most recent closure of a motor industry plant, the GMH plant at Pagewood was in a State governed by the Labor Party-New South Wales. Clearly, the industry does not trust its prospects under a Labor Government. Of course, we ought to remember also that the Leyland plant in New South Wales was closed when the Federal Labor Party was in office. The party, cannot be trusted to give adequate consideration to its decisions.
—What a reputation!

—It is an awful reputation. We need to recognise also that investment generally collapsed under the Labor government between 1973 and 1975. It is the policies of the Fraser Government that have been effective in restoring a favourable economic climate for investment. The statistics show the record levels of investment that are occurring at present in Australia. Perhaps the approach of the Labor Party could be summed up in a quotation from that old sage, Petronius, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: We trained hard, but is seemed that every time we were beginning to form into teams, we would be reorganized. I was to learn later in life that we tend to meet any new situation by reorganizing; and a wonderful method it can be for creating the illusion of progress while producing confusion, inefficiency and demoralization.

That really sums up the approach of the Labor Party to this issue. The policies that it has advocated are very general. It completely ignores the need for specific detail and the specifics of policy. The Labor Party's attitude clearly has not been thought through. As I have said, there is conflict between the statements of spokesmen on the Labor Party's side of politics, and the Labor Party has not demonstrated in this debate any conflicting statements from the Government.
Let me refer to a recent statement by the Labor Party's former leader, the former Prime Minister, Mr Whitlam. He said.
In our time we got rid of Leyland in New South Wales. In Wran's time we got rid of General Motors in New South Wales-and the Labor vote has gone up consistently in New South Wales.

He was criticising specifically the Opposition's shadow Minister for Industry and Commerce, the honourable member for Adelaide who has launched this motion today. He has advocated significant reductions in protection for the industry in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?

—The former Prime Minister, Mr Whitlam, who must be regarded still as a strong spokesman for the Labor Party because he makes plenty of statements. That clearly demonstrates the conflict that exists in the Labor Party, once again in contrast to the unified and consistent approach of this Government.
—It was evident this morning.

—Once again this was evident this morning, as the honourable member for Moore said. As I said, this Government is ensuring that adequate consideration is given to any decision that is taken so that all points of view are heard.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at some of the other statements that the Labor Party has made recently on the industry. The honourable member for Adelaide claimed in a recent speech that there had been a depressed demand for motor vehicles this year. Nothing could be further from the truth. In fact, the statistics show that there has been a significant increase in the demand for motor vehicles this year. So much for the Labor Party's knowledge of the industry. What has it suggested? It has suggested the establishment of an Automotive Industry Authority. The Labor Party is, of course, suggesting more government bureaucracy. The Labor Party seems to be very confused about the way in which it would operate. It says such an authority would be under the umbrella of the Industries Assistance Commission. That demonstrates confusion about the role of the IAC which, in fact, is an independent body established to give independent advice to the Government on the requirements of industry. Its recommendations can be accepted or rejected by the Government.

It seems that the Labor Party would set up an Automotive Industry Authority whose decisions would be taken as final. The Labor Party is suggesting, of course, that some bureaucracy would have better wisdom about the way in which the motor industry should operate, its future demands, and the future prospects for it, than the marketplace with or without certain levels of protection. Surely, it is the marketplace for automotive vehicles that should best determine that industry's future. That can operate on a free market basis without any protection or it can operate in a modified market form with certain levels of protection. That is what the Goverment has to determine in giving consideration to IAC recommendations. But that situation must be regarded as a better option than some massive bureaucracy determining each and every decision that is to be taken with respect to the motor vehicle industry. In what way would that Authority take account of technological changes and of changes in consumer demand in regard to the size and style of vehicles? It would be very difficult for such an authority to have the wisdom which market forces would have in determining those requirements.

It is the Government's view that the recommendations of the IAC should be given adequate consideration, together with the input of all those other interested parties, including the manufacturers, consumers and back bench members of parliament. That is why the Government will not be hastened into ill-advised decisions; it will ensure that adequate time is given to consider all of those points of view and to consider the effects on the economy, the effects on consumers and the effects on the industry itself. When it has given consideration to those points of view it will make a decision which will be in the interests not only of the industry but also of the Australian economy and the Australian community. I am confident that the decision that the Government takes will ensure the survival of the industry and its long term prosperity. Until that decision is taken it is not appropriate for Ministers in particular to comment on likely decisions. Once again, we see in the approach of the Labor Party a lack of consideration for the industry. This has been demonstrated by its members asking questions of Ministers in that context, expecting them to make some comment on the industry, on the IAC report, before that adequate consideration has been given. Either the Labor Party is naive or, as I said, it is seeking political expediency at the expense of the industry and the Australian economy. The Government will not accept that approach; it has never accepted that approach. It will continue the consistent approach it has adopted in reaching decisions on the matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scholes Mr G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —If I were an employee dependent for my future livelihood on the honourable member for Kingston (Mr Chapman), who has just spoken, I would be petrified. Not only did he indicate that he does not believe that anyone should embarrass the Government or Ministers by debating this matter but also he is an attender, I understand, at the free trade lobby called the modest members' club. Government members do not seem to see any conflict at all in the fact that among their number are people who wish to see dissipated major sections of the Australian manufacturing industry involved in the production and manufacture of motor vehicles and the parts and supply areas of that industry. Those members who want those sections dissipated or thrown out are apparently free to express their opinions as they wish. But apparently they find objection when someone supports the continued employment of substantial sections of the Australian community and opposes the opening up of Australian markets to unrestricted and, in many cases, subsidised industries which are non-competitive with Australian manufactured products.

SPEECH.PARA: It is all right for the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Sainsbury) to talk in the House about the costs in the motor vehicle industry. There are costs associated also with a number of the other aspects of protection that exist in Australia. I do not see many members of the rural lobby standing up in this Parliament and offering to allow free imports of New Zealand dairy, meat and other products, which would be available to be sold in Australia if there were not varying forms of restrictions. I do not see members of the National Country Party, which is very good on downing protection in some areas, getting up and making statements that they are prepared to give up large sections of tax concessions.

I will get back to the subject at hand because it is critical not only to Adelaide but to the people in my electorate. Geelong is a city which literally is dependent on the motor vehicle industry. It has a major manufacturing plant which is involved in the higher end of the technology of the motor vehicle industry. Up until the current models, the substantial design and drafting and the higher levels of technology for motor vehicles have been undertaken in that area. Uncertainty was created when two years ago this particular motor vehicle plan period was interrupted by the present Government with a change in the plan to suit a manufacturer. The plan was foreshortened. That may seem to be a reasonable objective, especially if it satisfies one of the manufacturers who happens to be politically influential; but the facts of life are that if a company invests $1m in the design and production of an Australian-based vehicle it is entitled to expect that the undertakings given by government at that time for the period during which the plan will operate, and therefore for the recovery of the invested funds, will be met. In this instance they will not be met. The Government has tinkered with the last set of decisions.

The honourable member for Kingston suggested that we are not entitled to debate this matter, nor are we entitled to know what the decisions or recommendations of the Industries Assistance Commission are or what discussions are taking place at a government level. He suggested that that is normal. It is not normal. During the last series of hearings on the car plan, the IAC recommendations were made public before the Government made its decision, and manufacturers, employees and other interested parties were invited to give evidence or to make submissions on the proposed changes. Recommendations were then arrived at in respect of that plan, which is the plan that is substantially, with some changes, in operation at the moment. Unfortunately, there have been other changes in the plan which have acted to the disadvantage of the longer established manufacturers in Australia. One of those changes is that they do not have access to import licensing for vehicles outside the manufacturing plans, access which the two Japanese manufacturers who have most recently come into the plan do have. I do not include in that the Mitsubishi company because it replaced Chrysler Australia Ltd. We have now a situation where two manufacturers have a distinct advantage over the other three manufacturers.

It is unfortunate that the Parliament could not have a proper and full debate on this matter. Certainly the honourable member for Henty (Mrs Child) has great concern about parts manufacturers in her electorate. The honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Milton) and the honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mr Scott) are equally concerned about the effects on the people they represent, as are other honourable members on our side of the Parliament. Apparently honourable members on the other side are not so concerned. The motor vehicle industry is a substantial part of employment in Australia. Prior to the last election this Government brought in a proposal whereby it guaranteed textile and footwear industries substantial protection over the next seven years. It introduced legislation in respect of a narrower section of the industry which in fact will provide bounties equivalent to $12,500 per employee-in excess of $70m a year. It now suggests that those employees-I speak specifically of those in my electorate because the industry is almost the sole source of economy in the Geelong area-are expendable to some whim of the Government, some ideological belief that there can be a magical creation of additional jobs. If that magical creation of additional jobs really is possible, why is it that we still have 350,000 unemployed after six years of this Government in office? Where are the jobs which were to be created in other areas of industry? What is the mobility of labour?

We talk of uncertainties. If a person has a house to sell in Geelong, while the motor car industry is in doubt he can forget about it. If he has to move somewhere else, or wishes to move somewhere else to escape the continuing unemployment in that area created by economic policies which do not in any way meet the requirements of those people in Australia who wish to work, he has no prospect whatsoever of disposing of his property, of the investment that has been made in the house, which has been encouraged for many years by governments in this place and in other places. He is tied into a situation where he is economically limited in his opportunities to move. Certainly the losses involved in moving from an area where there is concern about the future of employment and about the economy of that area, are significant and have a destabilising effect.

The Ford Motor Co. of Australia Ltd may or may not be the best manufacturer in Australia. It is probably the oldest, and it is now the only vehicle firm which in recent times has provided vehicles with the higher technology rather than that at the low end of the technology scale. We are now hearing suggestions from Government members and from the IAC which appear to have some sort of a Hans Christian Andersen approach, suggestions that if we do the things that they believe we should, all the other things will come good. Over the weekend I saw that two people who are being paid in our universities, clearly under false pretences, suggest that if we import vehicles instead of manufacturing them in Australia the servicing and maintenance of those vehicles will create jobs to take up the slack from the manufacturing industries. If the imported vehicles are so bad that they require those sorts of numbers, I suggest that we would not be doing ourselves or anyone else a favour by importing them. The ordinary consumer does not have taxation write-off provisions for his motor vehicle, as do some other more favoured people in our community.

I would like to deal in some detail with my own electorate, but in a 10-minute debate that is not possible. In a city of 170,000 people, the motor industry pumps $189m a year into the city's economy. I ask any honourable member in this House: What would happen to Canberra if a comparable situation arose and the Public Service was moved somewhere else? The example I am talking about is fairly obvious. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a submission which was made on behalf of my electorate to the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs, (Mr N. A. Brown). It is impossible to read it at this time.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
EMPLOYMENTANDMANUFACTURING INDUSTRY IN GEELONG
Passenger Motor Vehicle and Components Industry-Post 1984 Assistance Policy
Submission and Deputation by Representatives of the Geelong Community
August 1981
Introduction

The action and decisions to be taken by the Federal Government on assistance measures for passenger motor vehicles and components after 1984 are of absolutely vital importance to the Geelong community.
This submission requests that the Federal Government:
recognises the extent of economic dependence of the Geelong Region on manufacturing industry especially the motor vehicle and components industry.
consider fully the impact of any proposed measures on the Geelong economy and community.

consults with the Geelong community on the specific impact on Geelong of any proposed measures. Where these are adverse it would be expected that the Government would also report on region specific adjustment assistance.
In making these requests the Geelong community wishes to point out that:
the IAC has stated in its draft report that Geelong has the highest employment concentration in motor vehicle and components manufacture of any region in the Nation.
Geelong's concentration is almost totally in manufacture and design not in overseas sourced assembly or design.

It is therefore suggested that the requests made above are entirely reasonable and that the Geelong community does have a special claim to recognition, consideration and consultation by Government in this matter.
MANUFACTURING INDUSTRY IN GEELONG
The Geelong Region has 19,200 people in manufacturing employment i.e., approximately 2 per cent of the manufacturing employment of the Nation.

Value added by manufacturing in Geelong is $414m (1978-79). Approximately 41 per cent of manufacturing employment in Geelong is within three enterprises-the Ford Motor Company, International Harvester and Alcoa. The future Geelong operations of both Ford and International Harvester are now both endangered by uncertainty in government policy. The Ford plant employs 4,400 persons.

The Geelong Region's economic development is almost entirely linked to the growth of expertise and investment in its manufacturing base. It is a region without substantial natural resources. Until 1973 this course of economic development was positively encouraged by government as a means of maintaining an alternative industrial centre outside of Melbourne as well as providing wider employment opportunities for Western Victoria.

The Geelong economy has never fully recovered from the 1973 tariff and quota changes in the textile and clothing industry. The direct impact was almost instantaneous with a number of major manufacturers ceasing or severely winding back production. About 800 people lost jobs in the textile and clothing industry in 1974 and during 1974 and 1975 unemployment rose by 2,700 indicating that about another 1,500 employees lost jobs in the service sector indirectly as a result of the tarriff/quota changes and economic disruption of that time.

During 1975 and since the motor vehicle manufacturing policy has been the subject of numerous proposals and policy shifts Government would appear to be unaware of the very damaging affects this uncertainty has on business and community confidence in regions with a high investment in motor vehicle manufacturing.

Additionally during 1980 the negative impact has developed in Australia of virtually unrestrained tractor and agricultural machinery importation, leading to a large number of importers without servicing/parts networks or long-term commitment to the Australian market. Retrenchments and early retirements at International Harvester's Geelong plant totalled in 1980-81.
IMPACT OF PROPOSED CHANGES

Whatever the particular options which are finally adopted by Government virtually all known proposals would be likely to adversely affect total employment in the motor vehicle and components industry in Geelong. This is because all known options dilute in one form or another integrated manufacture and Australian design.

Consequently, the major point that is suggested the Government note in relation to Geelong is that it has had sustained high unemployment since 1973 and that any loss of jobs in motor vehicle and components manufacture in the next few years will bring on a deeper recession in the Region's economy.

The Geelong community and Victorian Government have been successful in attracting some new investment since 1973 and new industrial development should be high in the 1980's. But, the projects are capital intensive and will not immediately, at least that is until the late 1980's, offer a substantial employment alternative to the motor vehicle and components industry. While the current IAC reference and Government consideration are for post 1984 it is highly likely that any adopted measures will be adjusted to by companies before 1984.
It is in recognition of the above that the following summary of the current economic importance and future decline of the industry in Geelong is outlined.
