RESPONSIBILITIES AND COMMUNITY VIEWS
It is accepted that the Government must make its decisions in the broad national interest.

However, where such decisions could have major livelihood implications for an identifiable group of Australians, such as a regional community, it is strongly suggested that the Government has a responsibility to consult fully and directly with the persons to be affected before decisions are made. It is not accepted that because the final decisions rest with individual companies that this lessens Government responsibility. There is also a responsibility for the community to indicate the general nature of its concern to Government. In doing this the following points are made with the widespread support of the Geelong community:
there is a general concern in the Geelong community, through its high involvement in manufacturing, that the nature and value of manufacturing industry is not fully understood by Government.

Specifically there would seem to be an inadequate appreciation of the value of concentrated manufacturing activity. The value of such activity in developing economies of scale across a wide range of small and medium-sized enterprises is very high.

in the uncertainty surrounding manufacturing industry the Geelong community does not see a short or medium term alternative to manufacturing for economic survival. At March 1981 there were 6,507 registered unemployed persons in the community-representing 9.0% of an estimated workforce of 72,000.

It is likely that any sustained period of unemployment in Geelong exceeding 10% would push Geelong's economy into severe recession. The delicate balance of Geelong's economy at the moment must be understood by Government.

Geelong's relative smaller size-total population 172,000-compared to the metropolitan centres of production means that adverse changes are not spread as thinly or absorbed so easily as in the capital cities.

The Geelong Region can expect some significant growth in processing/manufacturing industry during the 1980s. However, the current average investment for these projects of $1.36 million per employee and at least during the 1980s they do not offer any substantial replacement to existing manufacturing activity. Indeed existing manufacturers are crucial to the manpower needs of these projects. Ford has long supplied other Geelong industry with skilled employees through Ford's high commitment to apprenticeship training.

large-scale relocation of the work-force out of the Geelong Region is not a reasonable economic or social option to be encouraged by Government. While it may appear to be an attractive solution to skilled man-power shortages on resource projects, it must be recognised that such relocation is highly selective. Only the skilled are encouraged to move. Thus Region's like Geelong are left without their major resource for future economic development and with large numbers of unskilled and semi-skilled people in unemployment. This process has begun to happen in Geelong over the last 18 months.

the social problems and dis-harmony generated by unemployment in industrial areas appear not to be understood by policy-makers. With sustained levels of unemployment the effect of uncertainty in the employed labour-force increases rather than diminishes the tensions of industrial relations in the work-place.
SUGGESTED PROPOSALS

This submission supports the principle of 'gradualism' for changes in protection of the motor vehicle and components industry. However, it is suggested that decreases in Australian content and changes in market sharing particularly should only be undertaken after the Government is virtually absolutely sure that such measures will not undermine Geelong's medium or long-term economic structure or its cohesive society.

The IAC merely recognised in its draft report that adverse effects in Geelong could be very high. It is suggested to Government that the Draft Report nowhere near fulfilled its reference in respect to regional implications.

It is therefore suggested to Government that a process of full consultation with the Geelong community before adoption of changes will enable Government to have a more informed picture of their possible impact not only in Geelong, but also, by assessment of the Region with most concentrated activity on the industry, of the total impact on Australia's manufacturing sector. The community is willing to lend every assistance to such consultation.

The IAC did recommend in its Draft Report the adoption of 'region-specific' adjustment assistance measures. It did not suggest, in the Draft Report, what these measures should involve. The Employment Strategy for the Geelong Region (attached) was produced because of downturns in others of areas of manufacturing in Geelong. However it is suggested that the recommendations of that Strategy are equally appropriate for Government consideration as medium-term assistance to this Region. Equally however measures for effective short-term assistance must be devised by Government.
(i) removal of the uncertainty over manufacturing industry;
(ii) ensuring that capital and infrastructure is made available to manufacturers at competitive rates to that supplied to natural resource projects;
(iii) relocation of a higher-order public administration function to Geelong to stimulate its tertiary/services sector;
(iv) increased funding and commitments for up-grading the skills of the existing work-force in Geelong;
(v) special commitment for skills enhancement for those persons in Geelong at all levels of industry who will be responsible for the introduction of new production methods in manufacturing industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the Government considers the motor industry and protection, it should also consider that people who talk against those sections of industry in Australia quite often have very significant economic advantages from the taxpayer's purse. Those people and regions who will be disadvantaged have no means available to them for recovery. It is a serious question. I believe it is unfortunate that it is not publicly debated more often.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bradfield Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Both the honourable member for Adelaide (Mr Hurford) and the honourable member for Corio (Mr Scholes) have spoken about the motor industry but, when one looks at the wording of the matter of public importance put forward by them, they certainly have not taken the opportunity to put forward any arguments in support of the matter. I presume from that that there is no argument against the Government, in any of the conflicting statements that have been made, that would have any effect on the motor vehicle industry. When one studies past statements made by members of the Opposition, there are very many conflicting statements, statements that have done nothing but create mischief and cause concern within the motor vehicle industry. On 25 August 1981 the honourable member for Adelaide gave a notice of motion in this House which caused anxiety amongst the motor vehicle industry and people employed in it. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move: That this House calls upon the Government:
(1) to end the uncertainty caused by the draft recommendations of the Industries Assistance Commission . . .

That is something to which he drew attention which does nothing more than create uncertainty. On 25 February 1981, in a question addressed to the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Sir Phillip Lynch), the honourable member for Adelaide made reference to the IAC's own admission about plants closing and thousands of jobs being lost. I contend that this is drawing unnecessary attention to the industry and creating unnecessary anxiety amongst people in it. On 19 August 1981 the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Lionel Bowen) asked the Minister a question about the automotive complementation scheme as follows:

Is the Minister aware that this scheme is coming into some disarray because of the allegations certainly made by the automotive parts manufacturers that there is manipulation of the scheme by transfer pricing . . .

All the conflicting statements have been made by members of the Opposition. They are made to destroy an Australian industry which has grown substantially since the end of World War II. In 1948 General-Motors Holden's Ltd, an Australian company, brought out an Australian car, the Holden. It was first presented to the Australian public at a cost of #675. For those members not as old as I am, that is $1,350. Today an Australian car sells to the Australian people for about $9,000. In 1948 it took two and a half years of average weekly personal income to purchase a car. Today it takes only eight months of average weekly personal income to purchase the equivalent car. Is that not an illustration that an Australian industry was born, has become efficient and has grown to compete as well as any other industry in the international market? Yet the industry is small by world standards. It has a market to produce only 400,000 to 450,000 units per annum. That is causing the industry trouble. Another thing that is causing it trouble-this was referred to by the honourable member for Adelaide-is the super-efficiency and high production of the Japanese manufacturers. They are causing difficulties through their competitive production not only to the Australian industry but also to every car manufacturing company in the world. We must address ourselves to those difficulties. They have led to the draft report of the Industries Assistance Commission that came out in February of this year. They will make this Government think very carefully to bring down a decision that will benefit all Australians on the final report of the IAC which, I understand, will be in the hands of the Government shortly.

This Government realises very much that the Australian automotive industry underpins much of Australia's engineering capacity, skills and technology. We realise that it provides employment in the manufacturing, servicing and distribution sectors and in the very important Australian component manufacturing industry. Those industries combined employ directly 150,000 people. Including the other industries dependent on the automotive industry, that figure is probably as high as 250,000. More importantly, the automotive industry, through apprenticeships, provides much of the future skills for Australian industry. It is an industry of which all Australians should be proud. It has weathered many storms over the years. It has weathered production cut-backs and reduced profitability. It has weathered and is weathering the demand change to small, more fuel efficient cars. In the near future it will have to make changes to come up with world car technology, particularly concerning front wheel drive vehicles. The opposition and the honourable member for Adelaide say that the IAC's draft report came out this year and we should have made a decision. We will not be rushed into quick decisions. We will consider all the aspects. As I said, we will make a good decision for Australia. I will illustrate how hollow are the words of the honourable member for Adelaide. He made a speech to the Federation of Automotive Products Manufacturers on 9 June 1981. In one part of that speech he said:
I cannot set out a precise view of the assistance arrangements that the Labor Party considers necessary because we do not yet have the benefit of the IAC's final report.

The honourable member said that the Labor Party cannot make a decision and does not have a policy because it has not seen the IAC's final report, yet he expects us to rush into making a decision. By his own admission in that speech the Labor Party cannot do so. When the final IAC report comes out and before the Government makes a decision many aspects must be considered. Consideration of all those aspects will enable the Government to make the decision that will benefit all Australian people. We must consider what percentage of vehicles should be local content if there is such a plan, export facilitation, how we can assist our industry to export more of its products, the effect of quotas on people, the rate of duty we should apply to motor cars and automotive parts, the effects on employment and the future of Australian technology. We must consider a whole host of things. Last, but not least, another group we certainly should consider is the Australian consumers. They are just as important, if not more important, than all the other factors I have mentioned. That is the total package that will be considered by this Government. We will not be rushed into a wrong or hurried decision. We will make a sound decision that will have a future for the Australian automotive industry, people in the servicing and distribution side of the industry, the Australian private motorist, the Australian commercial world that relies on the use of motor vehicles and Australian industry that also relies on the technology and vehicles that come from that industry. That is the decision we will make; they are the things we will consider. It will be a decision to benefit all Australians.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY TAXATION (ADMINISTRATION) AMENDMENT BILL 1981

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Howard, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill is the first of four Bills to implement further proposals relating to stamp duties and taxes imposed in the Australian Capital Territory, including Jervis Bay, that I announced in my Budget Speech on 18 August 1981.

In the statements accompanying my Budget Speech it was indicated that, following a review of the level and scope of the stamp duties and taxes imposed in the Australian Capital Territory, the Government had decided to impose two new duties in the Territory. The first is to be imposed on new life insurance effected in the Territory and the other on new and transferred motor vehicle registrations in the Territory. This Bill and three associated Bills that I shall introduce shortly, contain the provisions necessary for the imposition and collection of the two new charges.

In announcing the new taxing measures I indicated that they would apply from 1 October 1981. That remains the Government's intention and it is hoped that passage of the Bills will occur in time for the Bills to come into operation on that date. Following approval of the Bills by the Parliament they are to come into operation on the date fixed by proclamation.

I turn now to the substance of the present Bill. It will amend the Australian Capital Territory Taxation (Administration) Act 1969 to incorporate machinery provisions for the assessment, collection and recovery of the two new taxes. The scheme to be implemented to impose and collect tax on new life insurance effected in the Territory is modelled largely on the existing scheme relating to the tax on general insurance effected in the Territory. Persons who carry on a business of life insurance in the Territory will be required to register with the Commissioner of Taxation and lodge monthly returns of premiums received in respect of taxable life insurance business. Insurers will pay the amount of the tax payable in respect of that insurance but will be authorised to pass on the tax by recovering it from the persons liable for payment of premiums.

For the purposes of the new tax, life insurance falls into two broad categories. The first category relates to temporary and term life insurance. With this type of insurance, the term of the insurance is limited to a specified period and the sum insured is payable only in the event of the death, within that period, of the person whose life is insured. If the person survives that period, no amount becomes payable under the policy. Tax is to be imposed in respect of this category of life insurance at the rate of 5 per cent of the amount of the premium payable in the first year of the insurance.

The second category is life insurance other than temporary or term insurance. Included in this category is the whole of life and endowment insurance and the amount of the tax is to be calculated by reference to the sum insured. For life insurance with a sum insured greater than $2,000 the amount of tax is to be $1 plus 20c for each $200, or part thereof, of the amount of the sum insured that exceeds $2,000. Where the sum insured is between $100 and $2,000, the rate of tax will be 10c for each $200, or part thereof, of the sum insured.

Tax on life insurance will not be payable if the person whose life is insured is domiciled outside the Territory and stamp duty or other similar tax imposed by a State or other Territory has been paid in relation to that insurance. This exemption is to avoid the possibility of double taxation where a person who takes out life insurance in the Australian Capital Territory is required to pay stamp duty in a State or Territory because, for example, he or she lives in that State or other Territory. An exemption will also be provided for personnel of diplomatic missions of other countries where the other country provides a reciprocal exemption for Australian diplomatic personnel.

I turn now to the new tax to be imposed on new and transferred vehicle registrations effected in the Territory. The tax is to be imposed on the registration of all classes of vehicles, including trailers, that are registered by the Registrar of Motor Vehicles. The tax will not be imposed where the vehicle to be registered in the name of a person was last registered in that person's name in the Australian Capital Territory or elsewhere in Australia. The amount of the tax is to be calculated at the rate of $2 for each $100, or part thereof, of the market value of the vehicle. Persons seeking registrations on which tax is to be imposed will be required to state to the Registrar of Motor Vehicles the market value of the vehicle and to tender payment to the Registrar of the amount of the tax payable on the basis of that value. The Registrar will not register a vehicle if these requirements are not complied with, unless the registration sought is exempt from tax.

Exemptions from the tax will broadly follow existing exemptions from other classes of Australian Capital Territory stamp duties and taxes. Thus, vehicles registered to public hospitals, public benevolent institutions, religious institutions, public educational institutions and diplomatic missions and their personnel of reciprocating countries will not attract tax. In addition, exemption will apply to licensed motor vehicle dealers in the Australian Capital Territory in respect of vehicles held by them as trading stock for resale.

It has been decided to provide an exemption for certain disabled persons. Disabled persons who will be eligible for exemption are those who would qualify for exemption from sales tax in respect of the purchase of a new vehicle. The exemptions from stamp tax will, however, apply to both new and secondhand vehicles.

A memorandum containing more detailed explanations of the technical aspects of this Bill and the three other Bills to which I have referred is being made available to honourable members. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Dr Klugman) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY TAX (LIFE INSURANCE BUSINESS) BILL 1981

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Howard, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This is a further Bill associated with the Australian Capital Territory Taxation (Administration) Amendment Bill 1981, which I introduced a short time ago. As I indicated in speaking to that Bill, tax is to be imposed on life insurance effected in the Australian Capital Territory and the purpose of this Bill is to impose the tax, at the rates declared in the Bill, on two categories of life insurance.

Tax payable in respect of temporary or term life insurance is to be calculated at the rate of 5 per cent of the premium payable for the first year of cover. In the case of life insurance other than temporary or term insurance, the Bill will impose tax calculated by reference to the amount of the sum insured. For sums insured greater than $2,000, tax will be at the rate of $1 plus 20c for each $200, or part thereof, of the amount of the sum insured in excess of $2,000. For sums insured between $100 and $2,000, tax will be at the rate of 10c for each $200, or part thereof, of the sum insured. The Bill also makes provision for the exemptions from tax which I referred to earlier. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Hurford) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY TAX (VEHICLE REGISTRATION) BILL 1981

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY TAX (INSURANCE BUSINESS) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1981

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Howard, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Australian Capital Territory Tax (Insurance Business) Amendment Bill is the last of the Budget package of Bills in relation to stamp duties and taxes in the Australian Capital Territory. It is in consequence of the proposal to tax new life insurance effected in the Territory and its purpose is to withdraw an existing exemption from the tax on general insurance. The exemption I refer to is in respect of personal accident and sickness insurance which is undertaken solely in connection with life insurance. There is, however, no exemption for personal accident and sickness insurance not connected with life insurance. Now that it is proposed to tax life insurance effected in the Territory, there is no longer any case for retaining the limited exemption of life insurance-related accident and sickness insurance. All accident and sickness insurance effected in the Territory will now bear the tax rate that applies to general insurance. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Hurford) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Customs Tariff Proposals No. 13 (1981).

The Customs Tariff Proposals I have just tabled relate to proposed alterations to the Customs Tariff Act 1966. Proposals No. 13 (1981), which operates on and from tomorrow, contains tariff changes resulting from the Government's decisions on recommendations by the Industries Assistance Commission in its reports on Miscellaneous Manufacturing-Certain Refractory Products, and Railway and Tramway Locomotives Rolling Stock, etc. The Government has accepted the Commission's recommendations in both reports. As a result, certain refractory products such as bricks, blocks, tiles, crucibles, nozzles, et cetera, will become dutiable at a rate of 15 per cent, an increase of 7.5 per cent. The increase in assistance accorded the refractory shapes in question will reduce the disparity in assistance between these and related products. The production of refractory shapes will now receive a moderate level of assistance which will allow the local industry an opportunity to participate more in Australia's resources development.

In relation to the railway and tramway products report, the Government's decision that all goods under reference be dutiable at 20 per cent, represents a reduction in the level of protection from 30 per cent for most goods. It is an increase of 5 per cent for battery operated locomotives and most parts therefor, which is a small segment of the market. The proposed duty rate will provide this industry with assistance generally similar to that provided to the manufacturing sector as a whole, and will reduce disparities both within this industry and between it and other industries. The Government considers that the natural advantages of the local manufacturers will ensure there is no significant change in their position in the domestic market.

The Proposals also contains administrative changes to remove redundant concessional provisions in relation to tourist yachts and Papua New Guinea quota items. The provisions being removed have been unused for some time. A comprehensive summary setting out the nature of the changes has been prepared and is being circulated to honourable members. I commend the Proposals to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hurford Mr C.J.

I believe that probably will not be until next May because the Government has changed its procedures, and these validation Bills will come in only once a year rather than twice a year. The Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman), following normal procedure, merely handed me a copy of the Proposals as he rose to speak. In the meantime I can merely say that the case made by the Government is not proved because it has not had time to look at it. We will have to wait for many months after the horse has bolted until the next Customs Tariff Validation Bill comes into this place before I will be able to make a more considered speech on the subject. In the meantime I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the information of honourable members I present the report of the Industries Assistance Commission on Miscellaneous Manufacturing-Certain Refractory products. For the information of honourable members I also present the report of the Industries Assistance Commission on Railway and Tramway Locomotives, Rolling Stock, et cetera.
—I want to make a personal explanation because I claim to have been misrepresented.
—The honourable member may proceed.

—In the Canberra Times last Wednesday, the Age on Friday and the National Times on the weekend, and maybe elsewhere, an incorrect claim was made that I voted in favour of the Laurie Oakes offending Sydney Daily Mirror article being referred to the Standing Committee on Privileges. In the Age and in the National Times there was an extraordinary suggestion that I was not consistent because if I had voted that way I was taking steps at the same time to promote the Australian wine industry, and in particular the South Australian wine industry. I want to make it clear to the House that I did not vote for reference to the Privileges Committee. Even if I had done so I still would have defended my right to promote the South Australian wine industry. But the fact that I did not vote for that motion makes nonsense of the claims in the Age and the National Times. The Canberra Times corrected the mistake the next day. The Age corrected it at the first possible opportunity, and I presume the National Times also will correct the claim which is damaging to me. PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Sinclair)-by leave-agreed to:

That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent the honourable member for Mitchell moving forthwith the motion relating to the public funding of political parties of which he has given notice for the next sitting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-
(1) deplores the funding of political parties for the purposes of elections, because it reduces the funding for housing, health, education, handicapped and early childhood programs;
(2) endorses as a prerequisite the holding of referenda to allow the expression of public opinion on the funding of political parties for elections;
(3) recommends that the Commonwealth Grants Commission Act be amended to take into account election funding when examining relativities between the States for revenue sharing; and

(4) proposes that the Federal Government investigate the possibility of immediately reducing general revenue grants to States which adopt election funding by amounts equal to that spent by State Governments for funding political parties.

Right at this moment in the State of New South Wales $2m to $3m of taxpayers' funds are being set aside for the political purpose of the Australian Labor Party-to have itself re-elected to government. There is no sense of priority but just a wish to reinforce the ALP in office. Those funds could build 20 pre-schools in western Sydney. Those funds could build 10 centres for handicapped children. Those funds-$2m to $3m-could build 50 homes for welfare recipients. Those funds could pay a 4 per cent subsidy to 10,000 first home buyers. Those are the priorities of the Government of New South Wales. The Australian Labor Party has the gall to say that it amounts to only 20c per head of population. What it should be looking at is an alternative use for those funds and it should really be thinking of the needs of the State of New South Wales.

It is my belief that any State government that adopts these procedures should not be encouraged by the Commonwealth and in fact should have detriments placed against such decisions and such legislation. Those $2m to $3m could pay the salaries of 250 school aides in New South Wales, whether they be in primary schools or secondary schools. Large numbers of these people have been sacked over the last months, the State Government claiming that there has been a shortage of funds. In fact, $2m to $3m could pay the salaries of 150 nurses or community health workers. Where are the priorities of the State of New South Wales? Those funds could pay an additional $6 a week for three years to all the 31,000 nurses in the State of New South Wales. Those funds could maintain, active and operative, the casualty centre at Parramatta Hospital which is being closed by the New South Wales Minister for Health. Those funds could double the assistance to handicapped children in New South Wales in any one of the two or three really paltry programs for disadvantaged and handicapped children in that State. The fact that the funds allocated to political parties in the State of New South Wales are equal to those allocated to handicapped children's programs indicates the level of concern of the New South Wales Government.

Policies should be enough to get governments re-elected. Let them raise their own funds. Let them appeal to the community and see whether the community supports them. All that is happening in the State of New South Wales is that bad debts are being paid with taxpayers' funds. The bad debts were incurred as a result of bad management within the Australian Labor Party through successive losses at Federal elections when it sought to raise funds. It did not raise enough funds because it could not attract electoral support. Now it has tapped the till of the New South Wales Government to pay off its debts.

TALK.START.PARA: —Misappropriation.

—Misappropriation of funds, indeed. I think it is interesting to note that the first two governments to approve government support for parties seeking election were the fascist Government of Mussolini and the nazi party under Hitler. Those two governments were the first to support such a measure in a so-called democracy. Let us look at the situation in the United States of America. The United States Federal Act is about 106 pages in length and in four years there have been produced 130 pages of explanation of the regulations covering the funding of elections. What a simple system! If my colleagues opposite think the tax laws are complicated, they should look at the regulations governing public funding of political parties in the United States. They recommend that we follow in that direction, and the Australian Labor Party in New South Wales has done so.

SPEECH.PARA: Next Saturday in New South Wales there is to be an election. Honourable members may be aware of this! At the same time a referendum is to be conducted. This seems to be an ideal opportunity, to my mind, for the State Government of New South Wales to tap public opinion. There have been statements made in this House and elsewhere that 40 per cent of the population is opposed to the public funding of election campaigns. Figures available to me from substantial, recognised and reputable polls indicate that 70 per cent to 80 per cent of the population is opposed to the public funding of political campaigns. If the Australian Labor Party is interested in demonstrating that there is public acceptance, the referendum next Saturday in New South Wales is a marvellous way of finding out what the feeling of that State is, of gaining acceptance by the community, if the State Government can, and then establishing public funding of the election campaigns of political parties. Of course, the Premier of New South Wales is not prepared to go to a referendum on this matter. He is prepared to go to a referendum on all sorts of matters, but he is not prepared to go to a referendum on this matter because he knows that the figures produced by reputable polls indicate that 70 per cent of the population is absolutely opposed to the Labor Party putting its hand in the tin and funding its own election campaign.

This matter is far more important than the matters that are going before the people by way of referenda next Saturday. This issue of public funding of political parties is of the greatest significance. Let us look at the matters that are going before the people of New South Wales in the referenda. The first is a four-year term for members of parliament. That is fascinating, except that only half the work has been done by the Government in New South Wales in regard to a four-year term. It forgot to recognise-or perhaps it did not-that a four-year term, if carried at the referendum, will mean a 12-year term for members of the upper House in New South Wales. The Premier said: 'I did not really mean that at all. I meant only eight years but at some time in the future I will have to have another referendum to approve an eight-year term for members of the upper House in New South Wales'. What a ridiculous situation! Here we have a matter ready made to be put before the people in a referendum.

The other matter in the referendum is the pecuniary interests of members of parliament. In this House we have examined that matter properly and in detail. A distinguished judge has looked at the matter for Federal parliamentarians, Ministers and public servants. The Bowen report is available to every State government, should it wish to examine the matter. This Government is moving to establish measures whereby there is an alternative approach to the declaration of pecuniary interests. This alternative approach has not been examined by the Government of New South Wales and could easily be put into place without going to a referendum. Yet the Government of New South Wales refuses to go to the people to find out whether they are prepared to pay for the funding of political parties at elections. I think that is crass mistreatment and misjudgment of the people of New South Wales. I think it is a despicable and corrupt action.

I believe the New South Wales Government is seeking to create a situation where, after the declaration of the polls on Saturday and after the sources of funds are indicated by all the political parties, it will have an enemies list of those who donated funds to the Liberal Party. We can see it happening now. We can see the 60 per cent of executive committees within the Labor Party which are controlled by the union movement having access to material available to the New South Wales Government. They will say to employers and to business: 'If you keep funding the Liberal Party, you are for it. We will call stoppages and strikes and we will abuse the information that we have gained from the New South Wales Government', information which will be included on a list of enemies of the Australian Labor Party in New South Wales. It is no wonder that this type of funding first commenced in fascist Italy and in nazi Germany.

I am amazed that any political party in this great country of ours can come forward in this way and do the same thing; tap the public purse to ensure its continuation in office. What does the Australian Labor Party really expect to gain from this except the denigration of the democratic process within Australia? That will be the result. The Australian Labor Party has sought to break down the democratic process by not encouraging people to participate in political parties. It wants to have a socialised, government-run instrumentality so that eventually one would have to apply to the Government to establish a political party and receive approval for funding. That is the ultimate result of that sort of thinking. I, or any member on this side of the House, do not want to see that sort of thing spread throughout Australia or be adopted by any State governments. The only process by which this can be stopped is to have the Government of New South Wales thrown out of office next Saturday.

If the ALP really wishes to cease being a captive of the union movement-it has said that political parties should not be captive of any section of the community-the way to do it would be to change the rules. It cannot be done by having up front public declarations of where funds come from. The Liberal Party has a completely open approach to the funding of political campaigns. Not one member of this side of the House has any knowledge of how his funds are raised by the campaign and the party machine. Members do not involve themselves in that process. It is not possible for an honourable member in the Australian Labor Party to be remote from the process of raising funds for political functions. It is simple to take out the figures on the amount of money available to the union movement. For the six-month period to the end of July the Amalgamated Metalworkers and Shipwrights Union has $9m available. That union and other unions are involved in the committees of the Australian Labor Party.

I do not believe any member could avoid the pressures that would come to bear on him, first of all, by control of voting numbers and, secondly, by the power of the purse within the Australian Labor Party. The Australian Labor Party has an inbuilt destruct button. Destruction will occur if it continues to attach itself so closely to various groups in the community. The process of government funding for political parties is not the answer that the Australian Labor Party is seeking. The proper process is to dispense with such legislation. If the Australian Labor Party wants to pursue it, it should be put to the people by way of referendum to see how they react to it. I will tell honourable members what the people will do. They would rather have the pre-schools, the health workers and nurses well-paid, and the advantages of an interest subsidy for first home buyers, than the funding of political parties to run election campaigns to reinsure in office the personal will of a small section of the community or the personal will of a member of parliament or a candidate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Robbing the pensioners and the poor; misappropriation of public moneys.
—Order! The Minister for the Capital Territory is not making the speech.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, the Minister is being very helpful. I know that he feels very strongly about this. In fact, he pointed out to me that the first two parties ever to introduce this process were the fascist party of Italy and the nazi party under Hitler in Germany. The Minister is aware of where this can go. He should not be prevented from intervening in such a helpful way. If the Australian Government continues to condone the use of taxpayers' funds in this way it is an abuse of its power. I recommend-this was put forward in the motion that I have moved-that the Commonwealth Grants Commission should be instructed, by way of amendment to the legislation, to disallow those payments when it is considering the relativities between States for the funding of revenue grants. The Grants Commission can assess this. The States that are seeking funds, the moderate, well-intentioned, dynamic States of Australia that will never have any intention of seeking funds from the taxpayers-I am talking about the Liberal and National Country Party Governments of Australia--
—Western Australia.

—Certainly Western Australia, Queensland, South Australia and Victoria will never have any intention of tickling the till to get money to reinsure themselves in office. The governments in those States will gain advantage from the Grants Commission being able to take into account what has happened in New South Wales. The Commonwealth Government ought to move immediately to reduce by $3m grants to New South Wales. If New South Wales wants to throw money around like that and not provide the services for which it was elected then it should not be subsidised by the Australian taxpayer. Let it appeal to the people of New South Wales and get the money from them. If this matter were put to a referendum there would be no way in which the people of New South Wales would support it. Why should the back-door method of funding political campaigns, of using taxpayers' funds which are allocated as general purpose grants by this Parliament, be used? A decision should be taken immediately to reduce by $3m the general grants to the New South Wales Government. To ensure that this process never happens again the legislation must be changed so that the Grants Commission can ensure that this is just a mere administrative factor that operates on every occasion that any State government uses its power to subvert taxpayers' funds into the payment of political parties.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the major arguments and assess the moral difficulties many Australians face when they say: 'Part of my tax must go to the members of an opposing party to have them re-elected'. It is morally wrong that taxpayers' funds should be used in that way. Honourable members opposite should not shake their heads. Of course it is wrong. They are absolutely certain that it is wrong. Two or three members of the Australian Labor Party in the House today are trying to put on a good front of support. Where is their support for this process? The problem is that they do not believe it. They do not believe that this is a proper process for the Government of New South Wales to adopt. There has to be some sort of equality in electoral acceptance before there is a close election. It is no good saying that money will buy votes. Money for publicity, television advertising, newspaper advertising, jingles and all of those sorts of things does not get votes. The only way to get votes in this country is to have the policies, the commitment, and to be able to present oneself in such a way on a day to day basis over a three-year period so that one gets the votes and the people support the policies of one's political party. That is why the Liberal Party and the National Country Party have been so successful in the Federal Parliament. There is a day by day continual effort on behalf of the entire population of Australia. It does not involve a capacity to buy one's way in with television advertising; it involves consistently providing programs for the benefit of the people.

I think I dealt with the superfluous argument about offering information on donors when I said that an enemies list may be prepared. Let us consider an enemies list. If, in the real world, we know it is likely that the revelation of donors' names will provide marks for future intimidation, what about the possible impact if it were publicly known that a particular union supported the Australian Labor Party and that union got favoured treatment, whether or not it had anything to do with funding? How does the Australian Labor Party stand. It is the same for everyone. I think the public disclosure aspects are open to all sorts of corrupting influences. Mr Deputy Speaker, I know you share my view when I say that I believe the legislation in New South Wales is corrupt. It is corrupt to use taxpayers' funds for the purpose of having the Australian Labor Party Government re-elected.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired. Is the motion seconded?
—I have a great deal of pleasure in seconding the motion and reserve my right to speak at a later stage in this debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Klugman Dr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was interesting to hear that grandstanding from the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman). I suppose that this week the Government will try to pass a number of motions which it thinks might embarrass the New South Wales Government. It is hypocrisy for supporters of the Government to talk about deploring the funding of political parties for the purpose of elections when they have the Government Information Unit which is used purely for political purposes, during elections and between elections. It spends some millions of dollars. This year $5m was spent on the Government Information Unit. In addition hundreds of people are employed by Ministers and parliamentary members of the Liberal Party and National Country Party of Australia and are paid from the public payroll. So much for the hypocrisy about funding political parties! Crocodile tears were shed about $2m. The honourable member mentioned a figure of over $3m but the Liberal Party has been kind enough to decide that it will not accept any money from the fund. So less than $2m will be distributed in New South Wales.

SPEECH.PARA: How many other things could be done by a government which spends $40m on aeroplanes for the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser)? We were told that they were bought for security purposes. But when the Prime Minister missed the plane on which his wife and the Governor-General went to Great Britain for the Royal wedding, he went by British Airways. Apparently security was not relevant then. The $40m expenditure on the aircraft was not as essential as it was thought. Let us look at the reasons why the New South Wales Government has introduced legislation about public funding and why most democratic countries of Europe-I will give a list later-have introduced it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Russia?

—Russia does not have democratic elections. Those of us who support public funding legislation have basically four objectives: Firstly, to limit, or eliminate political corruption; secondly, to force parties to reveal their sources of income in order to clarify to the electorate what kind of interest their financial supporters represent; thirdly, to reduce the advantage that may be derived by certain groups or individuals from their command of superior financial resources; and finally, to reduce, limit, or control the cost of politics generally. I will try to come to the last point later in the debate. I note that I have five minutes less time in which to speak than the honourable member for Mitchell. When we are talking about eliminating corruption, let us think back to the days when the present Prime Minister was in Opposition and was the spokesman for labour. He and the Liberal Party were subsidised by one Keith Compton Gale, who was managing director of Gollin and Co. Ltd. He was provided with staff by Keith Compton Gale, who was later charged with fraudulently obtaining huge amounts of money from the Gollin group of companies. I think he is now serving a prison sentence of 16 years for that. He was a close associate of the Prime Minister at the time when he was a shadow Minister.
—I wish to raise a point of order.
-I warn the Minister not to take a frivolous point of order.

—Not only is it not a frivolous point of order but also since 1975 there have been frequent rulings on this specific matter in this House. If there is an imputation that the Prime Minister has been engaged in impropriety, in any way, shape or form, Mr Speaker has ruled-in relation to this matter involving Mr Gale-that the matter must be brought before the House by way of substantive motion. If the honourable member indicates that he is making no imputation against the Prime Minister then he is in order. But if he is making any imputation against the Prime Minister of Australia in respect of this matter, I point out that it has been ruled on at least six times and I suggest to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that you uphold the ruling.
—The point is taken.

—I accept the proposition that the Prime Minister at the time was unaware that Mr Gale was obtaining the money fraudulently. I am not suggesting that he knew that. Let us look at where the Liberal Party got its money from. I refer to a report of the trial of Keith Compton Gale, as reported in the Australian, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Yamamoto, a citizen of Japan and an employee of Toyomenka (a trading partner of Gollin's) for 20 years-plus, was stationed in Sydney for Toyomenka during the period February 1972-August 1975. He told the court-
This happened during the conspiracy charges-
that at one time when he was asked to call at Mr Gale's office, Mr Gale told him that he (Mr Gale) wished to make a donation of $25,000 to the Liberal party.
He said Mr Gale asked him to exchange cheques with him as ''it would be better to have a cheque from a foreigner''.

Mr Yamamoto said he gave Mr Gale a cheque for $25,000 drawn on his (Mr Yamamoto's) personal account at the ANZ Bank in Macquarie Place and Mr Gale gave him a cheque for $25,000 which he immediately deposited.
That is where the Liberal Party's money comes from.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not proven evidence.

—It is not proven evidence but it was accepted by the court. Let us be quite clear on this matter. The man was convicted. It is interesting to note that he said it would be better to have a cheque from a foreigner. I would have thought that the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) who was probably the secretary of the Party at that time, would have preferred a cheque from an Australian. But he could not get it. The honourable member for Mitchell tells us that the Australian Labor Party is in a difficult position financially. I suggest to him that the Liberal Party in New South Wales is not much better off.
—We still will not take it from the public purse.
—Fair enough. Honourable members opposite are arguing that they are in a good financial state. Last week my secretary received a letter addressed to Ms Boyce Monahan. It stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . our singular problem is finance.
I would have thought their problem was votes. It also said:
The reality of our situation is that while our prospects are the best for years, our financial state is at its worst.
The letter goes on to state:

As stated earlier, the financial position of the New South Wales Division of the Liberal Party is at its worst. Despite 'folk-lore' stories to the contrary, we have never been a wealthy Party and at present have a very heavy debt. We have to overcome this and also raise sufficient money to mount an effective election campaign.
It is a bit late for the Liberal Party, just before an election, to decide how to raise money.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope she made a donation.
—No, but she will certainly send back the self-addressed pre-stamped envelope. The important things to remember are those four points as to why it is necessary to have funding of political parties.
—What are those four points again?

—I will conclude by mentioning them again. Let us have a look at the transcript. In New South Wales there was a lengthy inquiry into the question of funding political parties. Part of the evidence which was agreed to unanimously was the overseas experience. I will quickly mention the situation in some countries. We are told by the honourable member for Mitchell that some of them are terrible countries, from a democratic point of view. The report from the Joint Committee of the Legislative Council and Legislative Assembly states:

SPEECH.PARA: 3.4.1. Arrangements for the public funding of election campaigns in the Federal Republic of Germany are enshrined in the Political Parties Act of 1967.

The system has operated in Austria since 1975. In Italy legislation was enacted in 1974. Sweden introduced the payment of subsidies to political parties in 1965. Norway has given financial support to national organisations of political parties since 1970. In Denmark legislation regarding political funding has operated since 1969. It has operated in Finland since 1967. No date is given for Israel. In Canada legislation has operated since 1974. It has operated since 1976 in the United States of America for the presidential elections, following the scandal about where Mr Nixon got the money for his election campaign. I will quote from the general summary which is agreed to by all members of a bipartisan committee.

There are a vast number of States and provinces which enjoy a system of public funding. These systems exist within national systems, sometimes as a complement, sometimes based on distinct principles. The State or provincial systems have been the trailblazers for public funding in their nation. In the United States, for example, forty-nine of the fifty States have a system of disclosure and many long preceded Congressional action on many aspects of public funding and regulation of election abuses. The provinces of Scandinavia and West Germany have impressive systems now enjoying bi-partisan support. In Austria, there are 750 municipalities funding elections through the local town halls. There are something like one thousand systems of public funding and disclosure in different political units across the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not a bipartisan report.

—No, but the factual part was agreed to by both sides, not the final recommendation. One thousand systems all over the world in democratic countries have public funding of political units. It is quite ridiculous to argue that, in some way, it is an undemocratic thing to do. Whilst the United Kingdom does not have an extensive system of funding, in fact, it has significant funding. I will come to that in a minute. I will quote from a book written in 1972, which is quite some time ago. The New York Times correspondent, Anthony Lewis, writing from his post in London in 1970, wrote in his article 'From the Vantage Point of Europe':

SPEECH.PARA: American permissiveness on money and politics seems almost Roman in its decadence. The thought of allowing politicians to sell themselves in spot advertisements on television would be revolting in Britain or anywhere in the established European democracies . . .
I hope that honourable members who disagree about public funding agree at least with that basic proposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?
—Anthony Lewis, writing from London for the New York Times in 1970 said that. The article continued:

SPEECH.PARA: European and other modern democratic nations have had to wrestle with the same problems of escalating political campaign costs and the degradation of the democratic dialogue we have experienced in the United States. In general they have been much more successful that we have in controlling costs and upholding the level of campaigns.

I think it is important to remember that all over the world people who basically believe in democracy and who basically believe in the effectiveness of elections believe that there ought to be public funding of election campaigns. There has been scandal after scandal. I have mentioned already the case involving Gale and the Liberal Party and the $25,000. The previous leader of the Liberal Party in New South Wales, John Mason, very prominently announced, though he never took it up while still leader, that he was offered either $1,000 or $5,000 per week-I have forgotten how much, although it was a huge amount of money-in order to keep casinos illegal. We are told also by the honourable member for Mitchell that the Liberal Party members of parliament do not involve themselves in the processes of collecting money for election campaigns. Let me quote from the Sydney Morning Herald of 12 September 1981, in which there was a write-up about the troika of the National Country Party. It stated:
a liberal minister who canvassed funds in Melbourne before the 1977 election found that Nixon--
The Minister for Primary Industry-
had beaten him to most of the likely contributors. 'He didn't leave anything for the Liberal Party,' the minister laments.

All over the world in democratic countries there is a trend towards the public funding of political campaigns. I was going to quote an instance in France but I will not have time to do that. I think it is terribly important to remember that the Federal Government's only power in relation to this matter is that it can introduce free television and broadcasting time during election campaigns, for political parties on some fair and acceptable basis. The honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock), who will follow me in this debate, asked me to repeat the four propositions that should govern the funding of political parties. They are:
1. To limit or, ideally, to eliminate corruption.
2. To force parties to reveal their sources of income in order to clarify to the electorate what kind of interests their financial supporters represent.
3. To reduce the advantage that may be derived by certain groups or individuals from their command of superior financial resources.
4. To reduce, limit or control the costs of politics generally.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take issue with the honourable member for Prospect (Dr Klugman) in strongly supporting this motion. I do so by looking at the points that the honourable member for Prospect has enunciated as being worthy of gathering support for the opposition to the proposition that the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) has moved and which I support. The motion states:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-
(1) deplores the funding of political parties for the purposes of elections, because it reduces the funding for housing, health, education, handicapped and early childhood programmes;
(2) endorses as a prerequisite the holding of referenda to allow the expression of public opinion on the funding of political parties for elections;
(3) recommends that the Commonwealth Grants Commission Act be amended to take into account election funding when examining relativities between the States for revenue sharing, and

(4) proposes that the Federal Government investigate the possibility of immediately reducing general revenue grants to States which adopt election funding by amounts equal to that spent by State Governments for funding political parties.

This motion deals with the way in which the principle ought to be implemented, and that is by way of a referendum when people have had an opportunity to express a genuine point of view on whether an election should be publicly funded or not. It recommends also ways and means whereby this Government and this Parliament might express a point of view on the rather hypocritical way in which the New South Wales Government has cried poor mouth on the one hand and, on the other hand, has delved into the public purse to fund its election campaign on this occasion.

I simply draw to people's attention the sorts of statements that were made not so long ago by the Premier of New South Wales. At the Premiers Conference, he was quite prepared to launch a vigorous attack on the new tax sharing deal with the claim that New South Wales was left short of funds. He was vicious in his comments. I draw the attention of honourable members to a headline which appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald on Tuesday 5 May which stated 'Hospitals and schools will suffer'. He was as much aware as we are of what happens when one starts to fritter money away on frivolous exercises such as this at a time when it is not all that easy for State governments. He was as much aware as we in this House are of the nature of the expenses that are involved in the public funding of elections and the extent to which the State will be limited in meeting other demands.

In Parramatta, the area from which the honourable member for Prospect and I come, there is a hospital which we are to lose shortly. We will lose it because the State claims that it does not have sufficient funds. That is the fact of the matter. It is threatening to close down casualty wards in hospitals all over the State. The expenditure of $2m by the State Government would keep some of those casualty wards open. We hear complaints about the State Government having to charge fees in psychiatric hospitals. An amount of $2m would make a significant dent in that area. We have heard complaints about the need, on the State Government's part, to reduce its expenditure contributions to child care. Yet $2m would have a significant impact in that area and garner for the State additional public funds which would enable those facilities to be expanded and recurrent expenditure to be met.

The family day care programs have been cut down. We have heard the same claim that the Government does not have sufficient funds for schools. In the area in which the honourable member for Prospect lives-it is quite close to my own area-the schools at Burnside and Oaklands have lost staff. The school at Burnside, which is just around the corner from the honourable member's home, is likely to close. These facilities are at risk, and teachers and support staff are likely to be lost because the State Government claims that it has insufficient funds. We have seen the sorts of promises that are made in relation to first home buyers. Just imagine how much further they could be extended if the State Government used the funds that were available from this source to supplement those funds that are already available.

We have seen the situation in which police stations have been put on part time roster. What a disgraceful state of affairs. Just around the corner from the home of the honourable member for Prospect at Ermington we have a police station operating part time; police cannot be mustered because the Government is not prepared to make available sufficient funds to keep that station open. These are the sorts of events that have been taking place in New South Wales over the last few years under this New South Wales Government while it has frittered money away on such matters as the public funding of election campaigns. That is not the half of it.

The honourable member for Prospect sought by way of rebuttal of the proposition put by the honourable member for Mitchell to look at a number of expenditure items of this Government. He raised, firstly, the issue of the Government Information Unit; secondly, the question of Ministers' staff; and, thirdly, the overseas obligations of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) as the principal representative of this country. I take the same argument that the honourable member has raised and put it in the context of New South Wales. Does the honourable member for Prospect seriously want us to look at that other expenditure item which I was not proposing to raise in this debate; that is, the Premier's own information unit, his important publicity machine which has been used to promote his image in New South Wales? In the Premier's Department we have these vital public servants: Five special advisers, one chief Press secretary, four research officers and two assistants, one advertising manager, two journalists, one videotape editor, one videotape technician, an officer in charge of the ministerial Press office, a second in charge of the ministerial Press office and 18 ministerial Press officers.

TALK.START.PARA: —What do they all do?

—Well, I cannot imagine what they all do. But one can see from the nature of some of the publicity-I will come to that shortly-what some of them have been doing in preparing for this election campaign at public expense. The fact of the matter is that on top of those people that I have mentioned, the State Government employs at public expense ministerial staff for Ministers in New South Wales. I did not complain about that. On top of that the Premier of New South Wales goes overseas from time to time. They were the matters of rebuttal raised by the honourable member for Prospect. They have absolutely no validity at all in relation to the Federal Government. If they had they would have even greater validity in relation to New South Wales where not only are people employed to undertake a proper job but also there is an extravagance in terms of the number of people who have been brought to bear to try to create an image for the Premier of New South Wales.

SPEECH.PARA: We are dealing in this debate with the issue of public funding of election campaigns. The honourable member for Prospect endeavoured to say that there was not a great deal of money involved in this, that it was an important point of principle and that we ought to recognise that there was some justice in this proposal because it would enable advantages-I think that is the word the honourable member used-which might be gained from obtaining funds from private sources to be removed from a particular party. I must say that what worries me is the advantage that has been gained by the particular party in government in New South Wales as a result of the public funding proposals and the way in which that party uses the power of political office.

I want to gather together the costs to the taxpayers of New South Wales not only in terms of the Budget appropriation item of $2.1m for simply running the scheme and paying the amounts involved to the Australian Labor Party but also the additional costs from the nature of the bureaucracy that has been set up in New South Wales for the purposes of administering this Act. It has to be recognised that significant costs are involved in establishing and maintaining an election funding authority. They are the costs of meetings and the payment of members and alternates who have to sit on the authority. There is the cost of research and publication that is involved in the work of the authority, the cost of maintaining registers, the administrative costs of allocating subsidies and recording disclosures. There are the additional costs of course, of by-elections if they have to be held. There will be legal costs associated with the management of this authority, the accounting and auditing costs of the authority, the costs of staffing the authority, the cost of hiring consultants, the cost of hiring inspectors and carrying out inspections in every political office in New South Wales-that is, not just the principal office of the parties but all of the offices that are involved-and the indirect costs to parties of meeting those legal, recording and auditing requirements. They are significant costs which are not recorded in that one line appropriation but which will have to be met by the taxpayers of New South Wales. It ought to be understood what is involved. It is not just the funding of the Labor Party that is involved; there is also the additional funding associated with the very management of this complex and difficult system that has been established.

I come to the most reprehensible conduct of all in relation to the election campaign in New South Wales. We have seen not only a situation in which the Government of New South Wales is using millions of dollars of taxpayers' money to fund the Labor Party out of its past debts and to fund its present campaign but also the most slick, clever and dirty advertising program involving a State government and the use of State government instrumentalities. What we have seen is a series of government advertisements-not advertisements paid for by public funding but advertisements paid for directly out of the public purse. They are tremendously costly to the people of New South Wales. All of them are blatantly biased and deliberately touting the image of the Premier of New South Wales.

We have seen the arguments to support the two referenda proposals which Mr Wran has put up in New South Wales. I have here an advertisement which has been in many newspapers and which has also been repeated on television. It is headed 'A longer term for Parliament makes a lot of good sense'. I am reading from the one which appeared in the Daily Telegraph of Friday, 11 September. It deals with the question of a four-year term for the Parliament. It deals with the question of disclosure by parliamentarians of their financial interests. It goes on to say that those are good proposals.

Nobody would mind the arguments being put forward, particularly as they are supported by the Opposition and the Government, but what one notices is that one sees the glowing countenance of the Premier of New South Wales-the same campaign photograph that is appearing in every political advertisement made by the Labor Party. The advertisement states: 'If you approve, Vote Yes to Both Bills'. The fact of the matter is that if this were to be done in an even-handed way one would, of course, put a photograph of both the Government and Opposition leaders, but that is not to be the case. The fact of the matter is that over a period that has not been the only exercise which has been run out of the public purse and which has promoted the Labor Party's image. We have seen further advertisements. I produce the Daily Telegraph of Saturday, 5 September, advertising Carnivale 81.

TALK.START.PARA: —Another full page.

—Another full-page ad. Whose glowing countenance do we see in that advertisement sponsored by the New South Wales Government but the same Premier's. I could go through numerous situations where government advertisements with the Premier's photograph all over them are being used to advertise the Premier immediately before an election. These advertisements that we have seen have been produced by the Department of Industrial Development and Decentralisation, the Electricity Commission of New South Wales, the Department of Attorney-General and Justice and the Housing Commission of New South Wales. As well we have the railway advertisements which have the little sing-along ditty that public funding did not have to pay for and which promotes the Government's so-called achievements in public transport. This is the way in which the Labor Party in office seeks to advantage itself.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to give the House some details of the cost involved to the people of New South Wales. We have seen $576,000 spent on the Labor Party's election campaign on Sydney television. On country television we have seen over $300,000 spent as well as money spent advertising on radio, in the metropolitan Press and the country Press. The total is probably of the order of $1,199,000. The Labor Party claims that its campaign will cost $1.1m, of which it expects public funding to pay for $750,000. The Labor Party will get that amount from the central fund but in addition it will get of the order of $375,000 from the electorate fund for Labor Party candidates. We have a situation in which the Government's advertising-I have dealt with this matter in the debate-will cost something in the order of $1.25m. The referendum advertising, which is heavily slanted towards the Labor Party and Mr Wran, will cost over $1m. If these sums are added to the amount which I have suggested is being spent on the Labor Party's campaign, we see something of the order of $3,350,000 of public funds being spent on promoting the Labor Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am concerned about the cynical abuse of the forms, the time and the purposes of this Parliament in a motion of this kind, notice of which was given only this morning, being brought forward this afternoon. The purpose of the motion, of course, is quite apparent. Its purpose is to attempt to get some benefit from this issue for the coalition parties in New South Wales at next Saturday's election. In that election the coalition parties will be slaughtered, and honourable members on the Government benches in this House know that that is so. It was my privilege to be on the side of the Premier of New South Wales and supporting the Government in New South Wales for two years before I became a member of this Parliament. The people in New South Wales will vote sensibly next Saturday, as they did on previous occasions, because they know that the members of the New South Wales Government are honest and honourable men. I stop short of extending that same compliment to members of the Opposition in New South Wales, for good and sufficient reasons which I may or may not have time to develop this afternoon.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. Is it proper to impugn the character and reputation of members of another Parliament?
—Order! This has been a very wide-ranging debate. I think the honourable member for Mitchell is a little sensitive. There is no point of order.

—On occasions such as this I wish that the operation of the Parliament was televised. I draw to the attention of those people who are listening to the proceedings on their radios the fact that there has been considerable hilarity on the part of Government members about this matter. In fact, when the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) was moving this motion initially those honourable members who were sitting on the Government side were giggling like school children. They knew the purpose for which the motion was introduced and they were taking some strange, distorted form of relish from the procedures that were taking place.

SPEECH.PARA: The people in New South Wales are aware of the fact that this decision by the New South Wales Government, which has now been implemented, represents another very substantial step forward in the great traditions of democratising society. For example, we could go back to the claims that were made by the Chartists. One of their claims, one of their demands, was payment for members of parliament. Prior to that there was no opportunity for ordinary members in the community to represent constituents within the national and State legislatures. On that occasion, all the forces of privilege within Western societies fought as strongly as they possibly could to prevent the claims and the demands of the Chartists being achieved, but they were achieved. As I have said, this provision is another step forward in the democratisation of parliamentary institutions and procedures in Australia, because we are lagging years behind so many other advanced industrial Western societies.

Is there any substantial difference between the Government funding the operation of an electoral booth to make it possible for people to cast a sensible vote and funding the projection and promotion of policies by political parties to make it possible for the electors to come to some sensible and reasoned decision? This is the issue which fundamentally concerns members of the Government. They know that as a result of the dirty little deals they do in back rooms, getting together the massive funds which are at their disposal, they are able to embark on massive advertising campaigns. Often they are corrupt and lying advertising campaigns, such as we had in the last election. The Government deliberately misrepresented and distorted a question of capital gains tax when it said that the Australian Labor Party, of all parties, a social democratic party, would contemplate taxing people on the basis of their own homes. Yet that lie was perpetuated. The Government persisted with it, and unfortunately sufficient numbers of people in Australia were confused by it. For that reason it was a very smart political act, a very smart political trick. Of course, the Goverment had the sorts of funds necessary to finance that type of campaign.

It is extraordinary that this motion should be brought into the House in the last week of the election campaign when it has not even become an issue in New South Wales. The Liberal leader, Mr McDonald, has refused to raise it because of his own seedy record in respect of fund raising. For his own election campaigns he and his State electorate council participated in organising dirty little illegal gambling fiascos in back sheds in some of the suburbs of his electorate. That is on record. Is it preferable that funds for political parties be raised in such a way? That is the position the Government and spokesmen for the Government are adopting in relation to this question. The Liberals prefer funds to be raised at gambling nights and as a result of deals they do with companies. Do they deny that in 1977 substantial funds were given to them by IMB Australia Ltd which brought about a reconsideration of tenders for computer contracts, or that recent changes to the Broadcasting and Television Act were brought about by payments made to the Liberal Party by Rupert Murdoch? Is that denied by them? The National Country Party is also in the pay of multinational companies.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. The honourable member is making allegations which could be identified with particular Ministers in particular actions of the Government and, therefore, should be the basis of a motion if the honourable member wishes to continue with them.
—Order! No specific person has been named, although the language was rather unparliamentary. I warn the honourable member for Hunter not to follow that line any more.
—Thank you for your advice, Mr Deputy Speaker. I would appreciate your assistance in having these frivolous points of order reduced.

—I raise a point of order. Mr Deputy Speaker, it was not a frivolous point of order you just had before you, and mine is not. The question I wish you to rule on is whether the honourable member can continue to put rhetorical questions which demand an answer from me and which I would like to answer right now. Quite frankly, I have no knowledge of the funding of the political party to which I belong. It is unfair in a rhetorical question to ask me to reply.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—It is quite obvious that I am saying things which can be substantiated. Perhaps they bite a little deeply for members of the Government, and they should bite deeply. Members of the Government should be hanging their heads in shame about the history of corrupt funding of the parties to which they belong. The Liberal and National Country parties wish to see this process continue. The Labor Party does not deny that substantial funds come to it from the trade union movement. We are proud of those funds. We are proud that we can accept the funds that come to us from organisations which support the Labor Party. We are not involved in the sorts of dirty little back room deals that members of the National Country Party and Liberal Party are involved in.
—Why did you leave?

—That is another frivolous point, but I would like that point to be made. I chose to come into this Parliament; I resigned from the New South Wales Parliament. Some members who sit on the Government side of the House came here after having been defeated in the New South Wales Parliament. One of them is even a former Leader of the Opposition. The same thing will happen to the present Leader of the Opposition in New South Wales this Saturday. He will be done like a dinner.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia is the only advanced industrial democracy, with the exception of Great Britain, that does not have a working system of public funding of the political process. In Britain the Labour Government was looking to implement the Houghton committee of inquiry report which recommended public funding for British elections.
