The Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) has described, as have other members on the Government side, the New South Wales legislation as corrupt. Perhaps when he parades on the world stage as a statesman he tells President Reagan that he was elected under a corrupt system because his election was funded by public funds. Does the Prime Minister tell Mr Trudeau in Canada that he was elected under a corrupt system because Canada's elections are funded by public funds at all levels of government? Does he tell Chancellor Schmidt in West Germany that he was elected under a corrupt system? Does he tell President Mitterrand in France that he was elected under a corrupt system? And so the list goes on. Australia is lagging behind in one of the most important steps in democratic development that was undertaken by so many other advanced countries so long before.

The cost of this proposal in New South Wales is only 22c per elector per annum, the cost of the postage stamp before the most recent increase. The total cost is less than $2.2m. If we are to talk about spending priorities, the Budget that the Parliament is in the process of considering indicates that during the last 12 months the international tourist who masquerades as the Prime Minister in this Parliament spent in excess of $5m out of the taxpayers' pockets to fund his overseas jaunts. The honourable member for Prospect (Dr Klugman) has already said that the Prime Minister spent $40m for two VIP jets, yet he went to the Royal Wedding in London on a commercial flight. In addition, $5m has been spent on the Fraser Government's Government Information Unit which is now on public record as having been used for party political purposes. What about the $150m cutback that this Government imposed on the New South Wales Government in hospital funding.

The Liberals are not concerned about public funding as an issue. They are concerned about the provisions of the law that relate to disclosure. The law will mean that any candidate who receives more than $200 will have to disclose its source. any party which, at a general level, receives a donation of more than $1,000 will have to disclose its source. The Liberals do not want to acknowledge that they receive large donations from oil companies and the National Country Party does not want to acknowledge that it receives large donations from mining companies. In the McPherson by-election the National Country Party spent more money than the Australian Labor Party is spending on the whole State election campaign in New South Wales. This motion refers particularly to the need for a referendum to be held on this question. The greatest referendum that can be held will be held next Saturday. We know what the results will be. I have already said that the people of New South Wales will reaffirm the wise political decision they made on the previous occasion. The Wran Government will be re-elected. One of the issues that will exercise the minds of people in New South Wales is public funding.

If the people in New South Wales want to ensure that adequate funds are available to all political parties, to make sure that their funding comes from on top of the table, not from dirty deals under the table and that the sources of funds available to political parties are adequately disclosed so that the electors themselves know where the funds are coming from and where the perks may otherwise have been going to and if the electors in New South Wales reendorse, as they will, the Wran Government next Satuday, they will endorse a most significant step forward in the democratisation of New South Wales. When this Government and this Parliament have the same courage and concern to introduce this measure it will be a major step forward in the democratisation of the Commonwealth.
Question put:
That the motion (Mr Cadman's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: (Budget Debate)
Debate resumed from 10 September, on motion by Mr Howard:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I continue my speech on the Budget by again emphasising that Government members quote selective statistics in a dishonest attempt to portray Australia as a dynamic and prosperous country. Nowhere is such dishonesty more evident than in the area of unemployment. I repeat my question to the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr N. A. Brown): What will happen to the young first offenders referred to the Knox Community Youth Support Scheme group by local police and magistrates? The answer is stark and tragic; obviously they will end up in a penal institution. The Minister's claim that the young people displaced from CYSS will be accommodated by the new training schemes is just not true. Apart from the fact that the new training programs are not sufficiently extensive to provide places for the young people from CYSS, why destroy a scheme which has been so valuable in providing opportunities for personal and social development for unemployed youth? The decision to abolish CYSS was inhumane and the abrupt closure of the scheme on 31 October is also causing great uncertainty for both the CYSS project officers and the young people who rely on their help. I urge the Minister to reinstate the scheme. I can only hope that the newspaper reports are true and that, as a result of the overwhelming appeals from all over Australia, the Treasurer (Mr Howard) is also considering reinstatement of the scheme. Another inhumane decision was the failure of the Government to increase the unemployment benefit of $36 per week for under 18-year-olds. It is an appallingly inadequate amount for young people who live away from home and those from the country, being $37 per week below the poverty line.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn now to the area of health where the total Commonwealth Budget outlay is $4,023m-an increase of 10.2 per cent over the outlay for 1980-81. This increase hides the sheer incompetence of a government which ended the widely popular and equitable universal health scheme of Medibank despite a promise to retain it. The William Angliss Hospital is the only public hospital in La Trobe and it ended the year with a deficit which will have to be carried into the next financial year. Unless the William Angliss Hospital receives additional funding, there is no doubt that increasingly it will have to restrict its services to the public. Such a restriction obviously will not concern the Government as it is attempting to compel the States to impose means tests in their public hospitals. Another appalling aspect of health care is the withdrawal of support for community health centres, a withdrawal which has been encouraged by the health policies of this Government. It is disgraceful that there are no community health centres in my electorate where there are over 1,430 people to every medical practitioner in comparison with 580 people to every medical practitioner in inner Melbourne. With community health funding virtually entirely absorbed in the block grants to the States, the future for community health is exceedingly bleak. The Minister for Health (Mr MacKellar) has had the audacity to claim that the new health scheme is a responsible scheme. Does the Minister consider that it is responsible to introduce what amounts to a compulsory health insurance levy which will cost many families up to $11 extra per week? It is a flat rate tax in disguise which instead of being paid to the Government, is going straight to private health funds. Perhaps the Minister means that it is responsible to introduce a health scheme which is so complex that many pensioners and chronically ill patients are uncertain whether they are entitled to a Pensioner Health Benefit Card. The truth is that the new health scheme is confusing and archiac, and charges from the Minister that the Opposition is not dealing with the substance of the new arrangements are nonsensical, if not downright dishonest.

Social security is another area where the Budget provisions indicate a blatant disregard by the Government for the people who are in greatest need. Both the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) and the previous Minister have claimed that pensioners are ensured social justice under the provisions of their Government. Whilst it is true that pension rates increase in line with the movement of the consumer price index, it is also a fact that the increase lags six months behind the June and December CPI figures. By the use of this skinflint accounting procedure the Government saves about $90m this year at the expense of pensioners. It is estimated that last year this lag in the increase cost pensioner couples $172. Does the Minister consider that this represents social justice? Another skinflint policy of the Government is the imposition of the means test on the over 70s who were free of means-tested pensions in 1978. Those who cannot pass the test are now receiving $18.25 less per week than other pensioners.

It seems to me that the Minister is out of touch with the people. He needs to get out in the electorates and to talk to the community support groups. The volunteers who work in the welfare agencies, particularly those who provide emergency relief, are stretched to the limit and both financially and physically are reaching breaking point. Each day thousands of people throughout the country are crying out for emergency assistance to prevent family breakdowns, starvation, untreated disease, eviction and violence. For these people there is the daily fear that they will not be able to obtain the basic necessities of life of food, shelter and clothing. The claim by the Minister for Social Security that the Government is assisting those in greatest need rings hollow in the ears of those people working in the welfare agencies. In my electorate the number of people in need has increased steadily over the past five years. There was an increase of over 20 per cent last year. Members of the Maroondah Upper Yarra Valley support team which co-ordinates emergency relief agencies in the outer eastern region of Melbourne have recently conveyed their concern to me regarding the lack of adequate emergency relief funds. Income security and maintenance is a responsibility of the Commonwealth Government and a comprehensive income security system must include the provision of adequate emergency relief funds as a necessary component of the system.

Another aspect of social security which I want to mention concerns the initiatives provided for disabled people. The program of aids for disabled people announced recently by the Minister for Health, to cost $2.4m, is woefully inadequate. Victoria is to get only $600,000. This amount is a disgrace in a year which is the International Year of Disabled Persons. Even in the overall Budget there is still no real recognition by the Commonwealth Government that disability carries extra cost which must be compensated for if disabled people are to have equal opportunities in our society.

Finally in the area of social security is the failure of the Budget to provide much-needed funds for children's services. There is a particular concern in the municipalities of my electorate which contains a high proportion of young children and young parents. In the city of Knox, 80 per cent of the population in 1976 was under 40 years of age. At a recent meeting of outer eastern region municipalities, a number of municipality representatives expressed to me their deep concern at the lack of government funding for pre-school and infant welfare centres. The levels of subsidy assistance are just not keeping pace with the escalation in costs and the population growth of a rapidly developing area. There is no hope in this Budget for the young parents in my electorate, as the Minister has made it clear that there will be no money for new programs and services next year.

Housing is another area of this Budget which gives no hope for people in need. Two-thirds of the people in the electorate of La Trobe are buying their own homes, but with crippling interest rates of at least 12 1/2 per cent they are finding it increasingly difficult to meet their mortgage repayments and their other day to day commitments. High interest rates are a product of the overall economic policy of the Government. The Treasurer has estimated that there will be an inflow of $7,000m in 1981-82. He claims that this money is being used for resource development, but based on our experience of 1980-81 it can be anticipated that three-quarters of this inflow will be entirely speculative in nature; it will be speculation in real estate, in the share market and in the exchange rate.

Some foreign money has been used also for the takeover of Australian businesses. The Government, in order to make room for this inflow, is holding down the domestic supply. In consequence, with the high demand for funds from business corporations and semi-government authorities, interest rates are rising. It is the lack of government control of foreign investment which is causing home buyers to be crippled with increasing interest rate rises. The Federal Government has withdrawn from its housing responsibilities, and this is particularly evident in the area of public housing. The Budget shows that Federal housing expenditure has been reduced from 1.9 per cent in 1974-75 to 1 per cent of total Budget outlays in 1981-82. This is an appalling record, and, to cap it all, the imposition of the 2 1/2 per cent sales tax on building materials and furnishings could add up to $1,000 to the price of establishing a home.

Education is another area of this Budget which indicates the user pays policies of the Government; policies which are creating two classes of people in Australia-on the one hand the privileged users who have the money to pay for the best in health, education, housing and transport, and on the other hand the underprivileged who do not have the ability to pay and who must rely on government facilities to provide them with welfare, health and education. The Budget figures point the way quite clearly, with the 1982 general recurrent grant for government schools stabilising at $269.2m but the general recurrent grant for non-government schools increasing by 11 per cent to $414.1m. That is in spite of the fact that 77.7 per cent of our nation's children attend government schools and only 22.3 per cent attend private schools. These figures indicate a deliberate transfer of recurrent funds from public to private education. The allocations of capital grants indicate the same pattern, with a cut of 5 per cent for the government schools capital program in 1982. This latest cut means that the total government schools capital program has been cut by 36 per cent since 1976.

Let me translate these figures into the realities of the education scene in my electorate. Many of the schools are operating in portable and other sub-standard classrooms, and those school buildings which are comparatively new are now being badly affected by the lack of maintenance funds for the undertaking of essential repairs. In addition, many small primary schools are unable to offer adequate classes in art, physical education, music and library studies because of the absence of specialised staff. Cutbacks have been made in the provision of emergency teachers, and this has resulted in the cancellation of many school camps and excursions. In some cases there has also been a cancellation of classes.

Having dealt briefly with some of the educational problems in my electorate, I shall now refer to one of the most irresponsible of decisions made by the razor gang-that is, the decision that nine colleges of advanced education in Victoria are to be consolidated by 17 August, or are to have their funding cut completely. This decision was made without any educational or financial rationale, apparently in the blind belief that wholesale amalgamations will save money. It is a decision which has thrown staff, students and educational planners into a state of chaos. It seems that now, indicating the typical ad hoc planning of the Government, the Minister for Education (Mr Fife) has recognised the enormity of this blunder, and at the last minute has backed down. The colleges will be financed for another 12 months from a special trust fund. The colleges are now left in a position of insecurity, still under financial threat but with a breathing space of 12 months. This situation must severely undercut any commitment to long term planning and educational efficiency in Victoria. Educational forecasters have been presenting clear evidence for some time that there are already teacher shortages in the areas of maths and science in Victoria. The shortfall in the total number of Victorian teachers in 1982 will be at least 600, rising to 1,400 in 1984-hardly an appropriate educational climate to threaten and financially undermine our teacher training institutions!

At this point I mention the precarious situation of the Melbourne State College. This College has a reputation for excellence and is an institution which arts students choose before Monash University, La Trobe University or Deakin University. Entrance scores on Higher School Certificate results also are consistently higher than those of the three universities. The College is more frequently nominated as the most preferred institution by diploma of education students than any other Melbourne college or university. The threat to the security and integrity of this College, by the acceptance by the Government of the ill-conceived advice of the razor gang, represents just another example of the Government's sacrifice of the education and social needs of the community.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is typical.

—As the honourable member says, it is typical of the Government's attitude towards education and many other areas of policy. Another Victorian institution under threat is the Victorian College of Pharmacy, which is threatened with a 14 per cent cut in recurrent funding. Pharmacy is a high cost course since it has a high component of practical work in each of the biological, physical and chemical sciences. By so significantly reducing the recurrent funding available, the Victorian pharmacy student will be severely disadvantaged educationally compared with his or her counterpart in other States. A reduction in funding of this magnitude must inevitably lead to a lowering of standards of both education and, eventually, the practice of pharmacy in the State of Victoria.

SPEECH.PARA: The shortsightedness of this proposal is illustrated by a consideration of the activities of this College. Self-help-a virtue extolled by the Government-on the part of the College has led to the formation of an academic interface company, the Institute of Drug Technology Ltd, which is self-funding and provides a surplus to the College for supplementing research funding. This company employs its own staff and has carried out projects which include the manufacture, under State licence, of two drugs for human use, a synthetic drug candidate research program and an analysis of 2,4,5-T residues in streams and rivers. Work in this area, which contributes directly to the community, will be affected by the large cut in recurrent funding for the Victorian College of Pharmacy over the next triennium. This will be due to a reduction in standards of the College staff and a failure of industrial pharmacists to recognise potential problems with which the Institute could be of assistance. Thus, the Institute of Drug Technology Ltd, which maintains the utilisation of College resources, will return a lower surplus for use by the College.

In the time I have had available I have endeavoured to draw to the attention of the House the major deficiencies of this most heartless Budget. I reiterate that Government Ministers and members deliberately manipulate statistical information in the debates in this House in order to present an entirely false picture of the Australian people enjoying an unparalleled period of prosperity and security. One has only to conduct interviews with any group of electors in the capital cities of Australia to discover that they are highly critical of the policies and attitudes of the Government. It is a government which has demonstrated, by the razor gang decisions and by a series of heartless and depressing Budgets, that it completely lacks a sense of social justice. We have a Prime Minister who rightfully has been called the Robin Hood of the wealthy and the privileged; he robs the poor to help the rich. In the areas of employment, health, social security and education, the Government is following policies which must intensify the problems of rising living costs for the average Australian family. With the additional burden of rising interest rates, the impact of health insurance costs and the massive increase in sales taxes, this irresponsible Budget will add many more Australians to the ranks of the three million people who are presently classified as disadvantaged.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hicks Mr N.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I regard the Budget now before the House as a document that has been prepared with the long term welfare of Australia in mind. As with most responsible Budgets, no doubt it has displeased a number of people within the community but I am hopeful that its implementation will result in a reduction in interest rates, which rates are presently plaguing young home buyers, and will assist in the control of inflation. However, it is no use the Federal Government bringing in a Budget which reduces borrowing if the State governments do not follow suit. Although I regard the Budget as a responsible document, there are a few matters about which I would like to comment as they are of considerable importance to my electorate and, no doubt, to other electorates throughout Australia. The order in which I place these matters is no reflection on their comparative importance.

SPEECH.PARA: In my short experience in the Parliament I have encountered few organisations that show such a depth of understanding of what they are about or as much concern for their cause as the Isolated Children and Parents Association. Whilst it has been in operation for only 10 years, very few other groups would have such a comprehensive overview of education within Australia and of the problems of educating young people living in the isolation of the outback. Because of its work in bringing to the Government's notice its problems, the Government has over a number of years provided basic allowances free of a means test for eligible students who are boarding away from home, studying by correspondence or living in a second family home close to school facilities.

The scheme also covers children regarded as isolated for reasons of medical or social disability. It is pleasing, therefore, to see that as from the beginning of 1982 the level of family income above which allowances are reduced will be increased by 7 per cent and 14 per cent in regard to additional boarding and special supplementary allowances respectively. In addition the special supplementary allowance for eligible senior secondary students will be increased by 10 per cent. It is estimated that the scheme will cost $16.7m in 1981-82 compared with $14.5m in 1980-81, and that assistance will be provided for 19,170 children. The Government will be introducing a three-year pilot program costing about $4m to provide on loan video facilities to certain isolated students and communities. The advent of the communications satellite will provide another facility for education besides its other roles of communication and the provision of entertainment. It is to be hoped that the ground signal receiving equipment will be made available to people in isolated areas at a reasonable cost, as they already pay dearly for telephone and power charges-where they are available.

Personally speaking, I was disappointed by the announcement of the cessation of the Community Youth Support Scheme, as in my electorate there are CYSS projects operating in Griffith, Leeton and Deniliquin and all are doing an excellent job for the young unemployed. It was comforting to hear of the greatly increased expenditure in job training schemes for the young unemployed and of the assurance given by the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr N. A. Brown) that officers of his Department will be visiting all CYSS projects before 1 October to ensure that these people presently catered for by CYSS will be appropriately cared for. This is particularly important in areas where there are no technical college facilities or there are geographical disabilities. The Minister's assurance of his flexibility in this matter is greatly appreciated.

Despite the misgivings of a small minority of Government members and the doubts expressed by some members of the Opposition about the scheme, I feel it has served a useful purpose and I know that I would be expressing the sentiments of my colleagues in the Parliament in thanking the various project officers and community groups for their work and concern. In fact, one of the great merits of the scheme is the way in which communities have become involved. It was pleasing to read in this morning's Press that CYSS still has a chance of survival but, as the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs indicated in the House today, the outlook is not as optimistic as the media would have us hope. I am sure many of my colleagues would welcome a scheme similar to CYSS if CYSS must close, as they all feel strongly for those young unemployed in their areas who have particular problems that the normal education and work training systems cannot overcome.

The Government's $225m funding program for 1980 to 1983 for aged or disabled persons' accommodation was implemented under the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Act 1954 and the Aged Persons Hostels Act 1972. This money has been contributed, in the case of the Aged or Disabled Persons Act, on a $2 for $1 basis to a maximum limit of $12,100 for single unit accommodation or $14,035 for a double unit plus a maximum of $1,920 per unit for land costs, and may be made to religious and charitable organisations and to local government bodies to meet the costs of erection, extension or purchase of those homes. The expenditure is estimated at $45.6m in 1981-82. Under the Aged Persons Hostels Act, under certain conditions, the Commonwealth meets the cost of hostel accommodation up to a maximum of $18,150 a person for buildings and up to $2,400 a person for the purchase of land. A further $250 is available for furnishings. Expenditure of $58m is provided for 1981-82.

Since my election to Parliament, in nearly every corner of the Riverina electorate I have been met by groups expressing the need for accommodation for the elderly. Whilst they realise it is better for the elderly to remain on their own in their own homes for as long as possible, this is not always practicable. Although the Federal Government has made a tremendous contribution in this area, there is still much to be done. The Riverina electorate has received substantial sums for care for the aged. However, the standard letter now received from the Minister states that all the $225m has been committed and that no assurance in relation to funding can be given. This is not the fault of the Minister but an indication that more funds must be provided for the elderly, particularly as this nation has an aging population.

In the city of Broken Hill, which has a population of approximately 28,000 people, nursing home accommodation is provided by the Sisters of Compassion. They provide care and accommodation for 50 elderly people at the Home of Compassion in south Broken Hill. The Sisters, a catholic order of nuns, care for the elderly with great devotion, but the numbers waiting to enter the home are heartbreaking. The only other accommodation for the elderly who require constant care is provided in the geriatric ward of the Broken Hill and District Hospital where, although the nursing attention provided is second to none, the conditions of the building are far below standard and, because of lack of priority by the State Government, there does not appear to be any possibility in the near future of alleviation of the problem. The geriatric ward caters for 69 elderly citizens. The city does have hostel-type accommodation at Aruma Lodge and home units provided by Southern Cross Homes at the Con Crowley Village, and this accommodation is first class. However, the residents of these units must also ultimately seek nursing home accommodation. So there we have it-nursing home accommodation for 119 people in a population of nearly 30,000 when surrounding districts are included.

This situation is ludicrous, and to add to the tragedy the nearest practical nursing home accommodation is 500 kilometres away in Adelaide. Imagine the heartache of the elderly and their relatives in this situation. Of course, this is not unique to Broken Hill or the Riverina electorate but applies throughout Australia. The point I am making is that because the $225m has been used, we should not stop there. It is a long while before 1983 and the Government must have an ongoing commitment as regards accommodating the aged. This is particularly crucial when local groups are expected and, in most cases, are eager to raise their share of the finance towards the cost of caring for their elderly citizens. Without some ongoing commitment of finance by the Federal Government, local people will lose their incentive to raise money which they may have to return to donors if Federal funding does not become available. It is my hope that the Government will look into this matter so that nursing homes such as the 60-bed unit presently being promoted by the Uniting Church at Broken Hill and other accommodation for the aged will gain greater priority and that there will be an ongoing commitment announced soon for works beyond 1983.

This year $685m has been provided in Commonwealth grants to the States and the Northern Territory for road works. This was part of the Government's commitment announced in June 1980 to provide $3,650m in road grants over a five-year period to the States and the Northern Territory. The total allocation for New South Wales for 1981-82 is $214.34m. Of this, $103.57m is for national highways, which are totally funded by the Commonwealth Government, $64.5m for rural and urban classified roads and $46.27m for rural local roads. In addition to the finance provided by the Federal Government for rural local roads, local government has the alternative to pay for road works out of council rates, which in New South Wales have a ceiling placed on them, or they can be financed from the untied grants that are paid to local government under a tax sharing arrangement. This year in my electorate there has been approximately a 16 per cent increase in these funds. The only other source from which funds are available is the New South Wales Government local government assistance fund which appears to be on the decline. However, because of other claims on local government finances, there is still not enough money remaining to carry out even essential maintenance, much less construction work. The amounts provided by Federal and State governments for road works sound impressive, but I am convinced, as are the constituents of my electorate, that neither the Federal nor the State Government is spending enough on roads within New South Wales and, in particular, within the Riverina.

Earlier this year representatives of local government throughout Australia converged on Canberra with the specific purpose of gaining greater funding for road construction and maintenance for their respective areas. I was pleased to see excellent representation of local government from within the Riverina electorate. While in Canberra the delegates met the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) and, although I know the Minister was sympathetic to their problems, he could not offer any hope of greater financial assistance. The stage has now been reached when my electorate is in a desperate situation as far as road funding is concerned and large amounts of money must be channelled by Federal and State government into the system. I am sure that I speak for all my colleagues, particularly those from rural areas, when I say that we will be working towards a greater share of the public purse being placed into road works. I urge our State colleagues to adopt the same attitude.

The allocation of $35m as part of the National Water Resources Program was particularly welcome. In the Budget Papers this amount was shown as a rural subsidy while it will in fact be used in both urban and rural areas. I hope that some of this money will find its way into the Riverina for salinity mitigation, drainage and flood protection works to continue works already being undertaken with combined Federal and State moneys. The town of Deniliquin is particularly in need of funds at this time for levee bank construction works, but this will depend greatly on State government priorities.

Because of ever-increasing costs of freight, energy and communications for people living in isolated areas I was pleased to see an increase in relation to the zone allowance for dependants; from 25 per cent to 50 per cent in the case of zone A and 4 per cent to 20 per cent in the case of zone B. As a newcomer to the Parliament and a person who less than a year ago was the single income earner on a medium salary for a family of four teenage children-all of whom were, and still are, attending high school-I know the worries that parents in similar situations are facing today when they hear of increased taxation on clothing, shoes and some of the necessities of life. The position is made more difficult when one is in that situation because if one wants to enjoy the basics that two income families or people on higher incomes take for granted one has to obtain them on hire purchase. With interest rates at today's high levels this makes one's position even more untenable.

I believe that in order to obtain a balanced economy so that income taxes eventually can be reduced the Government must find ways of cutting its expenditure. It is interesting to note that outlays on defence pensions and other benefits are to rise this year by 15.8 per cent compared with a rise of only 10.4 per cent in all other outlays. The time has come for the Government to look into some areas which in the past it has been reluctant to approach. One of these areas is family allowances. Many Australian families on low incomes eagerly await their family allowance payments to provide necessities for their children. However, others on high incomes regard the family allowance as a pin money gift from the Government. I have heard many people say that they have never used the family allowance but have banked it for little Johnny or little Joan so that they can have some money in the bank when they get older. Because the family allowance payments are not large it might be that some accumulation is necessary over short periods to make necessary, worthwhile purchases. But I contend that if one can afford to bank these payments over a long period one does not need them. In other words, people on the poverty line could be receiving the same family allowance as, for example, a parliamentarian, a Queen's Counsel or a company director. Paying the family allowance to families on high total incomes is giving money away. Therefore, a means test is required for the payment of the family allowance. This may not be politically popular but it would allow more money to be made available for distribution in other welfare areas that are short of funds. No fairminded Australian could object to this proposal. In a similar way other outgoing payments of the Government could be looked at.

Some people oppose the Government's policy on sales tax for political reasons. Others are genuine in their concern. I support the Government only on the basis that in the not too distant future the decisions announced in this Budget will benefit those families that find themselves struggling today by reducing inflation and bringing down interest rates. If they do not then my attitude must alter.

A warning has been sounded by the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Anthony) that the capital inflow into this country has slowed. At the same time the current account deficit has continued to grow. We cannot continue to depend on massive capital inflows from overseas. The Deputy Prime Minister pointed out that overseas trade is crucial to Australia's well-being. With the short term trade prospects deteriorating and long term outlook uncertain, it is imperative that this nation remain competitive. This means that any increase in inflation will pose a serious threat to our nation's welfare. This Budget has been drafted with these facts fully in mind. Other honourable members have eloquently spoken for and against the Budget. Most have referred to the needy, the unemployed and those who do not appear to be sharing in Australia's wealth. I can only hope that the Budget now before the Parliament will, by its thrust, keep this nation, whose economy is the envy of the world, on an even growth pattern so that those people and other Australians will benefit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That all words after 'That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
'whilst not opposing the Bill, the House rejects the Budget strategy because:
(1) it deliberately reduces the rate of economic growth;
(2) it increases unemployment;
(3) it adds substantially to the rate of inflation;
(4) it relies on a massive private capital inflow;
(5) it fails to tackle the real causes of rising interest rates, and
(6) it increases the burden of taxation to the highest level in our history,

and, in addition, deplores the Government's callous disregard of the millions of Australians living in poverty and its continued attempt to reduce the living standards of the great majority of Australians'.

The Opposition regards the Budget as deplorable both in regard to the overall strategy on which it is based and the allocative decisions it encompasses within that strategic framework. It demonstrates convincingly not only that this Government has no answer to the scourge of stagflation but also that it has no real concern for the victims of that disease. It demonstrates further-if such demonstration were needed-that this Government is thoroughly dedicated to the task of bringing about a more inegalitarian and divided society. We on this side of the House deplore these developments. We especially deplore and abhor the callous unconcern for millions of Australians in poverty, and the continued and unceasing attempts by this Government to reduce the living standard of low and middle income earners and their dependants who represent the great majority of the Australian people.

The Government's Budget strategy is basically nothing more than a policy of contracting the rate of economic growth following a substantial rise in the growth rate in 1980-81 because of concern at rising inflation and interest rates. In order to reduce the pressure for higher inflation and interest rates the Government is aiming at reducing the Budget deficit by around $1,000m, thereby contracting the level of demand in the economy and hence reducing the rate of growth of output and employment. By so doing, the Government hopes to bear down on inflation and particularly wage increases, to which it attributes most inflationary pressure. Also, by reducing the size of the deficit, the Government reduces the size of the public sector borrowing requirement and, thereby, the government demand for funds in the capital market. It hopes by so doing to reduce interest rate pressures. Such policies are said to be compatible with non-farm product growth of 3 per cent to 3 1/2 per cent this year compared with 4 per cent last year. With expected recovery in farm product because of improved export prices and recovery from drought, it is expected that gross domestic product will rise by over 3 1/2 per cent compared with 3 per cent last year.

We see this strategy as being hopelessly misconceived in several respects. It rests on a false view of the underlying state of the economy. In this there are two aspects. It assumes that the increased economic growth rate last year was attributable to the successful implementation of the Government's economic policies. The Budget Speech is full of self-congratulation in this regard but such self-congratulation is an absolute nonsense. Rather, the recovery last year was attributable to a completely exogenous factor and to three absolute deviations from Government policy. The exogenous factor was the second oil shock-the 150 per cent increase in the world price of oil-which occurred in 1979-80 which made our energy resources infinitely more attractive for development, thus stimulating a massive upsurge in real business investment. A 21 per cent increase in real terms in such investment occurred last year. So much for the exogenous factor. The deviations from policy were, firstly, increased government expenditure in an election year-a politically opportunistic increase of 3 per cent in the real level of government expenditure, well above the normal one per cent rate of growth which has occurred in previous Fraser Budgets-which is a clear deviation from its normal policy. Second was the rapid rise in money supply. The Government's target rate of growth for the money supply was 9 per cent to 11 per cent. But M3, the standard measure of the money supply, grew by 13 per cent and M6, which includes non-bank financial institutions, grew by 16 per cent. This blow out of the money supply growth caused the Reserve Bank of Australia to criticise the Government trenchantly in its annual report for what it saw as the inflationary measures involved and the Government's failure to accept interest rate rises needed to prevent that increased money supply-most of which, of course, occurred from the unprecedented $6.5 billion private capital inflow last year. A further effect of the increased money supply was undoubtedly the stimulation of more growth than would otherwise have occurred. Another of these deviations had this stimulatory effect on the economy.

The third deviation was the increase in real wages in 1980-81-the first such rise since 1974. The Government claims there was a 3.9 per cent rise in real wages last year, but this ignores the impact on wage earners of increased interest rates. Even taking that into account, and that there was some increase in the tax burden, the fact still remains that there was a substantial increase in real wages last year. That increase in real wages occurred despite bitter opposition from the Government. It was not part of the Government's policy to increase real wages by almost 4 per cent last year; it occurred totally in opposition to the Government's policy. So the fillip to consumption expenditure and, therefore, to economic growth which stemmed from this real wage rise, was in no way attributable to Government policy. Thus the substantial increase in the rate of economic growth last year is no cause for government complacence or self-congratulation. It was quite demonstrably attributable to an outside influence, that is, the oil shock, and to the failure of the Government to achieve particular Government objectives rather than representing successful implementation of its policies.

Another aspect of this false view of the underlying state of the economy is that the Budget ignores the fact that last year the growth was concentrated in the first half of the financial year. We had a 6.1 per cent annual growth rate in the first half of the year and only 1.6 per cent in the second half. Certainly national account figures are subject to revision and the difference between these two halves may be exaggerated in the figures that we have at the present time. But if the national account figures are anywhere near right then this contractionary Budget may well impinge not on a strong underlying growth, as the Budget assumes, but on a fading recovery. If this is the case, the growth of output and employment will be well below Budget estimates and the growth of unemployment will be well above Budget estimates. Already in the last two months we have seen unemployment increase sharply. This gives further cause to fear that the Budget assumption of firm underlying growth may be quite misplaced.

The second reason why we see this Budget strategy as being highly inappropriate is that it relies on more unemployment to keep inflation down. The Budget assumes some rise in unemployment as a result of the falling growth rate in non-farm output and so slow employment growth. It is important to realise that this is not just something that is expected to happen despite the Government's best attempts to prevent it. Rather it is the deliberate intention of the strategy to bring this about. What a sterile and despairing policy this is! Here we have a government which presides over an economy with an official unemployment rate of over 5 per cent and an actual unemployment rate of probably double that amount. Indeed, in a Library discussion paper circulated to all members of this Parliament, Professor Perkins of Melbourne University estimates that the actual unemployment level is 10 per cent.

In this situation of a 10 per cent unemployment rate we have a government which moves in this Budget, as a basic part of its strategy, to deliberately increase the level of unemployment. What a disastrous policy this is. The basic Fraser Government formula for combatting inflation is to create more unemployment. It has been doing this ever since it has been in government. After six years it is still the same appalling and despairing policy. The restoration of full employment, or anything remotely resembling it, is simply not possible from such a policy. This is because, if we do have a pickup in the growth of output and employment, as occurred last financial year, so that unemployment begins to fall, inflation also starts to rise. The Government then moves to slow down that growth rate by the contractionary budget and monetary policies that we now have. So employment growth slows and unemployment increases again.

The terrible lesson of six years of Fraser Government-it is unambiguously spelt out in this Budget-is that the basic economic strategy that is pursued has made, and will in future make, a restoration of full employment quite impossible whilst that strategy persists. Furthermore, it is clear that more and more unemployment is needed to keep inflation at any given level. Why this is so is too complicated to explain at present. With these kinds of policies we need more and more unemployment to keep inflation at any given level. Hence unless policies are changed we must expect that ever higher levels of unemployment will be incurred. Inevitably what flows from such a conclusion is that new policies and a new means of dealing with our economic problems are needed. Rather than relying solely on fiscal, monetary and exchange rate policies to solve these problems, we also need more government intervention in the form of economic planning, of which there is an absolute dearth in this country. We need controls on resource development, for reasons that I will spell out later in this speech. We need prices and incomes policies to enable a less inflationary resolution of conflicting income claims than presently occurs. The development and implementation of such policies will be key elements of the economic policy under the next Labor government.
Sitting suspended 5.59 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner I was explaining to the House the reasons why the Opposition rejects the Government's Budget strategy. A third reason is that, in pursuing its strategy of reducing the deficit to reduce inflation, the Government employs measures which are themselves patently inflationary. An example of this is the health insurance rearrangement, which is about the fifth we have had under this Government. It is said in the Budget Papers that this will have the effect of increasing the consumer price index by some 0.75 per cent in the current financial year. This applies similarly to the sales tax increases, which are well known to the people of Australia by now. It is estimated in the Budget that they will add 0.75 per cent to the consumer price index this year. That, of course, is a patent understatement of the real inflationary effects of those sales tax increases. The full effect will be more like 1.75 per cent than 0.75 per cent. This follows from the figures of the Treasurer (Mr Howard), in his statement to this House on 12 March, when he was rejecting the concept of expanding indirect taxes. He said, at that time, that the reason for doing so was that they would be inflationary and that for every $500m additional revenue raised through increased indirect taxes there would be an addition of one per cent to the consumer price index. He said, in the Budget Speech, that the full year revenue from the sales tax rises would be $890m. So on the basis of those figures we can expect an increase in the consumer price index eventually from these sales tax figures of about 1.8 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: Increased State goverment taxes and charges also are attributable to actions of this Government. All the States have been cut back in their funding by this Government and, as a result, are being forced to increase their taxes and charges. They too will eventually feed into the consumer price index and so add to the rate of inflation. So the direct effect of the Government's actions in this Budget is to increase the consumer price index by over 2 1/2 per cent. This includes 0.75 per cent for health insurance, 1.75 per cent or more for sales tax and some unknown additional amount for State government taxes and charges. What follows from this is that the inflation rate for 1981-82 as estimated in the Budget Papers at 10.75 per cent is certainly an underestimate. That figure is for the year on year, 1981-82 over 1980-81. But on the July 1981 to June 1982 Budget basis it is more likely to be a 12 per cent rise, as we estimated it.

How ironic it is that the action taken in this time of anti-inflation could have such a clear inflationary impact. But, in fact, the inflationary impact is even greater than it first appears because of the impact on inflationary expectations. Nothing is more likely to feed inflationary expectations than rising inflation itself. This is because it encourages people to endeavour to protect themselves against that expected higher inflation, and especially if there is no protective mechanism in place, such as wage indexation. Of course, in the process of protecting themselves by seeking higher incomes, people add to the rate of inflation. They bring about higher inflation. The Treasurer recognised the importance of this indirect aspect in his statement to the House on 12 March. So the inflationary impact of the Government's action are very substantial indeed. It is incredibly ironic that such action has been taken in the name of opposing inflation.

A further reason why the Opposition rejects the Government's Budget strategy is that it does not attack the interest rate problem at its source. The extent of the interest rate problem is, of course, clear to everyone in the community. We have had a rise in mortgage interest rates of some 3 per cent over the last 17 months, taking them to the highest level ever in our history. The Treasurer is emphatic in his Budget Speech that the cause of increased interest rates is increased demands for funds in the capital market. He claims that the Government must therefore cut its demand for funds in the capital market and thereby reduce the interest rate pressures by reducing the overall Budget deficit. But this is the same policy as he employed last year when, as we are all painfully aware, the policy was patently unsuccessful, as was shown by soaring interest rates. The rapid rise in interest rates last year occurred because the Government did nothing about the real cause of pressure for increased interest rates-that is, the greatly increased demand for funds in the capital market by the private corporate sector.

Despite the rapid rise in the money supply the demand for funds from the private sector grew so enormously that there was still a shortage of funds. But the Government's response was not to control that private demand for funds but, rather, to reduce the public sector demand for funds. This policy was pursued even though the public sector borrowing requirement was well below the level of previous years. In fact, as a percentage of GDP it was at the lowest level since 1973-74. What the policy amounted to, therefore, was a policy of increasing taxes on Australian taxpayers so as to prevent them from having to pay higher interest rates. Such a policy would have been small comfort even if it had worked. But it did not work last year and we got increased taxes and increased interest rates. The same policy is being pursued again this year, only this time we are to have sharply reduced government expenditure as well as increased taxes. So the Government is again saying to the taxpayers that they should pay more tax and that they should have less government expenditure on their behalf so that they will not have to pay even higher interest rates. Again this will be small comfort even if it does prevent further interest rate rises-but there is no certainty of that.

Whether interest rates rise or not will be determined, as it was last year, by the strength of demand for funds in the capital market by the private corporate sector and by what happens to the rate of growth of the money supply. If business investment growth is as strong as the Government forecasts-that is, a real increase of 10 to 15 per cent-then there could be further interest rate rises. Certainly, the Budget figures for the combined corporate sector borrowing requirement and for the public sector borrowing requirement are the same as last year-that is, 5 per cent of gross domestic product. Last year it was 2 per cent of GDP public sector borrowing requirement and 3 per cent for the corporate sector borrowing requirement. This year it is the other way around; the total is still 5 per cent. So the expected demand for funds from these two sources is estimated to be just as strong as it was last year. With the Government stressing its much greater determination to restrict the money supply growth to the target rate of 10 to 11 per cent this year, it would seem that further interest rate rises are a distinct possibility. If the Government were really serious about reducing interest rate pressures it should tackle that pressure at its source, which is the corporate sector demand for funds, and do it by controlling the rate of resource development which is generating this vast demand for funds rather than reducing the living standards of most Australians by increasing their taxes and reducing Government expenditure on their behalf.

A further reason for opposing this Government's Budget strategy is that it relies heavily on a massive capital inflow. Last year the private capital inflow was an incredible $6,500m, by far, the highest ever in our history. This year the underlying Budget estimate of private capital inflow is, as the Treasurer admitted last week in questions on the Treasury estimates, an astonishing $7,800m-that is, much bigger than last year. Such vast inflows have substantial significance for the Australian economy. They clearly have impact on the level of foreign ownership and control of our economy. They certainly exert pressure for exchange rate revaluation to the extent that they exceed the balance of payments deficit on current account and thus create structural pressures in the economy, as they did last year with the 10 per cent revaluation. To the extent that they exceed the balance of payments deficit on the current account they also add to the money supply and so create the need for unpleasant offsetting action.

Last year the capital inflow added $2.8 billion to the money supply or about 45 per cent of M3 growth. This year it is estimated to be much the same-that is, about 45 per cent of money supply growth. In effect, what this means is that Australians will be paying directly through higher taxes and a reduction in our already small public sector for this high level of capital inflow. This will come about because the Government is hoping to offset partially the impact of such substantial funds through capital inflow in the economy by reducing the deficit. It does that by increasing taxes and reducing government expenditure. Reliance on such large levels of capital inflow for money supply growth is also quite dangerous. What happens if it does not eventuate, as could well be the case? In that case, the Government has to take offsetting action. If it is slow in doing so, we could have an enormous credit crunch. On the other hand, if it comes in in even larger amounts than was estimated, we could have the need for the Government to take offsetting action by selling more government bonds and therefore bringing about higher interest rates. Such reliance on massive--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired. Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak later.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Porter Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer (Mr Howard), in formulating this year's Budget, was faced with a situation in which after five years of coalition government the economy was at last showing signs of sustained growth. Through difficult economic circumstances and at times with politically unpopular measures this Government has turned the economy around and we are now starting to reap the benefits. In the last financial year we have seen an increase in consumer demand and consumer spending, reflecting in part the real increase in wages. We have seen a substantial increase in employment. We have seen a small resurgence in the profits of the business sector, which, of course, is the basis of future investment and employment. A new confidence has emerged in the Australian economy, largely brought about by stable and economically sound Government policies. This confidence is most obviously evident in the very large increase in business investment. Many of the problems which have been addressed in this year's Budget are in fact a result of sustained economic growth and confidence.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the greatest problems for the Australian community at the present time is the increase in interest rates. The rise in interest rates results from the demand for loan funds being greater than the loan funds available, and so interest rates are bid up. The large demand for loan funds has been caused by the confidence of the resource sector and the primary and secondary sector as they all try to expand their businesses or develop new businesses. Unfortunately, the amount of money demanded for this new investment has been much greater than the supply. The Government has limited its own borrowing program in order to ensure that a maximum amount of funds are available for the private sector. Even so, interest rates have still risen. With this in mind the Treasurer has budgeted for a domestic surplus in excess of $1,500m. This Budget surplus will substantially reduce the upward pressure on interest rates. Page 283 of Budget Paper No. 1 states:

. . . for any given set of economic and financial conditions a higher domestic Budget surplus reduces the need for liquidity to be withdrawn from the banking system by way of sales of Commonwealth Government securities to the non-bank sector. In that situation, pressures on interest rates will also be reduced below what they would otherwise be.

So it is clear that one of the fundamental considerations of this Budget is to produce a sizeable domestic surplus by which means it is hoped that the steam will be taken out of interest rate increases. That domestic surplus has been achieved in two ways: Firstly by restricting the growth of Government expenditure-although I might add that I would have preferred the Treasurer to have gone further in this direction; however, I recognise that that is not an easy task-and, secondly, on the revenue side, growth in employment, profitability of companies and wages will add to increased revenue, together with the sales tax which has been increased or imposed where none was previously payable. An alternative for the Government would have been to budget for a smaller domestic surplus by not imposing the new sales taxes and by reducing, say, personal income tax.

However, as I have already pointed out, a reduction in the size of the Commonwealth Government's domestic budget surplus could add to the upward pressure on interest rates and it could well have been the case that any tax reductions for the average Australian taxpayer with a loan or home mortgage would have been absorbed by increased home loan payments as interest rates rose. In other words, the average taxpayer with a home loan might have been worse off if the Government had given tax relief in this Budget instead of applying the tax income to reduce the pressure on interest rates. Looking to the future, it is clear that once the upward pressure on interest rates is removed there will be a great opportunity for the Commonwealth Government to reduce personal income tax rates. I believe care must be taken at that time to ensure that the Government does no cave in to pressure to increase its own expenditure.

There are a number of other matters related to the economy and the Budget which will have to be resolved in the period ahead. I refer firstly to the method of wage fixation. Wages increased over the last financial year at a rate which about 4 per cent greater than the inflation rate. Our competitive advantage in world trade is dependent on maintaining a low rate of inflation and controlling excessive wage demands. Since the end of indexation we have seen a number of extraordinary large wage claims. There is no doubt that these excessive claims threaten future economic growth not only in the resources area but also in industry generally. In a recent article the Opposition spokesman on industrial relations, the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke), said that organised labour had repudiated any inhibitions upon the exercise of its power to obtain what it believed to be a fair price in the market. The honourable member for Wills suggested that unions would take this course of action because the Government had attempted to free-up the market place by removing some restrictions which were previously imposed on the private sector. Surely that argument by the Opposition can be sustained only if market forces are allowed to play their part in the pricing of labour. With minimum wages, restrictive union membership, closed shop arrangements, restrictions on the freedom of movement of labour and a multitude of other restrictions on the price of labour it is totally unreasonable to suggest that a fair market price for labour can be reached. The honourable member for Wills was probably really suggesting that the unions are more likely to rely on might than right in the market place.

The Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, following the end of indexation, will endeavour to find a new basis for wage determinations, and a number of points must be taken into account. The Commission ought to continue to be the basis of wage determinations in this country in order to ensure that all wage and salary earners obtain a fair share of the national cake. The alternative is a wages scramble in which the price of labour is determined by the relative strength of the union regardless of the ability of the industry to pay and regardless of the national interest. The Commonwealth has a role to intervene in national wage case hearings. It seems to me that the Government's role ought to be to put arguments before the Commission relating to the general economic climate as well as the national interest. The Government has a role also to ensure that the rules applying to the union on one side and the employers on the other are fair and just. We must ensure that one side does not have an unfair advantage over the other. In this way the umpire-the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission-can make a reasonable decision. Finally, there must be co-ordination and consultation between the Commonwealth and State governments as public sector employers. The country cannot afford to have one State setting itself up as a wage pacesetter when those decisions become the basis for subsequent leapfrogging deals.

Another separate but related matter which the Government has to take into consideration in the forthcoming year is the issue of protection. One factor to be considered is the extent to which unions involved in highly protected industries use their position of special advantage to push for excessive wage demands. Other factors of importance are the prospective increases in rural and resource exports, together with the appreciating exchange rate. The Government has recently referred a general reference on tariffs to the Industries Assistance Commission for report. A particular matter which is before the Government is the IAC report on the level of protection to be given to the car industry beyond 1984. Unfortunately, the public debate on this issue has become rather irrational, with exaggerated claims being made on both sides. It is clear to me that if we, as Australians, are going to be able to compete on world markets, we must aim to have as many efficient and world competitive industries as possible.

The debate about the car industry at present is about the level of tariff which will assist the industry but at the same time continue to provide an incentive for the industry to increase its efficiency and productivity whilst having regard for the consumers and other domestic industries in this country. It is also clear that any change in protection ought to be gradual. Sharp shifts in Government policy shake business confidence and can do irreparable harm to the economy generally. I believe that many Australian industries are efficient and competitive, and there could be many more. For example, there is no doubt in my mind that in recent times, as a result of the IAC report on the white goods industry, that industry has rationalised and is becoming an extremely efficient domestic Australian manufacturing industry. There have already been substantial improvements in the Australian car industry. I believe this current review, together with a gradual reduction in tariffs, will increase the efficiency of the Australain car industry to the benefit of all Australians.

The tariff debate is related to the rates of change and the impact of technological change. I want to refer briefly to a recent report by the Bureau of Industry Economics entitled 'The Long Run Impact of Technological Changes on the Structure of Australian Industry to 1990-91'. That report made the point that there would be a considerable long term cost to the Australian community if we endeavoured to slow the rate of technological change. Such moves would have adverse effects on the growth performance of all industries and would result in lower per capita consumption and wage levels and reduced material living standards. In releasing the report, the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Sir Phillip Lynch) said that attempts to slow the rate of change 'would be likely to result in higher domestic costs and commodity prices, weaken the international competitiveness of exporting and import-competing industries and lead to a contraction in the level of external trade'. He went on:

Even a delay in the rate of adoption of new technology confined to specific industries, will have economy wide repercussions. For example, slowing technological change in the banking or communications industries would be detrimental to the cost levels of all industries, since the services provided by these industries are used by every other industry in the economy. It is short-sighted, therefore, merely to focus on the potential effects of technological change on the industry or sector in which the new technology is adopted.

The report found that employment in each of the 38 occupational groups studied was expected to grow during the 1980s. The same arguments, I believe, can be used against the maintenance of unrealistically high levels of protection for Australian industry.

A number of other matters will be the subject of the Government's attention in the next couple of years. Clearly, the current social security system needs to be reviewed. It has become evident that the number of recipients and the cost of the current pension system will increase dramatically over the next decade. Some consideration must be given to how that welfare bill is to be funded and whether benefits ought to be restricted to those in need. The current scheme, which provides an incentive for people to get rid of their capital assets or income-earning assets rather than providing an incentive for people to look after themselves in their old age, must be corrected. Another matter for consideration by the Government is the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System, whose report is to be given to the Government in the next couple of months. This will give the Government an opportunity to review fundamentally the working of the finance system in Australia. It is my hope that it will form the basis of increased participation by Australians in the ownership of our enterprises. This is one of the best ways in which Australians will be able to benefit directly from the development of our country. Such a move would also have the advantage that both Australian companies and the Australian people would share similar goals, which surely would enhance industrial relations in this country.

Finally, a matter which is being debated in rural Australia is the rules applying to foreign investment in our farmlands. In my view, the rules applying to non-resident foreign investors ought to be clarified and tightened to ensure that Australia's national interest is taken into account before approval is given for large rural land sales to foreigners. There are some cases of purely speculative investment, which I believe is of little benefit for Australians. As I understand it, the States have agreed to co-operate with the Commonwealth in an assessment of the extent and effects of foreign investment in rural land. There are, undoubtedly, cases where development, marketing and employment opportunities may be gained by foreign investment in our rural land. However, Australians must be given a reasonable opportunity to purchase the land. Whilst I understand that the Foreign Investment Review Board has a policy in relation to this matter and is required to be satisfied that the acquisition by a foreign person is not contrary to the national interest, I believe consideration ought to be given to the proposal that the acquisition ought to have some advantages for Australia. In other words, it ought to be positively in our national interests. I support the Budget. It is one entirely appropriate to our current economic circumstances.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Klugman Dr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It gives me great pleasure to second the amendment moved on behalf of the Opposition by our shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis). If I have time later I will repeat the actual terms of the amendment. I should like to deal with a number of topics in the Budget, partly because of my own interests and partly because it affects an area in the western suburbs of Sydney, where I live. I wish to deal with the question of the proposed alteration in the function of Parramatta District Hospital, and to some extent this question is also related to the Mater Misericordiae Hospital in North Sydney, a long way away. Last week or the week before members of the Parramatta Medical Board, who are medical practitioners with access to Parramatta District Hospital-not the full time staff but the private medical practitioners-accused the New South Wales Government of genocide, and I emphasise the word 'genocide', in proposing to change the role of Parramatta Hospital to provide rehabilitation and extended health care services. I am afraid that some members of staff, both lay staff and nursing staff, have been carried away by the self-interest of medical practitioners attached to the hospital.

SPEECH.PARA: I accuse certain doctors of playing a confidence trick on the hospital staff and the general population. Doctors who do not have the qualifications necessary to admit private patients into the new Westmead Hospital in the case of Parramatta District Hospital and the Royal North Shore Hospital in the case of the Mater Hospital, incite the public and staff to keep the Parramatta and Mater hospitals open to deal with acute patients. That is the only way for them to have private patients in a public hospital. They want to use the facilities of public hospitals provided by the taxpayers, put private patients into them and charge them. They use the facilities and staff of those public hospitals and charge the patients as though they are treating them in a private hospital. As I said earlier, they do not have access to Royal North Shore Hospital in the case of the Mater Hospital, which is the nearest, or the new Westmead Hospital, often because they do not have the qualifications necessary. They work up the staff and the public to think that something underhand is being done.

Basically, New South Wales has an adequate number of acute hospital beds. Hospitals should be run for the benefit of patients, not the financial benefits of a few medical practitioners. There have been numerous assurances-I am quite convinced myself-that no member of the staff of Parramatta District Hospital will lose his position. Staff members will have the option of either gaining a job at Westmead Hospital or being able to stay on at Parramatta District Hospital. There will also be openings in new hospitals and extensions in the area. Nobody will be sacked or lose his position. Let me tell honourable members and members of the public at large what is happening in the western area of Sydney. There is a new hospital, undoubtedly the most modern in Australia and probably one of the most modern in the world with the best possible facilities, at Westmead. It has at present 790 beds. This number can increase to 925 if and when that becomes necessary. The hospital at Fairfield has 147 beds; the hospital at Blacktown has 365 beds; the hospital at Liverpool has 337 beds with another 180 to come; the hospital at Mt Druitt to be opened in a couple of month's time has 200 beds; Nepean District Hospital has 249 beds with 100 being added; Auburn District Hospital has 296 beds; Auburn St Joseph's Hospital has 111 beds; the hospital at Bankstown has 340 beds, and the hospital at Lidcombe has 348 beds. There is no shortage of hospital accommodation in the outer western suburbs at present. It is my belief that a significant number of people are in hospital who do not need to be there, but that is an additional argument.

At present Parramatta District Hospital has 214 beds. It is proposed that at the end of the year it should have 134 beds for acute rehabilitation. It will be mainly for people who have undergone treatment, in some cases major cardiac or orthopaedic surgery, at Westmead Hospital. They will have to be rehabilitated. Westmead Hospital is on the other side of Parramatta Park from Parramatta District Hospital, less than 2 kilometres away. I can understand the worry on the part of staff who have become closely knit and have been attached to Parramatta District Hospital for a long time. Some of them do not wish to move. They do not have to do so. It is quite clear to the public that a huge new hospital has been built at Westmead with the most modern facilities. Few patients having the choice would rather go into Parramatta District Hospital than Westmead Hospital. The emergency casualty department of Parramatta District Hospital will continue to operate in the daytime at least. At night the very modern facilities of Westmead will be available.

The cost of providing and running hospital beds is now immense. I realise that it may not be a fair method of defining the cost to take the total cost of the construction and equipping of the hospital and divide it by the number of beds, but by using this method the cost of providing each bed at Westmead Hospital is over $200,000. The recurrent cost of a hospital bed, excluding capital expenditure, is now approaching $200 a day in an acute hospital. I think that Canberra hospitals have the highest costs in Australia. On average it costs $200 a day per bed to provide the facilities and trained staff necessary to run a hospital. There is certainly no shortage of beds; as I said earlier, a 200-bed hospital is nearing completion at Mount Druitt. By the time the number of beds at Parramatta District Hospital is reduced from 214 acute beds to 134 acute rehabilitation beds the hospital at Mount Druitt will be complete. Hundreds of new beds are appearing in the western metropolitan region. The number is in excess of the recommendations of the World Health Organisation.

The argument has been put repeatedly-I do not want to get involved in it too much-that every area and municipality has the right to have between four and five hospital beds per thousand of population. I think this is true overall for areas such as the metropolitan area of Sydney. But obviously a number of people, for a variety of reasons, who live in the western metropolitan area will still attend hospitals in the city for certain specific conditions. They may have been treated there before and know the doctors there; the doctors know the cases. Patients may have been treated in a particular way at, say, Sydney Hospital or Royal Prince Alfred Hospital. Therefore, some of the beds available in the inner city have to be added to those which are available in the western suburbs. I was pleased to see that the New South Wales Minister for Health, Kevin Stewart, is aware of the campaign by the doctors. He referred to their vested interests. In a statement a couple of weeks ago he said that the New South Wales Government:

. . . will not be intimidated by a campaign based on vested interests of the kind currently being waged by doctors attached to the Parramatta Hospital as visiting medical officers . . . the New South Wales Government has increased the number of hospital beds in the outer western suburbs by 950.
How that kind of increase in beds can possibly lead to people who were not under any threat 2 years ago, dying now because of inadequacies, is beyond my comprehension.

Obviously, I agree with Mr Stewart. To say that this is genocide is ridiculous.
