As I said earlier, I ask both the lay staff and nursing staff to think very carefully whether they are being conned, especially by the independent candidate who has nominated in Parramatta in the State election and who himself is one of the private doctors affected by the closing of Parramatta District Hospital. They should think for a long time and very carefully before they decide to support that particular person in a political campaign which is firstly, unnecessary and secondly, likely to be counterproductive. I think all of them would agree that a Labor Government will be returned in New South Wales on Saturday. They will obviously have much more say in a Labor Government if in that particular election they return a person who has been an excellent representative, Mr Barry Wilde.

Let me deal now with the last point of our amendment. In our amendment to the motion for the second reading of Appropriation Bill (No. 1) we give six points as to why the House should reject the Budget strategy. Our sixth point states:
it increases the burden of taxation to the highest level in our history.

Let me show honourable members just how true that remark is. In the last year of the Labor Government, 1975-76, when the present Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) was Treasurer, Commonwealth revenue was $18.2 billion. That amount has increased to $40.7 billion in the current financial year. That is a huge increase. Between the years 1975-76 and 1979-80 there was an increase in Commonwealth revenue of 62.3 per cent-in other words, money taken to a large extent from the people by taxation. During the same period, the consumer price index increased by only 47.4 per cent. So there was a 62.3 per cent increase in taxation and a 47.4 per cent increase in the consumer price index. That happened under a government which is reducing government services and which claims to be doing so to allow the people to spend more of their own money. In the years 1979-80 to 1980-81, Commonwealth revenue-taxation-increased by 18.6 per cent. During the same period the CPI increased by only 8.8 per cent. There was an increase in revenue of 18.6 per cent and an increase in the consumer price index of 8.8 per cent. The prediction for inflation in the current year is of the order of less than 10 per cent yet revenue goes up by 15.8 per cent, nearly 16 per cent. This Government, which claims to be a small government, is continuously excusing itself for giving less money to the States and for withdrawing from certain programs yet at the same time is spending a huge amount of money, much more money than any other government in the history of Australia and a much greater proportion than any other government in the history of Australia.

There has been some argument from people in the community on the question of whether single income families or two income families are better off. To my mind, some of the people who ought to know better and who generally support the poorer groups in the community, are taking the wrong attitude on this matter. They are arguing that the single income family is as well off as the two income family. That is obviously not true as far as taxation is concerned because whilst they oppose-and that is the reason I am raising the matter-the spouse rebate of $830 for single income families where the wife, as is usually the case, is a dependant, it is quite clear that that family is still worse off than a two income family with a similar sort of income. In that case, the tax free threshold is $4,195 for each income earner. In the case of a family with a single income earner that benefit is available only once. In the case of a two income family-and my family is a two income family so there is no special pleading involved; it is not in my interests to mention this-both spouses receive a tax free threshold of over $4,000. That benefit is very significantly greater for the two of them than the tax benefit for one person plus the $830 rebate. Those of us who feel that certain families are paying an excessive amount of income tax feel it is very important that they should be assisted by increasing the spouse rebate to a greater amount than the present $830.

I have only a couple of minutes left in which to speak. The honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter) talked about what the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission should take into consideration as far as wage earners are concerned and what Dr Isaac should take into consideration when dealing with the matter of doctors' fees which is at present before him. It is important to note that under the present system which commenced on 1 September doctors will have more private patients. The general practitioner will have fewer disadvantaged patients, whom he presently treats for 70 per cent of the common fee. When I say 'presently' I mean before 1 September. He will now either have disadvantaged patients for whom he will get 85 per cent of the fee or he will have patients for whom he can charge the full 100 per cent of the fee. In the case of specialists, a much smaller proportion of patients will be standard ward patients or public ward patients in hospitals. With the introduction of the hospital means test the specialist will now receive a fee for service instead of a sessional fee. So it is terribly important that Mr Justice Isaacs should take those facts into consideration before coming out with his conclusions as to how much doctors' fees should increase. It will probably mean, if it is done fairly, that there will not be a uniform increase across the board but that certain groups of practitioners will receive a bigger increase than others. He may find that some of them are so much better off under the changed system that is, the system since 1 September, that they should not have an increase at all. Again I emphasise that it gives me great pleasure to second the amendment moved by the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Gellibrand.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Prospect for his contribution to the debate. Before I call the honourable member for Franklin I would like to point out-I did not interrupt the honourable member for Prospect because I did not want to take up his time-that the occupant of the chair is referred to as Mr Deputy Speaker unless the occupant of the chair is the Chairman of Committees who is acting in the Speaker's absence as Mr Acting Speaker. But the Deputy Chairman of Committees and the Chairman of Committees when in the chair and Mr Speaker is not absent are referred to as Mr Deputy Speaker.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Goodluck Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It does not matter what some people are given, they will spend it. They will waste it and will not be able to handle it. It is precisely the same thing with the Budget. It will not please everybody. But unfortunately, sometimes the people who really need the assistance do not get it. In some situations, people who do not really need it get it. The Budget will always be unpopular. I have been listening to the speeches on the Budget of many of my colleagues and of many on the Opposition side. I can understand that it is politically wise for the Opposition to knock the Budget, to smash it to pieces, to use it as a battering ram, to use it as a tool with which to undermine the Government. I am afraid that is part and parcel of politics. I have been very interested also in the different groups that have been formed within the Australian Labor Party and even within the Australian Council of Trade Unions-the Left and the Right. The philosophy of the Left is: 'We should have it. It does not matter where it comes from but we want our share'. The philosophy of the Right is a little bit more understanding of the problems we have in Australia today.

SPEECH.PARA: The Treasurer (Mr Howard) has brought down a Budget. I will say exactly what I think about some aspects of it and also some of the limitations that I see inherent in it. It is very easy to stand up here and criticise. It is very easy to accuse someone of being disloyal or of being an ambusher. But if one is sincere a few people may start to listen and understand. Who am I to be critical? It is easy to be a back bencher and to stand up here and criticise. I repeat: If I had the job of Treasurer I may not be able to do nearly as well. Incidentally, that statement applies to some of the previous speakers from my side too. They are great when they can get the words out, but sometimes putting theory into practice it is not as easy as one might think.

Taking all that into consideration, I would like to say, firstly, that we thought-many of us still think this way-that the greatest enemy of the economy is inflation. I do not mean to criticise the Opposition; what is the use? During that period from 1972 to 1975 the then Government thought that if it spent big and gave away this and that it might indirectly help the needy, the pensioners, et cetera. But in fact it was killing some of those people on fixed incomes as a result of high inflation. Theoretically the business sector at that time might have been holding the reins, but there was bound to be a crash-and it occurred. We saw the problems with high inflation.

The thrust of the Government's policy is to reduce inflation and to keep it at a standard that is the envy of the rest of the world. The present rate of 8.8 per cent, by international standards, is very good. Whilst people may criticise and condemn, I believe that the way in which the Government has gone about trying to correct inflation has been supported by the thinking people of Australia.

I again refer to some of those within the left wing of the Labor Party who condemn, condemn and condemn and will never be satisfied. They seem to think that if we all have an equal slice of the cake it will make everything nice, smooth and happy for everybody, but we know that that is not the case. We have to remember absolutely if we are to achieve our goal we have to work for it. A lot of criticism is due to the knee-jerk reaction of members of the Labor Party who are always quick to use any unpopular but necessary decision in an effort to stir up public feeling to their own political advantage. Of course, any suggestion of riots, demonstrations or blood running in the street is bound to be sensationalised by the media. We even saw a pre-Budget rally in Hobart organised by a former Catholic priest. Guest speakers were John Halfpenny and a poor elderly pensioner who had led a pretty decent sort of life but believed in the philosophy: 'I should have the same as somebody else'. They stirred up a heck of a lot of trouble. They stirred up the emotions of the people of Hobart. I am afraid that that emotionalism has spread all over Australia. Those emotions have been intensified by stupid statements.

TALK.START.PARA: —Trouble makers.

—Yes, trouble makers. I am a Catholic and I hope that the Catholic Church condemns what has happened within the ACTU. The honourable member for Braddon (Mr Groom) will agree with me. There was a split between the left and right sections of the of the ACTU in regard to abortions on demand. I believe that the Catholic Church should support the feelings and aspirations of the majority of the people of Australia in regard to that divisive issue. It has to show its fortitude. If representatives of the Church are prepared to talk about the Mater Misericordiae Hospital in New South Wales they have to be prepared to talk about that issue also. The socialist theory got the people worked up in Hobart and all over Australia. But it just does not work that way.

SPEECH.PARA: Any rise in taxation will be unpopular but it should be seen as part of a move to alter the balance of taxes. If it does that and eventually leads to a reduction in income tax levels, surely that is what the people of Australia want. But we have to come up with the goods. We cannot increase the base for indirect taxes and at the same time fail to reduce taxation without expecting a backlash. This Government will have to heed the warning, the feeling and the sentiments that are being expressed in every electorate in Australia. It just cannot keep saying: 'We will do this' and then not do it. It has to come up with an answer. I am afraid that that is a warning the Government should heed.

If the Government's strategy to relieve pressure on interest rates and to keep inflation under control is correct, eventually we may see a reduction in interest rates. Then, I hope, young people will be able to buy their own homes and the elderly people who have been forced into taking out mortgages or obtaining loans from solicitors will be able to meet their interest payments far more adequately than they are at the moment. Although the Budget has been described by some as restrictive, in the words of the Treasurer, that is an essential part of Government strategy and will help in a major way to ease pressure on interest rates. I hope he is right. He explains that the strategy will not only preserve the hard-won gains of the past but also exploit the potential for greater gains in the years ahead. It would be a catastrophe if the Liberal Party lost government as a result of some of these unpopular decisions we may be making. Could the honourable member for Braddon think of anything worse than having a socialist government? We have heard some of the speeches from our friends on the opposite side. They would not have a clue about what is going on in the market place. They would not have any understanding of what makes this the country that we call a great country.

I refer to the decision taken at the ACTU conference in regard to abortion. The divisiveness among members of the ACTU at the moment is indicative of what is going on within the Labor Party-the Left and the Right. They just cannot understand that people are fed up with some of the feelings and aspirations that the left wing element seems to be putting into the Labor Party. We saw an example of it in Victoria when they got rid of Wilkes. They used all the excuses in the world. It was the left wing that got rid of him. That is exactly what is happening with the ACTU today. It is putting its views and feelings into the Labor Party. That is what it is all about. I wonder whether the honourable member for Braddon or the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) could think of anything worse than having a Labor Government in Australia again.

TALK.START.PARA: —The thought appals me.

—The thought appals the honourable member for Kooyong, and it appals me too because supporters of the Labor Party are showing their true colours. Therefore, we as a government have to be extremely careful that we do not lose the middle ground and that we do not underestimate the feelings of the ordinary, average Australian who may think that the Government, to a degree, is not understanding his problems. We have to be very careful because if we do not we could once again be giving Australia to the socialists. I could not think of anything worse.

SPEECH.PARA: At times governments make unpopular decisions in the long term interests of the nation. Responsible governments cannot always give the people everything they want, but on the other hand we cannot afford to ignore the fact that we represent the voters of this country and we must stay in tune with their general expectations. We must never think that we have so much knowledge and expertise that we can forget our role as representatives. That is extremely important.

I am afraid-I have seen this so often in this place-that some politicians of very high scholastic and intellectual ability are unable to read the feelings and mood of ordinary, average people. They think that everything they say and do is believed and understood. But unfortunately this is not always the case. Whatever the undoubted merits of the overall economic policy of the Government, it is essential that the Liberal Party is seen to have a human face and to be giving priority to ensuring that the average Australian shares in the country's prosperity not only through future resource development but also right now. I was disappointed, as were many other members of the Government, in what we did for the pensioners. I know the internal arguments concerning how much we can afford, how much we can give and how much we can do, but I know that many pensioners are finding it hard to survive today. It is a fact of life. I do not want any members of the Opposition to try to tell me what they have done for the pensioners. I know it is well used by members of the Opposition and well developed within the pensioners' unions that the Labor Party has the answer. In some areas of pensions our Government has a much better record than the Labor Party. Many welfare measures which one may have expected to have been introduced by the so-called protectors of the workers were in fact introduced by the Liberal Party, but members of the Opposition have a very sophisticated way of indoctrinating some of these elderly people into thinking that everything that this Government does is bad.

There are two major points to be kept in mind concerning the levels of pensioner benefits-whether they are adequate and whether they maintain their real value. Alternatives to the present pension scheme were the subject of an inquiry by a committee under the chairmanship of Professor Hancock. The Hancock committee drew the adequacy line for pensions at 30 per cent of average weekly earnings. Although under our Government pension levels have been slowly moving up, given the findings of the Hancock committee that an adequate level should be 30 per cent of average weekly earnings, we are still not doing enough. We cannot talk about the lucky country or a strengthening economy when a large proportion of our population exists on levels of income below the poverty line. We cannot consign elderly people to a human scrapheap. As we have built up our society we have made decisions that every individual is entitled to education. We have decided that children should not be forced to work. Then we decided that elderly people should not be obliged to work either. We have provided basic adequate medical care free of charge to pensioners. Surely it must follow that they should also enjoy the basic right of an income that is consistent and relative to a decent way of life.

Again I stress that I do not criticise the overall thrust of the Government's economic policy. I believe that overall the Budget is responsible and in Australia's best long term interest. But if we are to stay in office to achieve the great potential of this country we must show that we intend for all Australians to share the benefits. We must think of the vast number of low income people who cannot keep up with rising costs and whose day to day needs do not allow them to understand the importance of a tightening economy. Long term economic strategy must also take into consideration the immediate need of the poor people of the community. I am reminded of the passage from the old favourite the Wizard of Oz which seems to make a relevant point:

'I don't know enough' said the scarecrow cheerfully, 'my head is stuffed with straw you know and that is why I am going to Oz to ask for some brains'. 'Oh! I see' said the tin man 'but after all brains are not the best thing in the world'. 'Have you any?' inquired the scarecrow. 'No, my head is quite empty' answered the tin man. 'But once I had brains and a heart also, so having tried them both I should rather have a heart'.
Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Look, I am not interested in members opposite. The point I am making is that we have to show a heart. We have to make absolutely certain when we introduce policies that they are tempered with a measure of compassion. It does not matter about what people across the way say. We are the Government at the moment. We are the ones who have to design our policies to make sure that we show that compassion that is imperative today. Many people in the community are saying that some of our policies are not designed in the correct way. Therefore, we have to make the decisions. We must forget about those fellows across the way. They do not mean anything. They are the members of the Opposition. All they do is tackle and haggle over stupid little things and bring up dirty little bits of the past, but they do not really mean very much in the measure of things today. I have been involved, as have the honourable member for Braddon and the honourable member for Kooyong, in the Community Youth Support Scheme. We have heard a lot about the Scheme from members of the Opposition. They did not say very much when we introduced the CYSS programs. They thought it was an incorrect scheme and that it would not do very much.
—They criticised it.

—They criticised it. But now they have a good political point they can attack us on in relation to the CYSS programs. Unfortunately they have a point, the point being that we introduced the scheme and after five years of trouble and of smoothing out some of the problems we had in it, many involved in it are doing a very worthwhile job. Many project officers are doing a good job. An interesting thing was said by somebody during the week-we as back benchers have a role to play. Had we had a greater role to play within the CYSS programs, had we used the many talents on the back bench to develop the CYSS programs and had we got rid of some of those project officers who used the CYSS programs only as hornets nests of socialism to develop their own ideology and philosophy, we would have been far better off. Unfortunately we were conned to such a degree that we have to do this and that but never get involved in the nitty-gritty. The five members from Tasmania know the problems of unemployment in Tasmania. Had we been given the opportunity to develop those CYSS programs and to have got rid of some of the people involved in them who were not doing the job, we could have developed a very good scheme. But unfortunately we are members of the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not really criticising, but the point I am making is that had we been able to direct that flow of input and energy and to develop some of those projects in a better way, we would not have the problems we have today. Unfortunately we can be picked off by some members of the Opposition who were involved in CYSS to their political advantage. That aside, the practical point is that we need to develop a bridge between what we developed within the CYSS programs and what we should be doing in the future. It is very easy to say that on 31 October we are going to cut CYSS, but some of the buildings are half-constructed and some very good people in the local communities have got involved and the local authorities have got involved. Most of the project officers now, thank God, are good people. The bad ones have gone because we realised that they were not there for the interests of the young unemployed. They were not there to develop good schemes. They were there only to develop their own ideology. CYSS projects were referred to sometimes as hotbeds of socialism. I agree with that, because I saw some projects where the people involved could not even wash a cup because they thought it was not a good thing to wash a cup and to keep it clean.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not all of them.

—I am not saying that in respect of all of them. I am saying that now we have got rid of them, there is a good foundation for good schemes in the future. I believe the Government should use that bridge to develop those schemes. I hope that we can come up with something better than CYSS because the foundation is there and we have to make certain that future schemes are good for the young unemployed.

SPEECH.PARA: I was not going to say very much about the Budget in respect of Tasmania. There is only one thing I would like to talk about. The $6m that has been pinpointed for the development and upgrading of the Tasmanian airport, I believe, is going to be an essential ingredient for the economy of Tasmania. We have seen declining industries because of our isolation. We have seen our young people leave Tasmania. But we have something bright on the horizon-a tourist industry. We have the Apple Isle. Incidentally, we all forget the hook; we all forget that it is known as the Apple Isle. It is a beautiful island. It is endowed with wonderful natural features. It can be developed as a tourist isle and jets from oveseas could bring to Tasmania people who would spend their money and their time in Tasmania. It could be developed. Therefore, I applaud the Government for showing the foresight of using that money to develop the airport of Tasmania.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blewett Dr N.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the sixth annual Budget of the Fraser Government and it permits us to make an overall judgment of the half-baked economic policies of the conservative Government elected in 1975. It is the thrust of what I am going to say tonight that if there remain in this community any thinking people who believe that the Fraser Government has any answers to the economic malaise that grips this country, they will be finally and totally disillusioned by the 1981 Budget. I referred to half-baked economic policies; that is, policies which are neither flesh nor fowl, on which the wets and the dries in the Liberal Party cannot agree. Indeed, the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck) waxed eloquent about divisions in the Australian Labor Party. Let me say a little about the divisions on economic policy in the Liberal Party.

SPEECH.PARA: Whatever the rhetoric of the Budget, the dries have been relatively quiet on it. It is certainly very difficult to say that this Budget in any sense represents the philosophy of the 'dries', a Friedmanite type policy. It is scarcely possible to have a dry Budget in which outlays are rising by 12 per cent-1 1/2 per cent above the anticipated inflation rate-and governmental receipts are rising by nearly 16 per cent. It is very difficult to say that that is a dry Budget. Compare the situation under the much abused Whitlam period. In Labor's last Budget the receipts of public authorities as a percentage of gross domestic product were 25.9 per cent. As a result of this Budget they will rise to 27.9 per cent of gross domestic product. This is simply, without qualification, the biggest taxing government that this country has ever seen. Therefore, it is very difficult indeed to refer to this as a dry Budget.

Moreover, when one examines much of the vaunted rhetoric that the Government uses about decreased expenditure one sees that the underlying factor is often simply redistributive allocations and accounting tricks. To exemplify that I will take health expenditure in the present Budget. If one reads the Budget superficially it appears that there is a decrease in health outlays of $778m-a fall of 21.3 per cent over the previous year. When one starts to examine the Budget one finds that, if one allows for the new arrangements of hospital payments which are hidden in another section of the Budget and no longer clearly expressed in the health section the total outlays on health by this Government have risen by $370m over last year; a 10.3 per cent rise over 1980-81. That is only marginally below the inflation rate. When one continues one's research and reads the fine print of the Budget one learns that the new health insurance rebate will impose a hidden and delayed cost on revenue of $600m. It is a kind of accounting trick that transfers that payment to next year's Budget. If one includes this extra cost of the new health scheme the rise this year is $973m-a 27 per cent rise over 1980-81. The Government has introduced an inequitable, non-universal, complex health scheme and that is the economic result, although it is hidden away and difficult to get at. I would very much like to know what the dries think of a con-job operation like that. Certainly the dries, or the Friedmanite rump on the Liberal benches, can find little joy in that sort of Budget.

I am, of course, not completely clear about where the dries stand with their attitude to small government. I recognise that they are unhappy about some of the social welfare increases that have occurred under the Fraser Government, although almost alone in explaining this increase is simply the expansion of unemployment. Of course the social welfare budget has expanded under the Fraser Government, but primarily because unemployment has expanded under the Fraser Government. No doubt the dries approve of the fact that 18-year olds are getting no increase in their unemployment benefit in this Budget just as they have received no increase in every Fraser Budget. No doubt they approve of the fact that the rise in the unemployment benefit rate for the unemployed without dependants is only 8.7 per cent-again some 2 per cent less than inflation. I am sure that they approve of those sorts of things. But what do the dries think about the massive assistance to Australian industry provided in this and previous Fraser Budgets? The whole thesis of conservative governments is that the government's task is to individualise profits and socialise the losses of the free market. What do the dries think about that? In the whole six years of this Government there has been a massive increase in real terms in industry assistance and development-a 17 per cent rise since 1975-76.

It is very good government propaganda to show business that there is government firmness, expecially when the Government is most firm on low income earners and when it hits anything but business. The idea of reducing government spending-small government-may be all right and may be represented by these dries as most efficient, most reasonable and economically rational when it reduces the spending on welfare, public education, public health services, public housing, and the socially disadvantaged. They say it is efficient, reasonable and economically rational in those areas. But there is a clear contradiction between the position of the small government people who have small government for the many but big government to facilitate profit-making corporate activity. It is the contribution of the six years of the Fraser Government-this contradiction between a policy of small government for the many and big government for the few-that is producing an increasing inequality of opportunity and income distribution in this society. I would like very much to have the dries clear up some of those contradictions in their position.

We have just heard from the honourable member for Franklin that the wets do not seem to get very much pleasure out of this Budget either. We have seen from what the honourable member for Franklin and other Tasmanians have had to say that they have mounted a dismal, wettish dirge on the Budget. I note too the distinctively wettish speech of the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) who, I am disappointed to see, has left the House. His speech on the Budget was fairly wettish. It is true that the honourable member for Kooyong, in speaking on the Budget, because of the political exigencies of his present position, has to be all things to all men. But when one examines his speech one finds some distinctively wettish elements. He opposed the Budget because it is excessively contractionary. He argued too that the burdens of the Budget fall on those least able to bear them. He mentioned too the increasing unfairness of the income tax burden. Above all he gave this magnificent wet definition of the role of budgets:
In future, I would prefer to see a Budget framed on the basis of its being as economically and socially productive as possible.
I stress the words 'economically and socially productive as possible'.
It needs to promote balance in the process of growth itself, ensuring a sensitive adjustment between the challenge of economic productivity and the satisfaction of social need.
That sort of definition would have warmed even the heart of John Kenneth Galbraith.

We have just heard a protest about the Budget from one of the Tasmanian wets. I say to the five Tasmanian members of this House and to the Tasmanian people that it is the Government which all five of them represent which has abolished the Community Youth Support Scheme; it is their Government which has been increasingly tough on social welfare and particularly unemployment payments; and which has made pensioners increasingly desperate to retain their pensioner health benefit cards because of all the pressures which derive from the changes in the new health scheme.

I turn now to the other major part of my speech; to look at this Budget in the light of six years of economic policy. I ask honourable members to go back to just 1975 when the present Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) promised-this was his phrase-to 'turn on the lights'. Let us just examine what has happened to the lights in this country over six years. In that famous policy speech on 27 November 1975 he said:
The major element in our comprehensive economic strategy is to bring about growth in production . . . a growth rate of 6-7 per cent is quite feasible.

In the whole of the six years this Government has never got near that figure for growth. After growth appeared, as it did in the first half of the last financial year, the Government, in this Budget, moved quickly to stifle it. Let us look at that. The expectation for the next year of gross non-farm product growth is 3 per cent to 3 1/2 per cent. I think that is an inflated expectation because the decline in growth rate in the second half of 1980-81 appears to have been fairly severe. I know that the figures are still provisional but from the figures for the second half of 1980-81 it appears that the economy, which the Government is about to contract, was already contracting in the latter half of 1980-81. Yet the thrust of the Government's budgetary policy this year is to contract an economy which was already contracting. This Government has no solution to inflation other than to contract the economy. The Government has now embarked on a policy which will snuff out the prospects for growth and, on its admission, increase to new heights the levels of unemployment. The first truth about this Government is that after six years it has no solution to the most critical of economic questions facing this country and that is how to provide growth without inflation. Yet on 27 November 1975 the Prime Minister said:
The major element in our strategy is to bring about growth in production.
The Government has now had six years to achieve this. The Prime Minister's second economic pledge in 1975 was this:
There will be jobs for all who want to work.

Six years ago he promised that there would be jobs of all who want to work. In August 1975 278,000 Australians were formally unemployed. I suggest that that was a minimal figure. In August 1981 there were 378,000. I am using exactly the same source and again I argue that that is a figure which minimises the number of unemployed. Even on the basic statistics, under this Government, we have had a rise of 100,000 in unemployment. What happened to unemployment under this Government was that it peaked in 1977 and despite all the rhetoric it has remained basically static ever since. It is on a plateau, more prolonged and severe-I will mix my metaphors-than at any time since the Great Depression. The promise of this Budget-the sixth Budget-is for:
Some rise in unemployment over the course of 1981-82.

After six years that is the yield of the 1975 promise. In 1975 the Prime Minister said 'there will be jobs for all who want to work'. Yet in this Budget the Government promises a further increase from an already intolerably high plateau of unemployment. Again I quote from the speech in 1975:
The Government's economic strategy will be designed to bring down the rate of inflation.

Much nonsense has been talked about this Government's economic strategy on inflation, mostly, of course, by this Government. In the second half of 1975 the rate of inflation ran at 11 per cent. Six years later, in 1981, what is the promise in this Budget? The government promises-this is a conservative statement-an inflation rate of 10.75 per cent for next year. From all the evidence we have it will certainly rise beyond 11 per cent, possibly to 12 per cent. All the suffering and all the costs of economic stagnation have yielded these sorts of gains. Little was achieved on the inflation front in 1976-77. There were some marginal but significant gains in 1978, 1979 and 1980 but the inflation situation is now deteriorating.

The Government's answers to the problems are quite contradictory. On the one hand it has a set of contradictionary policies, a reduction of the deficit and a tight monetary policy, but on the other hand the deficit reduction is pursued primarily not by reducing outlays but by increasing taxes, by policies that will directly and indirectly fuel inflation. These taxing policies will directly and indirectly fuel inflation. For example, the private tax of health insurance which is regressive and inequitable, was designed, pretty unsuccessfully as I have shown, to reduce the deficit. It will contribute at least a 0.75 per cent increase to the consumer price index figure over the next year. This is directly inflationary. The sales tax increases, regressive and inequitable, designed to balance the expected losses from the oil levy are the thin edge of a wedge to provide a general consumer tax. These increases will be directly inflationary to the extent of at least 1 1/2 per cent, despite what the Government says. These are directly inflationary ways of reducing the deficit.

The 22.2 per cent increase in pay-as-you-earn tax receipts must increase pressure on wages and salaries and thus on prices. It must produce that pressure on wages because these receipts, which are being taken in with this hefty income tax grab, are not being used to boost the social wage. If we could boost the social wage with this money we might be able to reduce the pressure on wages. But this money is not being used to provide universal health services, it is not being used to provide better education resources, it is not being used to extend public transport, it is not being used to improve social welfare and it is not being used to provide better public housing. Therefore it will have an indirect inflationary effect because it will bring greater pressure on wages and ultimately on prices. Again, the policy of reduced allocations to the States, which compels them to increase charges for their services, will further generate inflation. The imposition of the user-pay philosophy this year on the public services will be inflationary. These will be the indirect inflationary effects of this deficit reduction approach.

After six years two things should be obvious to all on the inflationary front. Firstly, it is absurd to attack inflation indirectly through a deficit policy that directly as well as indirectly fuels inflation. Yet this is what the Government is doing. Secondly, it should be clear to all by now, for the evidence is overwhelming, that a policy of tolerating a high level of unemployment for a temporary period in the belief that it will make it possible to restore full employment without inflation has failed, and been seen to fail utterly. The rate of inflation is again moving into double figures, while unemployment is little below its highest levels. The tragic outcome of Liberal policies is a new inflationary spiral beginning at intolerably high levels of unemployment.

A major element in this policy disaster is the deficit fetish which has gripped this Government. Reducing the deficit has become an ideological obsession, an end in itself, irrespective of policy outcomes. Three assumptions have underlined this obsession. I will deal with these fairly briefly. They are as follows: Firstly, that there is a positive correlation between low deficits or Budget surpluses and low rates of inflation; secondly, that there is a positive relationship between low deficits and low interest rates; and thirdly, that as the public sector is cut back the private sector will somehow expand. All three assumptions are untrue. First of all, as Dr Barrie Hughes has conclusively proved, there is no inverse relationship between low deficits and high inflation. He states:
Indeed between 1975 and 1980 as deficits got bigger, inflation fell, and as the deficit was slimmed, prices growth stirred up again.

This financial year's domestic surplus will be accompanied by the highest rate of inflation in four years. Similarly for interest rates and the deficit. Over the past three years, as the deficit has fallen, interest rates have inexorably risen. Quite contrary to the underlying assumptions, as the deficit has gone down interest rates have gone up. Finally, the third absurd assumption is that as the public sector contracts the private sector will expand. Public private sectors are mostly not competitive but, on the evidence of Australian history, are mainly complementary. Most of the great expansionary periods in Australia were periods of expansion in public investment as well as private investment. The one exception to that is the Menzies period which was a period in which we lost our competitive advantage against most of the major West European powers which were prepared to involve themselves in public investment and economic planning. The nonsense underlining this Budget and the whole economic strategy has been aptly summarised by Hugh Stretton in a brief article. He states:
In a world in which productivity reflects education, skill and research, we are told to cut public production of all three.

In a world in which public and private enterprises are so closely meshed that they almost vary together, we are told that they vary inversely and that the way to increase total production is to cut public production.
In a world in which inflation has risen roughly in step with unemployment, we are told that maintaining unemployment will reduce inflation.
We are also told that lower wages and welfare will make the lower classes work harder, but higher salaries and profits will make the upper classes work harder.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened with interest to the speech of my colleague the honourable member for Bonython (Dr Blewett).
—It was a very good speech.

—I heard the acclamation from his colleagues, as, no doubt, did other members on this side. But that does not mean that the speech deserves such acclamation. I point to the particular matter upon which the honourable member for Bonython concluded, the absurd assumptions that he thought were underlying the statements of the Government in relation to this Budget. It seems to me that he based his criticism on another much more absurd statement when he suggested that we could continue to have further public expenditure expansion. Whilst it might have been easy to have public sector expansion in a situation in which the public sector did not use a significant proportion of the total resources available to a nation, I think the situation is very much more different when the public sector has expanded to the extent that it has already and when the cry in the electorate is, as it is now, for the public sector to contract a little. The cry in the electorate is for reductions in the expenditure that is necessary for the Government to maintaan public sector expansion. In fact, the electorate is clamouring not only for a reduction in expenditure but also for a reduction in the taxes which are necessary to maintain that expenditure. Whilst it might have been easy enough to argue for it when one was talking about a small amount of gross national product, it is very much more difficult, I think, to maintain that sort of argument in the situation that we have today.

SPEECH.PARA: Nobody likes to see interest rates go up. That is a fact that I can state very clearly, as well as can most other members in this House. We are not any different from the rest of the community. Few of us, I believe, are in the position where we could describe ourselves as being free from the commitment to pay off our home and the commitment to obtain for our families items of personal property that we desire if we are to live in the sort of developed community that we have today. I am in the position, I think, that most of my constituents are in, in that I have a mortgage on my home which I have to service. If interest rates go up they go up for me as much as they do for everybody else. I had the privilege of writing to a constituent about this matter only today. He sent me a piece of paper from his building society with some figures on it indicating the level of interest that he was required to pay. They bore a remarkable resemblance to the figures that I have to look at in relation to the mortgage on my home. I am not immune from these things. I appreciate--

TALK.START.PARA: —You just don't like it; that is your trouble.

—I may not be like the honourable member for Hawker (Mr Jacobi) or the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr John Brown). They may have paid off their homes and may not be affected by these matters. But I am affected. I imagine that many of my colleagues are affected in exactly the same way. I do not like the fact that interest rates have risen. But I appreciate the economic circumstances which have brought this about. Not just domestic circumstances but external factors also are involved. We are faced with rising interest rates around the world. We have seen that people who seek out places in which to put their money are very prone to move that money from one place to another. That can have an effect upon money supply targets in Australia. It can have an effect upon domestic interests rates also.

SPEECH.PARA: The more significant factor, I suggest, is the extent to which the other forces that are at work in our economy also have an effect upon interest rates. Here I mention, particularly, the demands of the Government, not only of the Federal Government but also of State governments. Extensive private interests seeking to borrow money to assist in the development of vital resource projects are also competing for a limited resource. Money is as much a resource in these terms as anything else. The fact is that when governments enter the money markets and compete to fill their loans so that they will have the funds to carry out important resource projects they are, in effect, competing with private people like me and like many of my constituents who also have a need for money. The market forces operate. Some people believe that, in fact, we can influence these market forces by regulation.

The Government, with my wholehearted support, has adopted another view. It believes that we cannot regulate interest rates artificially by arbitrary decisions of government, but rather that we can influence them by reducing the government competition. Of course, the Treasurer (Mr Howard), in his Budget Speech, outlined the steps that the Government was taking to reduce that competition from government. He mentioned, particularly, the decision of the Loan Council which cut about 4 per cent, in real terms, off the total amount of Commonwealth and semi-government borrowing programs. That was clearly a decision of the Government designed to get interest rates down. I think a matter that needs to be mentioned over and over again is that we are committed to lower interest rates. I believe that, as these decisions take their effect, honourable members opposite will be smiling on the other sides of their faces, particularly as events unfold.

The whole strategy behind this Budget is a strategy to reduce further the demands of the Commonwealth Government on capital markets to subsidise other government activities. In the post-Labor years we were busily paying off the Australian Labor Party's debts, as I have had to describe it in my electorate. We had an enormous deficit. Each year it had to be funded. The Treasurer might be able to help me but I think at times it approached $4,000m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Five per cent of GDP.

—It was 5 per cent of GDP, as the Treasurer has helpfully suggested. This amount of Labour's debt was something that had to be funded by the Government borrowing money in the market place. While it was possible to do that at reasonable rates of interest in the past, recently it has not proved possible. So the Government has had to move to a position where it is able to balance its budget. That is what the Government has been able to do on this occasion. The Treasurer mentioned in his Budget Speech that the overall Budget deficit has therefore been reduced to a point where this year it is estimated at $146m, which is a reduction of $981m on the outcome for 1980-81. He mentioned also in his Speech that, after allowance for transactions abroad, there will be an estimated Budget domestic surplus of $1,542m this year. That will be an important factor because it means that the Government will not be in the market place competing with the private interests or with the private borrower for the sorely needed funds.

SPEECH.PARA: One other matter that drew some comment in this Budget debate is the expansion of what we have known in the past as the wholesale sales tax law. The fact is that sales tax has been with us for a long time. It has been imposed largely on what I regard as luxury items or expenditure consumer items. The Government has made a decision to impose sales tax at a very minor rate upon a wider range of products. It has done that in the light of the decisions not to proceed with the introduction of a value added tax or to proceed with a form of retail turnover tax. They were decisions that I think were largely applauded because of the new sorts of regulations that would be required in the community to give effect to a new form of tax.

Sales tax is already in place but it has been expanded to cover a wider range of products. I think it is important to look at the reasons for the Government pursuing this at this time. I fully support the reasons adopted by the Government. It is well known in Australia that there is significant tax avoidance. Whilst the Government has moved against the blatant schemes-I think it has done so in a very active and positive way-there are real difficulties in moving against the most gross avoidance practices that are current in our community. A simple examination of the household disposable income figures reveals the extent to which a large number of people in our community are taking cash for their services and taking cash for goods that they sell and are not declaring their income from that source. The fact of the matter is that there are no ways known to us and no ways, I believe, that have been advanced by the more vociferous spokesmen on behalf of the Labor Party which are known to enable those sorts of practices to be contained. The only sorts of arguments that have been effectively put were that one might manage to contain tax avoidance if one were able to reduce the income tax rates to a much lower level so that people would not feel that they were justified in taking cash out in that way.

One way that we can, in fact, encourage those people with high disposable tax free income to make some contribution to public revenue is to tax their actual expenditure. That is what is happening when we are taxing through a wholesale sales tax. I think this is a very important initiative, one which in the longer term will be applauded, one which the Labor Party will, I think, in the years ahead regret that it has opposed so forcefully on this occasion. I believe that the public wants a situation to emerge where income tax can be reduced. I believe that that will be the situation in future years. Indirect taxes can be used to garner the necessary revenue to maintain proper and existing government programs.

I wish to deal with a number of other matters in relation to this Budget. I am glad that the honourable member for Parramatta is in the House because one of the matters which I wish to discuss concerns the district in which he and I live. It concerns the termination of the Community Youth Support Scheme programs. I note that the honourable member for Parramatta has offered some public views on the Government's decision not to continue with the CYSS programs. I must say that in my electorate I share the disappointment that more successful projects have not been able to be kept going. I certainly hope that in the examination that is taking place some of the aspects of the more successful projects can be picked up. In my electorate of Dundas the project at Epping recently developed a very important initiative which I think ought to be mentioned in this place and that was in the form of a fork-lift driving course-a very novel initiative in which a very good friend of mine. the chairman of that CYSS group, Theo Taylor, through his company had developed a course for which some eight young people had completed training. A second fork-lift drivers' course is currently in operation in his plant. Jobs have been arranged through the local CYSS program for those who have completed the course. That was a very important and successful initiative from that project.

One of the aspects which I would like to mention, though, also in relation to the two projects that have operated in my electorate at Ryde and Epping, was the very positive contribution by local government. The Hornsby Shire Council had made available to the CYSS program the property which had been previously occupied, and still is occupied, at evenings by the Epping youth service. The Ryde Municipal Council had similarly made available public property for the use of the Ryde project. I think this was very well received and very well understood in the community. Those connected with the CYSS projects particularly appreciated that. It was therefore with a great deal of disappointment that I read of the activities of the Parramatta City Council in relation to the Parramatta project. I thought that it was somewhat surprising that we would see in relation to the Parramatta project the willingness of the Parramatta Council to move the CYSS project at the time that this matter was under review and not to provide on any subsidised basis at all reasonable premises for the CYSS group to be able to continue its work. In a scheme that was designed to have public participation, in a scheme that was designed to have the active involvement of the community to support it, it was very difficult to see that the Labor controlled Parramatta Council took the view that the Parramatta project was not worthy of support. In a letter to the Town Clerk from 'The Exchange'-Community Youth Support Scheme of Parramatta--

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. I think the honourable member for Dundas knows full well that he is misrepresenting the Parramatta City Council. As a former alderman I take strong objection to his selective criticism, which is unfair and untrue.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—I would have thought that the honourable member for Parramatta, as a former alderman, would have been able to speak to his colleagues, who took this disastrous decision in relation to the Parramatta project. Perhaps, if the honourable member would like this done, it would save the time which the honourable member has taken up if I incorporated in Hansard this letter to the Parramatta City Council from 'The Exchange'. I have not given the honourable member an opportunity to look at it but he may well have seen it. It is a letter which deals with the question of that group's accommodation and in which it made its comments. I will quote part of the letter before I ask permission to incorporate it in Hansard. The letter reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Indeed we cannot believe that Council considers 9 O'Connell Street, credible alternative accommodation, and must conclude from Councils' continued offer of unacceptable premises and unwillingness to discuss other possible alternatives that it is systematically attempting to force The Exchange to close.
Would the honourable member like to have that letter incorporated in Hansard?

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I would not.

—I thought that might be the case. I note that last night at a Parramatta City Council meeting this matter came up for discussion once more. Although the specific question of accommodation for the Parramatta 'Exchange' was not covered the Council deigned to offer some views upon the Government's decision not to continue support for the CYSS projects in their present form. It will be interesting to see how, when faced with the opportunity to provide worthwhile accommodation to the Parramatta Community Youth Support Scheme, which I understand the Wran Labor Government is now suggesting it might continue to fund, the Council responds in terms of providing accommodation in Parramatta for that group, because other local government bodies have been prepared to provide support.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to take the opportunity to raise briefly in this debate one other matter which is of concern to me. I welcome, of course, the Government's support for the handicapped. In this Budget the Government has provided substantial support for the mentally and physically handicapped, as was mentioned by the Treasurer in his Speech. He added also that the provision of $1,134m for handicapped people in this Budget represented an increase of the order of $660m or 140 per cent in the time that this Government has been in office. He mentioned a number of new initiatives. These included $1.5m as part of a $5m three-year program to improve access and facilities in Commonwealth buildings for disabled people; $690,000 to establish work preparation centres in Perth, Adelaide and Brisbane for mildly retarded young people; and an increase from $5 to $8 a week in the incentive allowance payable to all sheltered workshop employees. Those are important initiatives coupled with that initiative to provide $1.4m to assist in the production of Braille and audio books, the improvement of radio and television services for the handicapped and the provision of sport and recreation facilities for the disabled.

I would like to encourage the Government to examine in a much more sympathetic way one other suggestion that has been put to it, particularly by the New South Wales Paraplegic and Quadraplegic Association of New South Wales. I have introduced Dr John Grant, the chairman of that group, to the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and to the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) in order to expand upon the Association's proposal for a mobility allowance for handicapped people. I believe its proposal, which was circulated widely to honourable members, is one very much worthy of support. The proposal that was put to the Government, I believe, may have been regarded by ministerial colleagues as a Rolls Royce proposal. The Association said that some 26,000 people needed assistance in this regard and recommended allowances that might be very close to the rate used in the United Kingdom.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Government's Budget can be summed up simply. It is disastrous, it is regressive, it is discriminatory, and it clearly reflects the old dictum: 'One law for the poor and none for the rich'. This is exemplified by contrasting the laws applicable to the small investor and the opportunity given to the large national and international corporations. The Government's foreign investment policies are a national scandal.

SPEECH.PARA: I put the following questions to the Treasurer (Mr Howard), and I am delighted he is in the chamber: Firstly, is it estimated that there will be an inflow of foreign capital into Australia of between $6,000m and $7,000m in 1981-82? If so, will a high proportion of this sum be speculative capital over which the Government will have little control and no measure of its cumulative effect once it is within Australia? Secondly, has the Government deliberately abandoned the regular compilation of all statistics in this field, including the periodic surveys that played an important role in monitoring the levels of foreign ownership and control in Australia? Thirdly, has the Government ceased the collection of statistical information relating to the level of (a) foreign investment in enterprises in Australia; (b) foreign ownership and control of (i) general insurance business, (ii) life insurance business, (iii) finance companies, (iv) mining industry, (v) accredited advertising agencies, (vi) tourist accommodation establishments, and (vii) manufacturing industry; and (c) foreign control in or of (i) manufacturing industry, study of large enterprise groups, (ii) mineral exploration, (iii) finance companies, (iv) life insurance business, (v) general insurance business, (vi) registered financial corporations, and (vii) the mining industry? The answer-I will not have to wait for it-is clearly yes.

It is inevitable that there will be downstream results from this Government's deliberate policies, from the lack of adequate surveillance, adequate statistics, adequate monitoring procedures and, what is more important, adequate knowledge of the cumulative effects of such foreign investment. The sell-out of our people's vast resources and assets has reached massive proportions. It is an appalling indictment of this Government's bankrupt policies, and I will give two examples of just how bankrupt its approach is. When the Australian Minerals and Energy Council and the Commonwealth-State Industry Ministers Conference established a joint study group to inquire into the Australian gem industry, there appeared faintly a ray of hope that the Department of Trade and Resources shared some concern for the industry. If it did it was to be sadly disillusioned. A working party was set up as far back as 1978 to examine the potential for processing of Australian gemstones. The group consisted of representatives of the Commonwealth, New South Wales, Queensland, South Australia and Western Australia. A draft report was prepared and circulated to the industry. The initial report was released in June last year, that is, a year ago. Inquiries have been made persistently by the gem industry, and there appears to have been no progress whatsoever. The costly preparation of the report has been a complete waste of taxpayers' money.

The Australian gem industry is of extreme value to the national economy and boasts potential for expansion. It has been abandoned and treated badly by this Government. Information contained in the report indicates a genuine effort at least to analyse sections of the gem industry and make comparisons with other countries. It points out various action taken to further the industry and to promote and protect it in the national interest. Other governments have emphasised the importance of importing uncut gemstones for the purpose of increasing their export figures. Loans have been made available at little or no interest to establish the cutting industries. Taxation imposts have been either limited or eliminated for several years in an effort to provide an industry capable of contributing large amounts to the national income. The actions of these countries have proved successful, in many cases at the expense of the Australian gem industry and with consequences to the Australian taxpayer, who should have received benefits from a wealthy industry but in fact has received nothing. The report is comprehensive and contains over 30 pages of information. It is interesting to note that it is available throughout Australia. It has been studied by all those who have an interest in the industry, except the Government.

This Government has spent large amounts of money compiling reports, promising the industry that action will eventuate but in fact adhering to policies of abandonment. In other words, if one puts it very simply, the study group proposes, the Government disposes. The national economy has been denied a large boost, and other aggressive disastrous legislation has been forced on the taxpayer. This shocking example of inefficiency is the work of a government which has been entrusted with a project of management involving a country extremely rich in gems, a situation making it the envy of the Western world. Departments such as the Department of Trade and Resources are being continually fed with facts and figures supporting the need for national initiatives. All it ever comes up against is a blank refusal, a blank wall. The report quotes Israel as having established one of the largest diamond cutting industries in the world. All raw material is imported. Government loans and subsidies enabled that country to enter into diamond processing in a very short time. India has advanced along similar lines and has been most successful.

These governments were progressive and quick to see the inability of other countries to manage their national wealth. Why is it that Brazil and New Zealand have also taken steps to protect their gem industry? Thailand has built an enormous sapphire business. How? Simply by processing Australian sapphire material and paying low prices to our miners. It is a scandal that the sapphire situation has now reached a stage where Australians do not know that the gem originates in this country and they go overseas to buy it. Believe it or not, this country supplies 75 per cent of the world's sapphires. Australia has the expertise capable of building a large processing industry. Our cutters process gem material, resulting in high class work which in most cases is superior to that originating in Asian or other off-shore countries. Opal has been almost entirely taken over by the Hong Kong market. Many of our cutters are forced out of business. Our dealers, who are fully experienced in overseas dealing, are now returning from regular trips having sold very little of their products. Why? Because of the opposition in Hong Kong.

Let me illustrate the bankruptcy of the Government in this area. On 26 August I asked a question of the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Anthony) about the allegations that Conzinc Rio-Tinto of Australia is negotiating for De Beers to gain control of the marketing of diamonds from the Argyle project. I asked:

Is it a fact that such a contract will firstly mean that Australians will lose control over the pricing . . . and marketing of these Australian minerals; secondly, a return to Australian prices substantially below the world prices;

The extent and value of Australian diamond resources at Argyle are unknown to any Commonwealth agency. The deposit is substantially foreign owned and its value is at least one billion dollars. A week later an article appeared in Barron's National Business and Financial Weekly in London which stated:

Australia now represents the greatest single challenge to the De Beers stranglehold on the international diamond wholesaling business. Australia could set up its own marketing mechanism which might some day rival De Beers.

I further asked the Minister whether he would take immediate steps to establish an inquiry as to the level of ownership, the conditions of development, the proposed marketing contract, and the value of the deposit to ensure that if it is developed it is in the national interest. I asked whether he would make sure that an inquiry is held before any contractual obligations are entered into. The answer was quite simply that he did not know but he would make inquiries as to whether the allegations were factual or not.
Debate interrupted.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Community Youth Support Scheme-Beehive Retirement Centre, East Sydney-Mr Eamonn O'Connor-Wheat Handling Dispute-Parramatta City Council-Health Care Services

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10 p.m. I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howe Mr B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer tonight briefly to what I think is a quite valuable document-'Government Scheming: An Expose on Employment and Training, August 1981'-produced by the Unemployed Workers Union, which is based in my electorate. It is a systematic attempt to answer some of the propaganda that is being put out by the Government suggesting that its training schemes replace any need for the Community Youth Support Scheme. The theme of the report by the Unemployed Workers Union is set by the Treasurer (Mr Howard). He said:

SPEECH.PARA: In many cases, employment schemes seems to have done little more than alter the composition of unemployment. They run the risk of displacing to some extent unsubsidised workers by subsidised ones.

He said that to the Brisbane Chamber of Commerce in 1978. The Unemployed Workers Union pointed out that whilst the Government is getting rid of CYSS in favour of its employment and training schemes, in fact it has nothing to boast about in this area. It points out that in 1975-76 the Australian Labor Party spent $205m on employment and training schemes. The Government is presently spending only $203m in today's dollars. This means, if the Unemployed Workers Union is correct, that the Government has in real terms cut funding by 44 per cent. Even if the Government's so-called 23 per cent increase over the last year is taken into account, this will result only in a 12 per cent increase in training opportunities.

In this document the Union runs through the three main areas of training to illustrate its essential point; that is, that training means essentially the subsidisation of employers. Firstly, the report refers to the area of trade training which is one of the major components of the Government's training programs. It will involve $72m this year for the Commonwealth Rebate for Apprentice Full-time Training scheme to subsidise employers so that students can be released from work for training programs. The report points out that there is considerable doubt about the value of this program. It quotes the Myer report and states:

'The Department (DEYA) did not comment on whether the program is achieving the aim of improving the quality of apprenticeship training. The Committee understands that this may not be the case.' It concluded that 'the program is an expensive means of providing an incentive to employers to take on additional apprentices, given that the subsidy is paid in respect of all apprentices.'

The second principal area that involves the Government is the so-called skills area training. There are three components to this. The first is skills in demand, funding for which has increased from $0.5m to $8m. Essentially, what skills in demand means is subsidies to the multinationals that control resource based industries. The second component is general training for individuals. That program has actually been cut even though it provides one of the few opportunities for retraining people over the age of 24 years. The third component within the skills training area is the training of manpower executives, for which funding has increased from $3m to $5m. There is no requirement that that training should have any orientation to the unemployed.

The third principal area of training is the so-called youth training which, again, fits into three sub-groups. The first is the School to Work Transition Program which is supposed to absorb 16,000 people. It is a program to which the States have been particularly hostile, in which planning has been almost non-existent and whose value is quite unproven. The second component is the Education Program for Unemployed Youth. Whilst it may be of some value, the only surveys that have been done indicate that as few as 26 per cent of the people who have been through the program are in jobs four months later. Finally, there is the notorious Special Youth Employment Training Program which the Government's own surveys have indicated in the past has provided an opportunity for a great rip off for employers. That program will absorb $65m. Again, it will mean a subsidy for employers with no guarantee of effective training. CRAFT will get $72m, SYEPT will get $65m and the skills in demand program will get $8m. That is a very large proportion of the total amount of money to provide work experience and training programs of extremely dubious quality.

There is no doubt in my mind that these programs will not absorb the very large numbers of people who are currently involved within the CYSS program. They represent part of the Government's strategy not of helping young people but of transferring resources to the corporate sector and then boasting that it is trying to do something for people. The reality is that this Government is not interested in unemployment or unemployed young people. I refer to the Age of 24 August. It stated:

The Federal Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs, Mr Brown, declined to be interviewed on the subject of a return to full employment. An aide said the Minister did not feel he had sufficient knowledge of the subject, and did not have time to be briefed by his departmental officers.

I ask that the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr N. A. Brown) get himself briefed on the quality of the training programs being offered, the direction of those programs and the suggestion that they represent a substitute for the CYSS program. I am quite sure that is not the case. I understand that the Treasurer, who is at the table, wants to transfer these programs to the Education Department.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.
—I point out that the young people involved in CYSS are totally alienated from educational institutions.
—The honourable member for Batman will resume his seat.
—It is a quite inappropriate form of funding.
—I warn the honourable member for Batman that if he persists in defying the Chair in that manner I shall have to deal with him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Mr W.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to draw the attention of the House to the problems as well as the achievements of a community project which is in my electorate but which hopes to be a model for similar projects throughout Australia. I refer to the Beehive Retirement Centre in Palmer Street in East Sydney. This centre provides part time work for elderly and retired people who find that one of the curses of retirement is the enforced inactivity of people who are still able and willing to do a job of work but who otherwise cannot. The centre obtains Commonwealth financial assistance as, of all things, a sheltered workshop although it is not a sheltered workshop and this category of aid restricts its expansion and the expansion of the idea. This is the problem to which I refer.

SPEECH.PARA: The centre's program is arranged in two sections. In the activities centre light, clean, part time work is provided. An amount of $5 per day is paid to those engaged in such work. The trade union movement has given its support to the arrangement. The work includes such light jobs as packaging, assembling, book covering, mailing newsletters, reconditioning old prams and rebuilding bicycles. There are 50 client organisations which offer work and for which work is done. These include-I mention a few in alphabetical order-the Australian Broadcasting Commission, the Boulevard Hotel, the Guide Dogs for the Blind Association of New South Wales, Master Foods of Australia Pty Ltd, Radio 2SM, Thomas Nationwide Transport Ltd, the University of New South Wales and Ward's Freight Services Pty Ltd. I could mention many others.

In the leisure centre, the other half of the program, facilities are provided for retired people seeking companionship and social activities. On average, the two halves of the centre cater for 95 to 100 people each day. Those using its facilities come from all over Sydney. The official purposes of the Beehive Centre-it achieves these, as I know from a recent visit-are to help retired and elderly people to avoid total dependency; to assist them through providing work to retain or regain a satisfactory lifestyle; and also, from an economic point of view, to prevent or defer the cost of their occupying hospital or nursing home beds. It is, in other words, a form of preventative community health. The success of this community project is primarily demonstrated in terms of the well-being of the participants but there is another point. When compared with the return on the expenditure of public funds for paramedical and hospital services the cost of this operation which is classified as preventative is extremely modest.

The Sydney City Council, under the stimulus of Alderman Joan Pilone, opened the Centre in 1971 but it was obliged to limit its services to elderly people living within the city boundaries. A year later Mrs Pilone, who is now the Chairman of the Centre, interested the then Minister for Social Services, Mr W. C. Wentworth, who obtained Cabinet approval for the Sydney Beehive Centre to be given a subsidy under the Sheltered Employment Assistance Act, to allow it to extend its range to people throughout Sydney. This was because Mr Wentworth was responsible for this particular Act. In any case, Commonwealth funding in 1980-81 under the Handicapped Persons Assistance Act-an inappropriate Act, as I say-amounted to some $59,000, which included salaries subsidies, equipment subsidies and rental subsidies.

The case for the concept of purposeful activity for retired people as a means of preventing or at least deferring dependence on costly health services speaks for itself. The population of Australians 65 years and over is about one million, or 8.8 per cent, and this percentage is increasing. Most people, not least members of parliament engaged in constituency work, realise that when retirement deprives a person of a purposeful occupation, an extreme sense of loneliness and a lack of purpose often lead to the onset of illness and permanent disability which place that person in the hands of public welfare services and institutions. So it seems to me that this organisation is showing its value. However, it is limited by the level of financial assistance that it gets. It is the only one. No other beehive centre can get this sort of support throughout the country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West Mr S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I urge the Government and the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) to rethink their attitude to the case of Eamonn O'Connor while they still have an opportunity and before the inevitable increased bitterness which has poisoned British-Irish relations for so long is indelibly scoured into the Australian-Irish political scene by the death of this young man, however misguided his action may be.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me quickly outline the case for reconsideration of the Government's stated intention to emulate the vicious, hard-line attitude of Margaret Thatcher to the original hunger strikers in the Maze. Of 32 counties in Ireland, nine are in Northern Ireland and six of these have been under British rule since 1918 and British military occupation since the early 1970s.
