The decision to partition Ireland was an act of British colonialism carried out not in Ireland but in the House of Commons, and against a four-to-one opinion against partition by the Irish people. Religious sectarianism is not the prime cause of the present impasse. That cause is the colonial economic and social repression of the catholic people of Northern Ireland. The Irish catholics suffer the worst unemployment, have the worst jobs and live in the worst houses. Having visited the United Kingdom recently, I detected a rising sense of disorientation on the mainland of the United Kingdom. Whatever Margaret Thatcher, the Australian Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and the Minister for Foreign Affairs may say, eventually the British will get out of Ireland. I heard James Callaghan, the former Prime Minister and Home Secretary, when troops were sent into Northern Ireland a decade ago, advocate in the Commons the withdrawal of troops and the establishment of an independent Northern Ireland. An independent Northern Ireland is not my position. Eventually Ireland will be unified but Callaghan's view is a measure of the public despair and discontent rampant in the United Kingdom regarding Northern Ireland.

But these are not the life or death demands of the prisoners in the Maze. They demand to be treated as political prisoners, as do the 250 Irish republican prisoners who were convicted before March 1976. Explicitly, their demands are as follows: The right not to do prison work; the right not to wear prison uniform; the right to have free association with other political prisoners; the right to organise educational and recreational facilities and to receive one visit and one food parcel per week; and no loss of remission. For these simple demands, 10 hunger strikers have died already this year and now we have a problem in Australia.

The Australian Government's attitude to Eamonn O'Connor, who wishes the Government to intervene on behalf of his incarcerated countrymen, is the same as Margaret Thatcher's. Let us examine it. Let them die, says Margaret Thatcher, for they are suicides in support of their cause. She says there will be no agreement on political status and so the shameful charade continues. The Australian Prime Minister joins her by saying that this is no Australian matter and is simply a matter for the British to decide. That is not the view he took about South Africa or Zimbabwe. As Max Harris of the Australian says:
Indeed many people regard it as a stroke of bad luck that the Irish are not black. If they were Ireland would have been unified decades ago as part of the process of de-colonisation.

Even if it is true that whether Mr O'Connor lives or dies is not the Australian Government's affair, since in its view decisions regarding Northern Ireland are for the British, and if it is true that Mr O'Connor's attitude is for him alone to decide, the fact is that Margaret Thatcher could save the prisoners in the Maze. Similarly, the Prime Minister could save Mr O'Connor in Australia. There must be a better way than just abrogation of responsibility. Let the Prime Minister and his Government express their utmost concern to the United Kingdom Government that, firstly, the situation in the Maze already has cost too many lives; secondly, that there is a need for a political settlement; and thirdly, that concern for Northern Ireland is now impinging upon Australian politics. Let it be done quickly and let the man be informed and urged to accept this intervention within the parameters of his original demands and to cease his hunger strike. Then an Irish national's life will be saved and one small positive humanitarian Australian move for a settlement in Northern Ireland will have been made. As a humane Parliament, can we do less?

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last Thursday night I stood in this place to raise a matter of extreme importance to my electorate, to my State of Western Australia and to Australia as a whole. I refer to the intrusion of the Waterside Workers Federation of Australia into wheat handling at Kwinana in Western Australia. During that speech I made reference to the recent dispute, which is a result of that intrusion. I said:

SPEECH.PARA: Already an Australia-wide strike, which laid up 60 ships and $50m of wheat exports, has occurred because CBH had the temerity to seek to transfer four grain handler members of the WWF to country installations. Why did it do this? It did it because it had no gainful work for them at Fremantle.

A colleague of mine, the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Giles), in closing his speech on another matter expressed considerable disagreement with my argument. In fact, he said my speech was stupid. He claimed that the men's sacking was a piece of petty politicking--

TALK.START.PARA: —A good judge.

—Yes, well, that is all right. I am quite happy to say it but I will go on, will I not? He claimed that the men's sacking was a piece of petty politicking which 'threw into jeopardy the entire export shipment of wheat from this nation'. Whilst regretting the use of the word 'stupid', I am otherwise grateful for this statement to allow me to expand further on this matter and to draw attention to the great problem in our society of the acceptance of industrial expediency.

SPEECH.PARA: There were no petty politics. It is reasonable to say that an agreement did exist between the Waterside Workers Federation and the Co-operative Bulk Handling Grain Shipping Terminal that, until the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission hearing was resolved, manning levels would be maintained. As work had ceased in one area, CBH, mindful of the cost responsibility to its co-operative shareholders, sought to transfer four men to a country area where work was available, still maintaining manning levels. However, these newly initiated members of the WWF have learnt their first lesson well; that is, not to take any notice of their employer. They refused to be transferred. For that reason they were dismissed. Then, Charlie Fitzgibbon closed down the Australian wheat export, claiming breach of agreement. The honourable member for Wakefield, who was somewhat agitated in regard to the other subject, apparently did not hear the final words of my speech as recorded in Hansard. They were:
All they-
That is, the farmers-
really have to realise is that the strength of unions such as the Waterside Workers Federation of Australia is directly in proportion to the public's unsubstantiated fear of them.

The Western Australian farmer has no need to fear the WWF. He already owns all the facilities to load a ship at Kwinana. In fact, members of the WWF enter those premises with his permission. However, suddenly these farmers are told they should provide a handsome living and absolute security to an unspecified number of individuals who at no time have participated in the effort or risk-taking associated with growing a wheat crop. Why should they do this? It is not because these men possess some very special skills or propose to carry out the work to a degree of efficiency that cannot be improved. To the contrary; the wheat grower is to provide this employment because the men are members of the Waterside Workers Federation. He has no opportunity to pass on this cost to overseas customers, as many other sectors do when they have industrial problems of this nature. The scandals associated with the WWF in its traditional arena-shipside-are bad enough. I instance the $20m plus a year we pay to employ its already redundant members, the levies the union imposes on modern bulk shipping which has automatic loading facilities, and in this case the employers of wharfside labour paying the wages of those men involved in applying bans to wheat exports.

The legal process has run its course. Sir Leslie Price has abdicated his responsibility to Australian wheat growers for a very short term gain. The shareholder farmers of CBH now can turn only to the union movement for an example, and ignore Australia's laws that relate to this unsatisfactory situation. They must occupy the CBH terminal and commence the entire loading and handling procedure themselves.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just a few moments ago in this House we head an unbridled, unwarranted and, I feel, entirely unjustified attack on a council in Sydney of which I was formerly an alderman, that is, the Parramatta City Council. That attack was launched by the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock). In launching this attack, the honourable member for Dundas, I feel, has sullied not only his own escutcheon but also that of his party. He mentioned quite vehemently that the Parramatta City Council has been intemperate, unfeeling and unresponsive in its replies to attempts by a Community Youth Support Scheme group within my electorate with which I have a very close association, to have the Council provide it with some alternative accommodation. In doing that, the honourable member for Dundas made an attack which I would like to refute. In order to do that I think it would be fair for me to point out the very splendid and proud record of the Parramatta City Council in terms of its social welfare activities.

SPEECH.PARA: I am pleased to see that the honourable member for Dundas has re-entered the chamber so I can re-educate him a little in the facts of life. Of all the municipal and/or local government authorities in Australia none has a more splendid record in terms of generosity towards social welfare than the Parramatta City Council. I would like to outline some of the things it does. For instance-I know this is a subject dear to the honourable member's heart-the Parramatta City Council maintains, at a cost of something like $130,000 per year, the largest meals on wheels program in Australia. It is also a giant amongst the pygmies in terms of local government and its treatment of old age pensioners. Pensioners who have lived for five years within the City of Parramatta get a full rebate on rates, not chargeable against an estate after death, at a cost of something like $500,000 a year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it not now required by law?

—It is not required by law at all. Parramatta City Council also maintains a very large senior citizens centre within its city precincts-one of the largest in Sydney-at total government expense. On top of this I can name four properties which the Council provides for various social authorities. For instance, the Macquarie Legal Aid Service which replaced the defunct Australian Legal Aid Office, which has disappeared under the insensitivity of this Liberal Government, is maintained in premises at the Parramatta City Council's cost-free of charge. The Vietnam veterans are provided with premises from which they conduct their proper vendetta against the Government's insensitivity. The Parramatta Community Aid and Information Service is provided with something like a $40,000 a year subsidy and free premises. There are three cottages provided for the Rotary youth refuge, the Salvation Army youth refuge and a Lifeline youth refuge at Council expense. The CYSS group has been housed in a home at Council expense--
—No, rented.

—I am sorry. I arranged this matter as an alderman. It will be housed there until such time as the house is required to be removed in order to widen a road. On top of the things I have already mentioned the Parramatta City Council has the largest lending library service in Australia provided principally to assist the youth of the Parramatta City Council area.
—No more than any other authority provides.

—That is rubbish. I feel quite aggrieved that this man would come in here and launch an attack on a council which has a very proud and noble record in terms of supplying social welfare to its residents, which is properly the estate of the Federal Government. It strikes me as being very odd that this gentleman would have the temerity to attack a city council for failing, in his words, to back up properly a CYSS group when his own government is causing the demise of 300 similar groups around Australia. The cost to the youth of Australia-the despairing, helpless, restive youth of Australia-who cannot find employment because of the Government's action is incalculable. For this gentleman to come in here and criticise a local government authority because of his own political bias, to me is beyond belief. I think he should examine his conscience with regard to his own party and become a lion in the electorate as well as a lion here.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Mr M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think none of us would have been surprised earlier tonight to hear the energetic lack of interest of the honourable member for Cunningham (Mr West) in regard to his electorate by supporting another terrorist organisation, the provisional wing of the Irish Republican Army. This seems to me to be in keeping with his support for other terrorist organisations such as the Palestine Liberation Organisation and any other organisation which has no interest whatsover in his electorate.

SPEECH.PARA: Tonight I wish to raise a matter of some importance because it seems to me to be disappointing that the public's understanding of the new health insurance arrangements has been sufficiently clouded by a mist of propaganda from honourable members opposite that a totally wrong perception now exists throughout the nation. Health insurance is now cheaper or costs nothing at all for three-quarters of the people of Australia. Less than one in every four Australians now face dearer health insurance costs as a result of the Federal Government's changes to the health system that began last week. This is because the slightly higher weekly rates of health insurance will be far more than offset by a much bigger tax rebate, which the Government has also introduced.

One of the disastrous features of the present Government is that it does not promote or advertise itself with anything like the flair or the expense of Mr Wran's State Government in New South Wales. As a result, the untrue propaganda alleging a huge rise in health care costs in Australia now is widely believed. The honourable member for Bonython (Dr Blewett) can take credit for having spread that particularly nonsensical proposition. Three out of every four Australians are either better off or are paying no health insurance whatsoever. People such as the honourable member for Bonython who are spreading this untrue propaganda know it to be untrue.

Let us look at the facts and the dollars and cents of what it really costs now for health insurance. Under Medibank Private the old family rate of $9 per a week for basic cover went up on 1 September by $1.40 a week to $10.40. But this new weekly bill will bring a tax rebate of 32c in the dollar, which means the Government will repay $3.33 of this $10.40 bill. The simple fact is that the rise of $1.40 a week will be more than offset by a rebate of $3.33 a week, leaving the insured person better off by $1.93 a week or about $100 a year.

Is it not remarkable that a new system that is about $100 a year cheaper for a family should have been so dishonestly represented as involving a savage increase in costs? Similar savings are involved for those who insure with the Medical Benefits Fund of Australia Ltd, the Hospitals Contribution Fund of Australia or the Manchester Unity Fund-which, I might say, is my family's health insurance fund-or other funds. So the eight million Australians who have been covered by health insurance in the past now will be better off when they get their tax rebate cheque at the end of the financial year.

In addition, three million Australians who either are pensioners or are financially disadvantaged will continue to receive free health care under the new arrangements. By the way, there is a sort of inevitability about the Wran Government claiming all the credit in recent advertisements for this free health care for pensioners. In fact all but a very few pensioners will receive free health care entirely as a result of the Commonwealth Government's arrangements. Only a few thousand pensioners out of two million or so will be helped by the State Government. They will include those few pensioners over the age of 70 years who happen to be millionaires. The Federal Government is concentrating taxpayers' money on picking up the bill for those in real need.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Expenditure Commitments: Department of Industry and Commerce

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bungey Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What action has been taken to facilitate the importation of queen bee stock into Australia without quarantine risk?
(2) Are further initiatives planned; if so, what are they?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Existing quarantine legislation effectively limits the importation of queen bees to Australia to those from New Zealand, United States of America and Canada. This is because of the presence of Isle of Wight disease in most other countries.

However, the prevalence of Isle of Wight disease in Mexico is posing an increasing threat to North America apiculture. In addition, certain other bee diseases in North America are assuming increased significance. Accordingly, my Department has over the past four years, in conjunction with the New South Wales Department of Agriculture, developed a prototype bee quarantine facility which allows queen bees to be imported, held in quarantine and only their larvae released to the importer.

(2) In view of the success of the prototype facility a permanent facility capable of holding up to 24 queen bee importations at any time is being constructed at the quarantine station at Eastern Creek in Sydney. The facility is due for completion by mid-September 1981.

In conjunction with the development of the new facility revised legislation is envisaged which would require all importations, with the exception of bees from New Zealand, to be quarantined. This quarantine would apply as a standard procedure to importations from United States of America and Canada, but provision would also be made for the development of special conditions to allow importation from other parts of the world.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Koppers Pty Ltd Processing Plant, Hume, Australian Capital Territory

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kelly Mrs R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Capital Territory, upon notice, on 27 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is there a proposal to allow Koppers Pty Ltd to move their processing plant, which basically uses chromium, copper and arsenic, into the Hume industrial area, Australian Capital Territory; if so, has a thorough environmental impact study been undertaken by the National Capital Development Commision in relation to the proposed Koppers site and the impact of the processing plant on the Tralee Station International Tourist Complex.

(2) What study has been undertaken of the Tralee Station domestic water supply and, in particular, the underground water supply well which is also the only supply to the Canberra Fraser Park International Speedway Complex.
(3) Was any dialogue concerning this water supply undertaken with Mr Bernard Morrison.

(4) In view of the toxicity of CCA chemicals and their serious soil pollution potential, is he able to assure the public that a comprehensive study of the soils on the Koppers site has been undertaken on the texture, structure, depth, permeability and, in particular, the organic content of the soils.
(5) Is the least favourable soil for a plant of this type sand and gravel; if so, is this type of soil on the proposed site.

(6) Did Mr R. J. Corrigan, First Assistant Secretary, Lands Division, of his Department, say in a letter to the Joint Parliamentary Committee on the Australian Capital Territory that the soils rank reasonably well; if so, what authority carried out soil tests on the proposed site and where can the results of the tests be verified.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Koppers (Aust) Pty Ltd has sought a site in the ACT for a timber treatment plant that would use a copper, chrome, arsenate or CCA process for treatment of pine logs. A site in the Hume industrial area was selected following a detailed evaluation, undertaken in consultation with Koppers.

The evaluation considered issues related to the site location and the potentially adverse impact on the surrounding area, including the Tralee tourist complex; environmental issues associated with a CCA process; and appropriate protection measures.

The study drew heavily on environmental guidelines for CCA treatment plants currently being finalised by the Victorian Environment Protection Authority, these being thought to be the latest and most authoritative controls in the field.

Formal notification of the proposal was given to the Department of Home Affairs and Environment in May 1981 under the Environment Protection Administrative Procedures of the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act.
A recommendation about whether an Environmental Impact Statement should be required is awaited from the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment.

(2) No specific study of the Tralee Station domestic water supply or the underground well has been made. While environmental controls are designed to ensure that there is no significant pollutant escape from site, as a safeguard a number of bores are being drilled to facilitate regular monitoring of ground water surrounding the proposed plant site. Previous experience in the area suggests that ground water movement is predominantly northwards from the Koppers site and away from Tralee Station's underground water supply well but the possibility of movement in other directions is not being overlooked. While the well referred to may supply the Canberra Fraser Park International Speedway Complex it is not the only water supply available. Town water has been available to the property from the ACT for many years and could be used at the Speedway.

(3) Officers of the Department and the Commission attended meetings with Mr Morrison on 8 April 1980 and 27 February 1981. Information regarding the nature of the Koppers operation and proposed environmental controls, including material on proposed ground water protection, were provided to Mr Morrison. At neither meeting was the question of the Tralee Station water supply or the underground water supply well raised by Mr Morrison.

(4) In 1975 a report was prepared by the Bureau of Mineral Resources on the engineering geology of the Jerrabomberra Valley. The study area included the proposed Koppers site. The report considered significant geological and soil characteristics in the context of possible constraints on future development. It presented material on a number of soil characteristics including texture, structure, depth, permeability and identified the location of organic soils without specifically measuring organic content. The information available on soils was regarded as sufficiently detailed for identification of a suitable site for Koppers in the Hume area and in November 1980 the Bureau was asked to comment on the preferability in geological terms of two possible sites for the Koppers plant. The Bureau indicated a preference for the site presently proposed.

(5) The guidelines for CCA treatment plants referred to above indicate that the least favourable soil for a plant of this type is sand and gravel. The Bureau of Mineral Resources has indicated that in the area of the Koppers site the soil is predominantly a colluvium consisting of sand, silt and clay containing a thin discontinuous sand aquifer. With the presence of clay the situation is more favourable as clay soil types are considered capable of immobilising metal ions.

(6) Yes. The authority which carried out soil tests was the Bureau of Mineral Resources. Copies of the 1975 Report to N.C.D.C. on soil in the Jerrabomberra Valley and a professional opinion (1980) on the potential for ground water pollution associated with the two Hume sites considered for the purpose are available for examination at the offices of the National Capital Development Commission.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Timber Processing Plant, Hume Industrial Area, Australian Capital Territory

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kelly Mrs R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Capital Territory, upon notice, on 4 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Further to the information sought in my question No. 2328 relating to the proposal to allow Koppers (Aust) Pty Ltd to establish a timber processing plant in the Hume industrial area, Australian Capital Territory, has an environmental impact statement been completed, if not, why not.
(2) If an environmental impact statement has been completed, will it be made available to the public; if not, why not.
(3) Can he give an unqualified assurance that Lake Burley Griffin will not be affected by pollutants from this development; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) No. As advised in answer to Question 2328 a recommendation on whether an Environmental Impact Statement is required is awaited from the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment. Any decision on the Environmental Impact Statement must await this recommendation.

(3) The proposed environmental protection measures are designed to ensure that there is no significant escape of potential pollutants from the site. Further, a system of ground water monitor bores is being established to allow the effectiveness of the protection controls to be assessed.

The measures being applied reflect the most recent advances in the control of such pollutants and are designed to protect Lake Burley Griffin from foreseeable sources of pollution from this development. However, it is not possible to give the unqualified assurance sought, in relation to this or to any other development in the catchment of Lake Burley Griffin in the Australian Capital Territory or New South Wales.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Morris Mr P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 10 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) When did the Commonwealth contract Chandris Lines (Aust.) Pty Ltd as a carrier of migrants from the United Kingdom and Greece and when did the contract cease.
(2) In what circumstances was the contract terminated and why was it terminated.

(3) Were any complaints received concerning conditions on board Chandris vessels during the time under charter of the Commonwealth; if so, what was the nature of the complaints relative to (a) migrants, complaints, (b) paying passengers' complaints, (c) crew complaints, (d) Maritime Services' complaints, (e) Medical officers' complaints and (f) Coroners' findings.

(4) What was the (a) total complement of passengers and crew, (b) number of migrants, (c) number of paying passengers and (d) number of crew on board the southbound voyage of the S.S. Australis which departed Southhampton, United Kingdom, on 16 September 1977.
(5) How many (a) passengers and (b) crew (i) departed for Australia at Port Iraklion, Crete and (ii) embarked at Iraklion.
(6) How many (a) passengers and (b) crew was the Australis registered to carry.

(7) How many deaths occurred during the voyage of the Australis departing Southhampton on 16 September 1977 for Melbourne, what were the certified causes of death, who was or were the Australis' medical officer/s during the voyage and is he able to advise the repository of the sick-berth register kept during the voyage.
(8) Who captained the Australis during the voyage.
(9) Was the captain replaced at Fremantle, Western Australia; if so, why.
(10) Did the Australis have insufficient life-boats or rafts for the complement carried and was drinking water severely rationed on the voyage.
(11) Who were the Australian agents for the Australis during the voyage and were any complaints registered with the agents; if so, (a) how many and (b) what was the substance of each complaint.
(12) Who were the Australian directors of Chandris Lines (Aust.) Pty Ltd during 1977-78.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The contract became operative on 1 July 1970 and ceased on 31 December 1975.
(2) The contract was not renewed because it was decided that air transport was preferable and the immigration program had been reduced substantially.

(3) The Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has been able to locate reports from Welfare and Information Officers covering the period between September 1974 and November 1977 but they did not provide any indication of major or unusual complaints or problems. These reports relate to migrant welfare and do not cover parts (b), (c), (d), (e) and (f) of the question. The Department has been unable to locate any record of complaints falling into those categories. The Welfare and Information Officer reports indicate some complaints about the monotony of the food and it was generally described as basic, edible and ample. There were some reports of what might be regarded as usual shipboard ailments such as sea sickness, coughs and colds and dysentery and some cases among children of measles, mumps and chickenpox. On occasions there were complaints about cleanliness on board but regular inspections were maintained by the Captain and senior crew to ensure a reasonable standard of cleanliness.
(4) (a) and (d) No details have been located in the records of the Department of Immigratrion and Ethnic Affairs.
(b) 616 persons ex Southhampton.
(c) 1,681 persons ex Southhampton.
(5) and (6) No details could be located in Departmental records.
(7) As far as the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs is aware, no deaths occurred during the voyage.
(8) to (10) No details have been located in Departmental records.

(11) and (12) Mr George N. Pilavidis was the founder and owners' representative and Director of Chandris Lines (Aust.) Pty Ltd. The bookings for all voyages, including that of September 1977, were made direct with Mr Pilavidis. The Department has no information on the other matters raised.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Morris Mr P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 10 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did he or his predecessor in recent years receive complaints relevant to conditions experienced on board Chandris Lines (Aust.) Pty Ltd vessels, sailing from the United Kingdom and Greek ports to Australia, relative to (a) meals and food generally, (b) medical treatment, (c) overcrowding, (d) electrical failures, for example refrigeration or air-conditioning breakdowns, (e) shortages of drinking water, (f) general hygiene, (g) insufficient ablution amenities, due to replacement of such amenities by additional cabins and (h) deaths at sea.

(2) Have any complaints been registered concerning SS Australis, especially the southbound voyage departing Southhampton 16 September 1977; if so, (a) what were the complaints and (b) was advice given to the complainants to approach other Government Departments, such as maritime services, etc; if so, what Departments were recommended.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No record of complaints in recent years along the lines mentioned by the honourable member has been located in the records of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs.
(2) The only relevant record the Department was able to locate was a copy of a report by the Welfare and Information Officer for the voyage s.s.'Australis' ex Southhampton, 16 September 1977.

The report stated that the accommodation was on the whole of a good standard and the majority of passengers were quite satisfied. It was stated that the cleanliness of cabins and public rooms was of a surface variety but the Captain and senior officers carried out daily inspections on all decks to maintain a reasonable standard.
The meals were reported as being very basic and inclined to be monotonous.

It was stated that many passengers suffered from usual shipboard ailments, colds, coughs and diarrohea which spread quickly through the confined space of the ship. One passenger suffered a miscarriage. There was nothing in the report to indicate any serious problems; the report stated that the voyage was a pleasant and calm one with most passengers able to relax and enjoy their trip.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian Citizens Detained or Imprisoned Overseas

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Young Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 10 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many Australian (a) citizens and (b) permanent residents were (i) detained and (ii) imprisoned in each year since 1978 and during the period 1 January to 9 June 1981 and in what countries were they detained or imprisoned.
(2) On what charges, in each country, were these people (a) detained and (b) imprisoned and on behalf of how many have Australia's overseas missions intervened.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Figures and details are available only in respect of Australian citizens. Records of Australian residents are not kept as they are normally the consular responsibility of their countries of citizenship.

I do not propose to give specific details relating to each detention, arrest and charge to particular countries, as not all this information has been made public in Australia and its publication could be damaging to the persons concerned or to their families. If the honourable member requires specific information on particular cases or countries I can give it to him on a personal basis. I can however, give the information requested in general terms and this information for the period 1 January 1979 to 9 June 1981 is as follows:

(a) In 1979 the number of Australians detained was 209, the number imprisoned was 35, and the countries concerned were Belgium, France, the Federal Republic of Germany, the German Democratic Republic, Greece, India, Indonesia, Italy, Malaysia, New Zealand, Norway, Papua New Guinea, Spain, Sweden, Thailand, the United Kingdom and Yugoslavia.

(b) In 1980 the number detained was 201, the number imprisoned was 42, and the countries concerned were Afghanistan, Belgium, Denmark, Fiji, France, the Federal Republic of Germany, Greece, The Netherlands, India, Indonesia, Israel, Italy, Japan, Lebanon, Malaysia, Mexico, Nepal, New Caledonia, New Zealand, the Philippines, Papua New Guinea, Peru, Singapore, Syria, Tahiti, Thailand, Turkey, the United Kingdom, the United States of America and Vanuatu.

(c) From 1 January until 9 June this year 91 were detained, 18 imprisoned and the countries concerned were Canada, Czechoslovakia, France, the Federal Republic of Germany, Greece, India, Indonesia, Italy, Korea, Malaysia, Mauritius, New Zealand, Papua New Guinea, Singapore, Spain, Switzerland, Syria, Thailand, the United Kingdom, the United States of America.

(d) Of the arrests listed in a, b, and c, above, 238 were for drug offences and others were for robbery, murder, false pretences, currency offences, theft, conspiracy, wounding, forgery, hijacking, fraud, and immigration offences.
There may have been cases of Australians being detained or imprisoned overseas that did not come to official notice.

In the cases listed normal consular assistance was made available. Such assistance includes advising the detained person about his rights and position under the local legal system; notifying families in Australia if requested to do so; assistance with access to legal representaton; and providing other assistance which may be appropriate in the circumstances.

Australian missions did not formally intervene in the legal process in any of the cases listed. It is not policy to do so unless we are convinced that one of our citizens has not received the same treatment under the law of the country concerned as a citizen of that country would receive, or unless the application of the law in a particular instance falls below international standards. This is standard international practice.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Capital Territory, upon notice, on 18 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many persons are currently employed by the A.C.T. Milk Authority on a (a) full-time and (b) part-time basis.
(2) What were the (a) labour and (b) other costs of administering the Authority in 1979-80.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Since the inception of the Milk Authority of the Australian Capital Territory in 1971, the Department of the Capital Territory has provided staff for the Authority for which the Department receives full cost reimbursement. The Commonwealth Functions (Statutes Review) Act 1981 provides for the Authority to engage such employees as are necessary for the performance of its functions under terms and conditions determined by the Authority with the approval of the Public Service Board. Negotiations between the Authority and the Board are continuing.
Answers to the specific questions raised are:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: O'Keefe Mr F.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, upon notice, on 19 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: How many Aborigines in Australia are (a) full blood, (b) half-castes and (c) persons claiming Aboriginal origin.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Viner The Hon R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The five-yearly Population Census is the only official source of Aboriginal population figures. Since 1966 no attempt has been made in the Census to differentiate between people of varying degrees of Aboriginal ancestry.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 19 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many air traffic controllers are employed at each capital city airport in Australia.
(2) What are their duty shifts (a) during a regular week, (b) during peak periods and (c) at night.
(3) What are the relevant air navigation regulations in respect of minimum controller staffing for airports.
(4) What transpires when an air traffic controller at the Brisbane Airport becomes sick on a night shift.
(5) How many times in the last 5 years has the Brisbane Airport been closed because of (a) industrial disputes involving air traffic controllers and (b) staff shortage and illness.
(6) What plans does he have for increasing the air traffic controller staff in time for the influx of air traffic anticipated before, during and after the 1982 Commonwealth Games in Brisbane.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) Sydney-196; (b) Melbourne-130; (c) Brisbane-101; (d) Adelaide-75; (e) Perth-68; (f) Darwin-42; (g) Canberra-29; (h) Hobart-8.
(2) Controllers work a continuous 7 hour shift:
(b) As many extra staff as considered necessary for the peak (e.g. Easter Thursday evening) working on rostered overtime.

(3) Air Navigation Regulations do not specify minimum controller staffing for airports. However, sufficient staff is provided to ensure that the functions of air traffic control as specified in Air Navigation regulation 94 (1) can be safely achieved.
(4) The senior controller on duty, after assessing the current traffic situation, would if considered necessary, call out an off-duty controller.
(5) (a) 5 days in May 1977; 2 hours in 1979-stop work meeting.
(b) 2 closures for up to 7 hours-no replacement available for illness.
(6) Brisbane Airport is expected to be in full normal operation for the 1982 Commonwealth Games.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 19 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has he or his Department received any complaints or inquiries concerning the running of engines on the tarmac of the Brisbane Airport during the curfew period.
(2) What approval is required for the testing and running of aircraft engines during the curfew period.
(3) What part of the airport is allocated for this activity.
(4) How close is this area to the nearest residential area.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. Over the period from 1.1.80 to 24.6.81, one complaint concerning grounding running of aircraft engines, two complaints concerning aircraft start-up and taxying noise, and one complaint concerning both ground running and taxying noise were recorded.

(2) Running of aircraft engines during the curfew period is not permitted unless such running is a matter of urgent maintenance. For engine running for periods not in excess of five minutes duration at low power settings, no permission is necessary. For engine running for periods in excess of five minutes duration or at high power settings, the Senior Engineer of the airline company is required to obtain approval from the Senior Operations Controller.

(3) Ground running for less than five minutes duration, at low power settings, may take place adjacent to the maintenance hangars. Ground running for longer than five minutes duration or at high power settings is required to be undertaken adjacent to the threshhold of Runway 22 at the north-eastern side of the airport.

(4) The threshhold of Runway 22, where ground runs longer than five minutes must be undertaken, is 1.8 km from the centre of Pinkenba with 107 residences, and 2.8 km from the next closest residential area which is in Hendra, immediately north of the Doomben racecourse.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 19 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Have there been fewer Qantas 747 and 747SP aircraft movements along the flight paths over (a) Hamilton and (b) Bulimba/Hawthorne, Queensland, in July 1981 than occurred in previous comparable periods; if so, is there any relation between any reduction in aircraft movements over residential areas and recent public criticism of aircraft noise.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Information concerning flight paths at Brisbane Airport is only held for thirty days. It is, therefore, not possible for a direct comparison to be made between the number of Boeing 747 and Boeing 747SP aircraft movements over these areas during July 1981 and the number in a previous comparable period. However, for the last thirty days in July 1981, 45.9 per cent of the total number of B747/B747SP movements involved overflight of Hamilton or Bulimba/Hawthorne.
It could be anticipated that a relationship would exist between a reduction in overflights and public reaction to aircraft noise.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian-flag Trading Vessels: Repair Work in Overseas Ports

QUESTION.SPEAKER: West Mr S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 20 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Which Australian-flag trading vessels have undertaken repair work in overseas ports for each year since June 1975.
(2) What was the value of this repair work undertaken in overseas ports for each of the same years.
(3) What was the value of repair work undertaken by foreign-flag trading vessels in Australian ports for each year since June 1975.
(4) What was the value of repairs undertaken by Australian-flag trading vessels in Australian ports for each of the same years.

(5) When will the Government develop a policy to expand the Australian ship-repair industry and require a share of foreign-flag vessels trading regularly to Australia to have repairs done in Australia in line with the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development 40-40-20 concept.
(6) When will the Government develop a policy to expand the Australian trading fleet in line with the UNCTAD 40-40-20 concept.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: My Department does not maintain regular statistics on the activities mentioned in questions (1) to (4). However, the Department recently conducted a survey covering ship repair matters for the year 1979-80.
Accordingly, answers to questions (1) to (4) are given within the context of the survey results for 1979-80.
(1) Ten. The names of the vessels cannot be disclosed as they were provided on a confidential basis.
(2) $3.3m (repairs and maintenance involving drydocking).

(5) The UNCTAD 40-40-20 concept is embodied in the United Nations Convention on the Code of Conduct for Liner Conferences. That Code applies only to liner cargo trades and has no application internationally to ship repair activities.

The Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) reported on the need for assistance to the ship repair industry in December 1978, and recommended that no change be made to the assistance provided by the Australian Government. The Government has accepted this recommendation.

(6) Australia has decided not to accede to the Convention on the Code of Conduct for Liner Conferences at this stage because it does not provide adequate shipper safeguards or the means to ensure efficient services, when compared with Australia's existing legislation embodied in Part X of the Trade Practices Act, 1974.

As a result of the discussions I had with shipowners and maritime unions in May 1980, both parties agreed to participate in the Joint Committee on Revitalisation of the Australian Shipping Industry, chaired by Sir John Crawford. Sir John is expected to report shortly on practical proposals aimed at producing an efficient Australian shipping industry which can compete commercially with land-based domestic transport and international shipping.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Army and Air Force Canteens Service, Woomera

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Wallis Mr L.G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 25 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to reports circulating at Woomera, South Australia, that steps are being taken to dispose of the Army and Air Force Canteen Service at Woomera to private enterprise.
(2) If so, is there any substance in these reports.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Killen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The Woomera Community Store is managed on behalf of the Department of Defence by the Army and Air Force Canteen Service (AAFCANS), that is, it is not a normal AAFCANS service.

The Store has been operating at a loss for some time and strenuous efforts are being made by AAFCANS and the Department to restore it to profitability. I would hope that with the support of the Woomera community these efforts will succeed. Should this not occur, consideration will need to be given to whether alternative operating arrangements should be introduced. One option would be to invite private enterprise to take over the Store; however no serious consideration has yet been given to such a move.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jull Mr D.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 25 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What success has his Department had in recruiting air traffic controllers for Australia in overseas countries.
(2) How many controllers have ben recruited and from which countries have they come.
(3) How many controllers hired from overseas have been (a) Australian nationals returning to Australia and (b) aliens.
(4) Are figures kept on how many Australian controllers have been recruited by overseas countries during the last 3 years; if so, how many have been recruited and to which countries have they gone.
(5) What is the total cost of training an air traffic control officer in Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The overseas recruitment campaign for air traffic controllers is still in progress in the United Kingdom and Hong Kong. The campaign may be considered to be reasonably successful.
(2) It is expected that up to thirty-three Air Traffic Controllers may be recruited, comprising twenty-three from the United Kingdom and ten from Hong Kong.
(3) None of the controllers hired in the current campaign are either Australian nationals returning to Australia or aliens.

(4) No figures are kept on how many Australian controllers have been recruited by overseas countries. When staff resign they are not required either to state the reason or to name their future employer. However our most informed estimate is that seven have resigned to take air traffic controller positions overseas.

(5) An air traffic controller in training with previous aeronautical experience undertakes a one year short course at a cost of $25,000-$30,000. A trainee air traffic controller without prior relevant experience undertakes a three year long course at a cost of $65,000-$70,000. This figure includes as a cost 18 months training during which time the trainee is in fact performing, under supervision, the full duties of an operational position.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 27 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that the Australian Consul in Los Angeles, United States of America, is a former Minister for Administrative Services in his Government.
(2) Is it also a fact that the new official residence of the Australian Consul-General in Los Angeles has been leased at $10,960 a month at a daily rate of $350.
(3) Is the Consul-General's total salary, exclusive of fringe benefits, in excess of $40,000 per annum plus various expenses and allowances.
(4) If so, is the maintenance of a Consulate in Los Angeles at such expense consistent with the Government's repeated call for economic restraint.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Consul-General was a former Minister for Administrative Services. The Australian Consul is however a career officer with the Department of Foreign Affairs.
(2) Yes.
(3) Yes.

(4) Yes, the Los Angeles Consulate-General fills an important role in serving Australia's expanding consular, trade, information and general political activities in Southern California. As the largest city on the West Coast of the United States and an important centre of industry, Los Angeles is a significant focus for the development of Australian trade and investment opportunities.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 27 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Who are the private consultants engaged by the Government to examine the practicality of selling shares in Trans Australia Airlines.
(2) What are the terms of reference under which the consultants will operate.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The consultants to investigate the practicality of selling shares in TAA have not yet been appointed. It is anticipated that interested parties will be invited to make submissions shortly.

(2) As I announced on 13 May 1981, the consultant will be commissioned to examine the practicality of selling shares in TAA, including how this might be done in the light of the Government's domestic aviation policy. The consultant will also be required to report upon measures to ensure independent ownership of Australia's trunk airlines in the event of a decision to sell any part of TAA. The precise terms of reference, however, have yet to be finalised.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 12 May 1981 (Hansard, page 2222) Mr Hyde asked me a question, without notice, about the importation of oil rigs. I wish to add to the remarks I then gave in response to the question. At the time I informed the honourable member that the policy on the importation of oil rigs was under review.

ANSWER.PARA: The review has recently been completed and I announced on 17 August 1981 that the Government has decided, after taking fully into account the views of all parties concerned, to introduce forthwith a significant de-regulation in this area.

Details are in my Press Release of 17 August 1981 and it would suffice for me to say here that the review was aimed at ensuring that the policy does not inhibit development, or add to the costs, of the offshore oil industry.

I might add, on the aspect of costs that the previous policy may have caused the industry, that research by my Department has indicated that at least for the last six years there has been no case where a foreign drilling rig, approved under temporary arrangements for use in Australian waters, has had its program interrupted because a local rig became available.
